PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from five citizens), Gareth Evans (from 34 citizens), Gietzelt (from 17 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 47 citizens) and Reid (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support ``The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smo- king tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legal enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
2. Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Related Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependant Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income earning spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement Scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of X-rated videos into the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.
2. The Government has ignored the repeated protests of the Senate and the people of Canberra on this situation.
3. As a result, X-rated videos are being sold from Canberra to other States, although they are banned in all States.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government to ban the importation and sale of X-rated video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:
We the undersigned-assembled.
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) Note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the Government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the Government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: BLOOD DONATION (ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME) (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE (No. 2) 1986

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the next day of sitting for disallowance of section 2 of the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986. I seek leave to make a statement which is a little longer than normal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sought the indulgence of the Senate to make a longer statement than usual about the scrutiny by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances of this short but very important Ordinance concerning blood transfusions and the acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The principal Blood Donation Ordinance 1985 stated that, provided certain testing procedures were used, the Red Cross Society would have a statutory defence if sued by persons who had contracted AIDS from Red Cross blood. This defence was provided at the request of the Society's insurance companies, which had refused to continue insurance coverage without the enactment of such a statutory defence.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Committee scrutinised the Ordinance late in 1985 we expressed very serious concern about its implications and the possible denial of rights of action to those victims of AIDS who had contracted the illness from contaminated blood transfusions or products. After an in camera hearing at which the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, attended and advised the Committee, it was agreed that the Ordinance would be amended so that the statutory defence would not avail the Red Cross or its insurers where actual negligence in the performance of the testing or other procedures had directly or indirectly led to the infection.

The Minister also agreed at that time to place a 12-month sunset clause in the Ordinance to limit its duration while research continued on whether the prescribed blood testing procedures could be improved upon and whether some form of national compensation scheme for blood transfusion victims of AIDS could be devised. These matters were reported to the Senate on 27 November 1985.

Section 2 of the latest Blood Donation Ordinance repealed that initial sunset clause to ensure that the modified statutory defence remained in force. Unfortunately, the Committee had not been informed that this would happen. There was also a lack of communication regarding progress with the Committee's suggested full scale review of testing procedures and compensation rights. In correspondence with the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) the Committee learned that the insurance companies, which had originally insisted on the statutory defence, had withdrawn totally from the scene, notwithstanding the enactment of the defence. It seems that to their minds, even with the statutory defence, the risk of liability was too great in terms of the economic return that would be obtained from premiums. I should say that their decision to withdraw was unrelated to the Committee's insistence on a modification of the defence in the Australian Capital Territory expressly to protect, in some degree, a person's right to sue for negligence.

The position now is that the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, backed by the Commonwealth Government, has undertaken to indemnify the Australian Capital Territory Red Cross Society in claims against it, provided that it has complied with the prescribed blood testing procedures. Similar arrangements also exist in the States. The Committee has also learned from the Minister that a compensation working party of the National Advisory Committee on AIDS has done some work on the question of compensation rights for victims of AIDS contracted from blood transfusions and other non-sexual transmissions of the disease.

When we examined the latest Ordinance which unexpectedly repealed the protective sunset clause, the Committee had the following concerns of principle: Firstly, it is a most serious matter for any legislation to take away rights of action. It is of course, if anything, more serious when delegated legislation is used. Taking away common law rights by legislation should be done only after the greatest consideration and, hopefully, when something more beneficial to the person who has the common law rights is given to that person in the absence of such rights. Much reflection and balancing of interests is required where it is proposed to use legislation to circumscribe a litigant's right of action or his or her chances of success in court. This issue is here compounded by the exceptionally serious medical, legal and social problems presented by AIDS. The Committee's earlier scrutiny of the main Ordinance in 1985 had tried to ameliorate the invasion of rights.

Secondly, the Ordinance represents a point of legislative contact between the Senate and the Government in its response to AIDS. The issues are serious and some form of continuous parliamentary oversight of developments in the war against AIDS is needed, At least as far as the technical, legal aspects of this ordinance is concerned, this Committee can and will perform an oversighting role on behalf of the Senate. The broader issues and the question of whether, for example, a select committee is needed are, of course, matters beyond the scope of the Committee's technical responsibilities.

Thirdly, since the Committee last looked at the Ordinance, no real advances appear to have been made in improving the prescribed blood testing procedures. They are regarded as 99 per cent reliable on persons in whose blood the AIDS antibody has already developed. The Committee has learned that it can take between four weeks and 40 weeks for an infected person's blood to develop identifiable antibodies detect- able by state of the art testing procedures. This unpredictable corridor of vulnerability exists and it is a limitation in the medical tests which has not yet been overcome. It can result in a person contracting AIDS and the Red Cross would not be liable to the victim in the absence of strict product liability or negligence.

Fourthly, the examination of a possible compensation scheme which could, to some extent at least, offset any limitation on the right to sue for blood product liability has not yet progressed to a conclusion. We understand that the Government recognises that there is a case for a compensation scheme and the question is still being looked at. To ensure that honourable senators are kept informed of the relevant issues arising from the Committee's scrutiny, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's correspondence to and from the Minister.
Leave granted.

PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE

24 February 1987
The Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P.
Minister for Territories

Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 February 1987 the Committee considered the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986, being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 90 of 1986. Section 2 of the Ordinance repeals section 10 of the Principal Ordinance which had provided for the Ordinance to cease to have effect on 1 January 1987. The Explanatory Statement explains that the reason for preserving the operation of the Principal Ordinance is the continuing need of the Red Cross Society to be protected from legal action where, notwithstanding the Society's compliance with prescribed procedures in the handling of blood and blood products, a person contracts AIDS from blood supplied by the Society.

As you know, prior to an administrative reorganisation last year, responsibility for this legislation rested with the Minister for Health, the Hon. Dr Neal Blewett, M.P., with whom the Committee, in 1985, had extensive discussions concerning the operation of the Principal Ordinance. In a letter to the Committee, dated 22 November 1985, Dr Blewett undertook, at the request of the Committee, to insert a sunset clause into the Ordinance. In its initial scrutiny of the Ordinance in September 1985, the Committee had been concerned about certain aspects of the Ordinance, including the provision of a statutory defence for the Red Cross Society in civil actions by persons who had allegedly contracted AIDS from blood supplied by the Society. This statutory defence, the drafting of which was subsequently revised to confine its scope, was included because without it the A.C.T. Society was unable to obtain insurance cover for its A.C.T. operations. The Committee was extremely concerned that such a special defence was needed and that insurance coverage for such a vital aspect of the health system was in doubt. In its letter to Dr Blewett of 18 October 1985, the Committee wrote

``The Committee is strongly of the view that you should amend the Ordinance to insert a sunset clause to provide for its expiry in the shortest reasonable time, but at least before the end of the autumn parliamentary sittings in 1986, while a genuine review of all the issues occurred. This review would allow assessment of: the above matters; new and improved testing methods which might be introduced (and which might improve further the insurability of the risk); the possibility of a system of indemnity or a no-fault liability fund; and the introduction of a replacement Bill into the Parliament. Consideration might also be given to extending the insurance, the fund or the Bill to cover tissue or organ donations and other diseases. These would all of course be matters on which you would need to consult fellow Health Ministers in the hope of a nationally uniform arrangement.''
The Committee noted Dr Blewett's reply of 22 November 1985 in which he stated

``I do, however, share your Committee's view that our knowledge of the AIDS virus and epidemic is constantly increasing and that it is important that both blood testing procedures and legislative provision dealing with AIDS be constantly reviewed and, where necessary, updated. I am, therefore, happy to undertake to review the Ordinance and its procedures on a regular basis to ensure that if any new tests or procedures become available and receive scientific approval, they can be adopted without delay. Given that AIDS is to be the subject of further consideration at next year's Australian Health Ministers' Conference, I am also agreeable to raise with State and Territory Health Ministers at that forum matters which are of particular concern to the Committee and to keep the Committee informed of any national action adopted by Ministers at the Conference that may affect the scope of the Ordinance . . . If the Committee still remains concerned with the Ordinance after the above undertakings, I would reluctantly agree to the insertion of a `sunset clause'. I firmly believe, however, that the operative date of such a clause should not be earlier than 31 December 1986. Any period ending earlier than 31 December 1986 is unrealistic in the light of current experience, both in relation to the settling of future insurance contracts to cover the Society and the implementation of any action agreed to at next year's Australian Health Ministers' Conference.''

The Committee was pleased to accept this outcome and after you had assumed responsibility for A.C.T. health matters, you wrote to the Committee on 11 February 1986 indicating your willingness to give effect to Dr Blewett's undertakings. The Committee's scrutiny of this matter involved a considerable volume of correspondence, and a number of meetings, including one in camera hearing with the Minister for Health himself yet, as you know, the Committee has not received any further communication from you concerning this aspect of the Ordinance. Since the sunset clause was placed in the Ordinance at the request of the Committee, it is somewhat surprising, to say the very least, that the Committee was not informed of either the progress of the review referred to in its letter of 18 October 1985 or the decision to repeal the clause.

Because of its implications, the Committee has, of course, had a continuing interest in the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance. In particular, the Committee has been concerned to ensure that the decision by Parliament itself to remove from the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 former clause 206, which was virtually identical in effect to section 3 of the Principal Ordinance, would not give rise to potentially discriminatory effects for veterans being treated in A.C.T. and State repatriation hospitals. At the Committee's request, the Committee Secretary wrote to your Department on 24 February 1986 and 17 April 1986, and to the A.C.T. Health Authority on 13 June 1986, raising this issue on behalf of the Committee. None of these letters produced any response from your Department or the Authority until the Committee wrote to you on 22 August 1986 reiterating its concern about potentially discriminatory implications of the respective legislation. In your reply of 10 October 1986, you indicated that there may be validity in the Committee's concern and suggested that the matter be taken up with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator the Hon. Arthur Gietzelt. In response to the Committee's letter to him of 17 October 1986, Senator Gietzelt, noting that the Ordinance contained a sunset clause, deferred any comment on the matter until the future of the Ordinance was known.

The Committee wishes to express to you its concern about the way in which this most important and most sensitive matter has been dealt with to date. The Committee expected that it might have been kept informed of general developments impacting on those matters of concern to it, in particular, the outcome of the extensive review recommended by the Committee in its letter of 18 October 1985 and the decision embodied in this latest Ordinance to repeal the sunset clause. The problem of inconsistency between the Minister's Blood Donation Ordinance and the Parliament's Veterans' Entitlements Act is a further complicating factor which, for the past year, the Committee has been trying to have resolved.

The Committee regards these as important issues and it would very much welcome your comments on them. I have sent a copy of this letter to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, with a covering letter drawing his attention to the repeal of the sunset clause and inviting his comments on the question concerning the differing rights of A.C.T. and State veterans.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Senator Cooney,
Thank you for your letter of 24 February 1987 concerning the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986 and the Principal Ordinance which it amended.

I wish to apologise at the outset for not informing the Senate Standing Committee of the repeal of the sunset clause from the Principal Ordinance. The deadline of 1 January 1987, which was required to be met if the Ordinance was to continue, effectively precluded referral of the question of repeal of the sunset clause to the Senate Standing Committee. The consequence of deferring the repeal of the sunset clause until the Committee was informed would have been the repeal of the Ordinance with resultant loss of protection from legal liability for the ACT Red Cross and the removal of the requirement that donors make declarations as to whether they are at risk of having been exposed to the AIDS virus. Accordingly immediate action had to be taken to prevent repeal of the Ordinance.

Steps were taken to arrange for the continuance of the Principal Ordinance because the ACT Red Cross had indicated there were no scientific advances which had a practical application to mass testing for the AIDS virus and it could still not obtain insurance. The Red Cross has recently written to the ACT Health Authority concerning these issues and confirms that they remain a problem (see attachment `A').

You will note the Red Cross no longer has insurance and is not totally dependent upon the protection provided by the Principal Ordinance and indemnification by the Health Authority providing it complies with the testing requirements of the Principal Ordinance (see attachment `B'). Up until 1 September 1986, the Red Cross had national insurance which was conditional upon the continuance of legislation comparable to the Principal Ordinance in all states except New South Wales and Queensland (each of which provided separate indemnification).

The national insurance had covered AIDS related claims which may be made regardless of the effect of the Principal Ordinance (such as negligence in the labelling of containers). National insurance was discontinued amid steps to provide indemnification against these claims by the States and Territories which have similar legislation to the Principal Ordinance. Agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and the States to fund jointly the indemnity. The Health Authority's indemnity was part of that process. Accordingly, the Principal Ordinance remains part of the scheme to protect the Red Cross from litigation. Without that protection the Red Cross has indicated it may be forced to discontinue its service in the ACT.

Of major importance are the requirements of the Principal Ordinance that donors make declarations as to whether they are at risk of having been exposed to the AIDS virus and the penalty for making false statements in the declaration (see Sections 5 (a), 7 and 8). Even if the Red Cross was to continue to provide this service without protection, the absence of the declaration requirements through disallowance of the amending Ordinance, would increase the possibility of infection of the local population. This would undermine the credibility of efforts to supply blood in the ACT and is likely to destroy confidence in the supply for some time.

From the outset it was understood the review recommended by your Committee on 18 October 1985 was to be conducted by the Commonwealth Department of Health as part of its national initiatives in conjunction with the National Advisory Committee on AIDS. I am advised the National Advisory Committee on AIDS established a Compensation Working Party and that common law recovery rights affected by the Principal Ordinance and comparable legislation in the States have received the attention of that Committee. It is recognised that there is a case for these AIDS victims to receive alternative compensation.

The National Advisory Committee on AIDS received a report on this issue on 4 February 1987 and referred the matter to the Inter-Departmental Committee on AIDS recommending that a statutory cause-base compensation scheme related as nearly as possible to common law benefits be established. The Inter-Departmental Committee will be considering the matter in the near future and I will be advising the Minister for Health to proceed with the scheme as soon as possible (see attachment `C') for a copy of the deliberations and Working Party Report to the National Advisory Committee on AIDS).

The disallowance of the Ordinance at this stage would not advance the position of victims should they subsequently have been afforded a much simpler and more satisfactory system of compensation to the alternative of initiating common law actions.

I seek your co-operation in approving the proposed amendment. Disallowance will result in the collapse of the ACT blood donation service and could undermine its credibility for some time. Furthermore it would be unlikely to benefit AIDS victims and could hinder their access to the type of compensation proposed by the National Advisory Committee on AIDS.
Yours sincerely,
GORDON SCHOLES

Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 30 April 1987 the Committee considered your letter and attachments of 27 April 1987 concerning the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 90 of 1986). The Committee thanks you for the letter and the accompanying papers which were useful in informing the Committee of progress made in offsetting the creation of a statutory defence by development of an appropriate compensation scheme. However, bearing in mind its initial scrutiny of the Principal Ordinance, the Committee remains concerned about the implications of the Ordinance.

As you know the Committee's original interest in the Principal Ordinance arose from its concern about the provision of a statutory defence for hospitals, medical practitioners and the Red Cross Society in common law negligence actions by plaintiffs who had innocently contracted AIDS from blood transfusions. As your attached paper by the Melbourne legal academics Messrs Evans and Patrick indicates at pages 12 and 13, common law recovery rights of innocent AIDS victims were severely affected by a very significant limitation on their personal legal rights. As far as the A.C.T. is concerned the Committee's requested amendments to sections 3 and 4 of the Principal Ordinance, made by sections 4 and 5 of the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 47 of 1986) have modified the width of the statutory defence in sections 3 and 4. The committee has noted with interest that the Red Cross Society's insurance cover, originally made available only on condition that a statutory defence be enacted, lapsed in August 1986 and the A.C.T. Health Authority has now undertaken to indemnify the Society against successful claims provided the Society has complied with the blood testing and other requirements of the Principal Ordinance.
The Committee now understands the position to be as follows:

a (modified) statutory defence, insisted upon by relevant insurance companies as a precondition for issuing insurance cover, remains in force notwithstanding the apparent refusal of those insurers to renew their insurance coverage;
that statutory defence is not felt to be needed to protect repatriation hospitals and medical practitioners since it does not appear in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986;
The A.C.T. Health Authority, backed by the Commonwealth Government, has, in effect, taken over the role of the Society's insurer;

a blood donor, wittingly or unwittingly infected with the AIDS virus, may contaminate the blood supply for up to 40 weeks before his or her HIV antibodies are detected by state-of-the-art testing which is considered to be 99% reliable;

accident victims, surgical patients, and, to a vastly greater extent, haemophiliacs, are exposed to a medically assessed probability of being innocently infected by AIDS virus from blood transfusions and products;

in the absence of proof of negligence, such persons have no right to compensation; when their health inevitably collapses then in the absence of private means, they may become social welfare dependants; and

it appears that as far as the Red Cross Society is concerned the only major, and perhaps only realistic, role played by the Principal Ordinance is to provide significant penalties for making wilfully false statements in the donor declaration form.

The Committee's concern in all of this is two-fold. Firstly, it is concerned, as a matter of principle, that delegated legislation does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties and that it does not contain matter more appropriate for enactment by Parliament than a Minister. It is, of course, a trespass on rights to circumscribe, directly or indirectly, a litigant's ordinary right of access to the courts. Further, although the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome is potentially the most important health issue in Australia, the legislative role of the Federal Parliament is affected by the legislative rights of the States. Secondly, the A.C.T. Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance is the major legislative point of contact between the Parliament and those responsible for all aspects of the management of the AIDS problem.

It is the Committee's strong view, therefore, that the sunset clause which the amendment Ordinance repeals should be re-enacted to come into operation again in say, 6 months, but limited in its scope to sections 3 and 4 of the Principal Ordinance. At that time the Committee would hope to have from you informative documents and materials, like those attached to your letter, which the Committee would hope to table in the Senate for the continuing information of Senators. (When agreement is reached between us on this matter and the Committee moves to withdraw its protective notice of disallowance, the present attachments will be tabled for the information of Senators.) Since no progress has been made in improving testing methods, and since a compensation scheme for innocent victims has not yet been finalised, the Committee considers that the situation now is essentially the same as that prevailing on 18 October 1985 when the Minister for Health was asked to enact the sunset clause which the current Ordinance repeals. As was the case last October, a further sunset clause would be a most valuable incentive to encourage progress with the review of these matters.

As you know the Committee in its scrutiny of legislation traditionally endeavours, as far as possible, to proceed through agreement with Ministers rather than by advocating disallowance of instruments which may infringe its Principles. The Committee is hopeful that in this most important and most sensitive matter you will be able to agree with the Committee's suggestion about a further sunset clause.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
MINISTER FOR TERRITORIES
HON GORDON SCHOLES, M.P.
Member for Corio
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
Thank you for your letter of 1 May 1987 concerning the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) (Amendment) Ordinance (No 2), 1986 and the Principal Ordinance which it amended.

Your decision to recommend that the operation of any sunset clause be limited to sections 3 and 4 is welcomed in view of the importance of other provisions in the legislation. However, due to the complexities of the matter and the resources which become tied up in re-enacting legislation, it is preferable not to limit the operation of sections 3 and 4 for less than 12 months.

It takes several months to develop and finalise even simple amendments to legislation. A sunset clause limiting the operation of these provisions for less than 12 months would not provide sufficient time to ensure the issues covered by them are properly pursued and reviewed. The issues will require consultation with the Commonwealth Departments of Health and Finance which in turn may need to consult with the States. I propose therefore to arrange for the insertion of a sunset clause which would allow the particular sections to operate for a further 12 months.

Your Committee will be kept closely informed on developments concerning issues relevant to sections 3 and 4 of the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance, 1985 and it will be provided with relevant material available for tabling in the Senate.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That the Order of the Senate of 22 February 1985 relating to the consideration of papers presented by Ministers be varied:
(a) by leaving out sub-paragraph (2) (d) and inserting the following sub-paragraph:

`(d) on Thursdays, at the commencement of General Business, when an Order of the Day is called on under this Sessional Order Senators who have previously spoken to that Order of the Day may speak again for not more than 5 minutes, and debate under this Sessional Order at that time shall not exceed 1 hour.'; and
(b) by adding after paragraph (2) the following paragraphs:

`(2a) Where a paper is presented but is not called on under paragraph (1) because of the limitation of time provided by paragraph 2 (b), the consideration of that paper shall be made an Order of the Day for the next day on which General Business is considered at the commencement of General Business, without any question being put, and where that Order of the Day is called on at that time, a motion may be moved without notice to take note of that paper.

(2b) Where consideration of a paper is an Order of the Day in accordance with paragraph (2a), it shall remain an Order of the Day for each succeeding day on which General Business is considered at the commencement of General Business until:
(a) the Order of the Day is called on and no motion to take note of the paper is moved;
(b) a motion to take note of the paper is determined; or
(c) the Order of the Day is discharged from the Notice Paper,
whichever first occurs.'.
2. That the following proposed Sessional Order be agreed to:
That the Standing Orders have effect as if Standing Orders 141, 142, 143, 144, 144, 145 and 149 were deleted and the following Standing Orders inserted:
`140. In respect of every amendment the President shall put a question, `That the amendment be agreed to'.

`141. An amendment to a motion may not be moved if it is the same in substance as an amendment already determined to the same motion, or would have the effect only of reversing an amendment already made.'
[Note: these Standing Orders are expressed to apply to amendments to motions, but by virtue of Standing Order 201 apply also to amendments moved to Bills in Committee of the Whole.]
3. That the following proposed Sessional Order be agreed to:
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the following procedures apply in respect of Bills:
(1) A Senator may present a Bill or two or more Bills after the Senate has agreed to a motion upon notice, setting out the long title of the Bill or Bills, that the Bill or Bills be introduced.

(2) After the presentation of a Bill or Bills, or after the receipt of a message or messages from the House of Representatives forwarding a Bill or Bills for concurrence, a motion may be moved without notice containing any of the following provisions:

(a) that the Bill or Bills may proceed without formalities (this shall have the effect of suspending any requirements for stages of the passage of the Bill or Bills to take place on different days, for notice of motions for such stages, and for the printing and certification of the Bill or Bills during passage);

(b) in respect of two or more Bills, that the Bills may be taken together (this shall have the effect of allowing the questions for the several stages of the passage of the Bills (or any of them) being put in one motion at each stage, the consideration of the Bills (or any of them) together in Committee of the Whole, and the reading of the short titles only on every order for the reading of the Bills, the words in parentheses being applicable where there are more than two Bills);
(c) that the Bill, or, where the provision referred to in sub-paragraph (2) (b) is agreed to, the Bills, be now read a first time.
(3) Where a motion is moved containing two or more of the provisions set out in paragraph (2), at the request of any Senator the motion shall be divided and the provisions put as separate motions.
(4) If, after the second reading of a Bill or Bills, leave is granted for the third reading to be moved forthwith, a motion for the third reading may be moved accordingly.
4. That the following proposed Sessional Order be agreed to:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, when debate on a motion is adjourned, by motion or by the granting of leave for a Senator to continue the Senator's speech, the resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting without any question being put, unless a motion is agreed to fixing another time for the resumption of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the explanatory notes relating to those notices of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The explanatory notes read as follows-

These proposed sessional orders are put forward with the aim of streamlining the proceedings of the Senate. The first two were recommended by the Standing Orders Committee in its Fifth Report for the Sixty-second Session, presented on 30 March 1987. The other two are designed to eliminate, with appropriate safeguards, procedures which have become purely formal and routine.

1. Consideration of Government Papers-The Standing Orders Committee, having been asked by the Senate to consider the sessional order relating to government papers, recommended these amendments of the sessional order. The effect of the amendments would be that papers not reached during the half-hour debate each day would be automatically listed for consideration at General Business time on Thursday, and would remain listed until disposed of.

2. Putting of Amendments-The Standing Orders Committee recommended that all amendments be put in the form: `That the amendment be agreed to'. This would avoid the inconvenient double question when words are proposed to be left out and other words inserted, and avoid the situation, which has occurred several times, of the Senate being left with a meaningless motion.
3. Proceedings on Bills-This proposed sessional order is designed to eliminate certain motions in the stages of the passage of Bills.

Paragraph (1): This would provide a simple motion for the introduction of a Bill which is making its first appearance in the Senate, and would allow two or more Bills to be introduced together where it is intended to move a motion to allow the Bills to be taken together. If the Senate does not agree to allow this, the Bills in question would proceed separately.

Paragraph (2): This paragraph provides that, after a Bill has been introduced or received from the House of Representatives, the necessary motions to set proceedings on the Bill in train may be `telescoped' into one motion. The individual parts of the motion are:
(a) that the Bill may proceed without formalities;
(b) where there are Bills to be taken together, that the Bills may be taken together; and
(c) that the Bill be now read a first time.

These motions are all moved separately under current procedures. The only changes which have been made to them are that the phrase `proceed without formalities' has been substituted for `taken through all stages without delay', because the latter misleadingly suggests that a Bill is going to proceed forthwith, and the motion to take Bills together is simplified.
The motion for the second reading of a Bill would still be moved separately and debate on that motion could be adjourned in accordance with the usual practice.

Paragraph (3) provides, as a safeguard, that any Senator may ask that the parts of the `telescoped' motion be put separately. This preserves the right of any Senator to vote against any part of the compound motion or to adjourn debate on the first reading of a non-amendable Bill.

Paragraph (4) provides that, if no Senator objects, the Committee of the Whole stage of a Bill may be dispensed with. Many Bills pass through Committee of the Whole stage without any debate or amendments being moved, and this procedure would be used in relation to those Bills to avoid the necessity for going in and out of Committee as a mere formality. If any Senator objects to the Committee stage being dispensed with, it must take place. This procedure has been used in the House of Representatives since 1963.

4. Adjournment of Debates-This proposed sessional order would avoid the necessity of moving a motion for the resumption of a debate whenever a debate is adjourned. It is proposed that an adjourned debate be automatically made an order of the day for the next day of sitting unless some other time is fixed by a motion. This would dispense with the great majority of resumption motions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make, unlike my lawyerly colleague Senator Cooney, a very brief statement concerning these notices of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four notices of motion I have given contain an amendment to the sessional orders and three new sessional orders designed to streamline proceedings of the Senate. Two of the proposals were recommended by the Standing Orders Committee in its report of 30 March. The Committee agreed that it would be appropriate for me as Manager of Government Business to take action to put them into effect. They relate to the automatic listing under General Business of Government papers not reached during the daily half-hour and a simplified method of putting amendments in this place. The other two proposals, which were discussed by the Standing Orders Committee but not formally reported on, relate to streamlining proceedings for the introduction of Bills and avoidance of the necessity for a formal resumption motion whenever a debate is adjourned. The proposed sessional orders have been formulated to streamline proceedings, as I have said, and also to avoid unnecessary motions without in any way detracting from the rights of senators. I commend them to the Senate.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the figures released yesterday by the Real Estate Institute of Australia showing that average home loan repayments in Australia have increased by a staggering $281 per month under the Hawke Government-from $350 per month in the March quarter 1983 to $631 per month in the December quarter 1986. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the figures cited by Senator Chaney relate to a period before the decline in interest rates which has taken place generally and not, in the broad of course, affecting housing interest rates. I appreciate that. I understand that the figures were compiled some time ago. Be that as it may, the circumstances of 1983 were vastly different from those of 1986 and 1987 when some $9 billion was taken off Australia's export earnings-that is, there has been a very substantial devaluation of the dollar during that period.

ANSWER.PARA: As has been said on a number of occasions in the Senate-and I do not wish to labour the fact-it is simply true that interest rates have been high as a result of those macroeconomic factors in the economy. The Government is not unmindful of the point of Senator Chaney's question. It is certainly very concerned about it. That is why a May expenditure statement will be brought down on Thursday of this week and will involve substantial cuts in Government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean Wednesday?

—Thank you, Senator-it will be brought down on Wednesday of this week. That statement will lead to substantial cuts in Government expenditure and hopefully that will contribute to a sustainable fall in interest rates in the foreseeable future-and I use the word `sustainable' quite carefully. I do not think I can add much to that except to say that, during the period since we have been in government, the first home owner's scheme will have assisted almost 250,000 first home buyers up to the end of the financial year 1986-87. When this Government came to office there had been an enormous slump in commencements to 105,000 in 1982-83. That situation has been much improved since the present Government has been in power.

—I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister in his reply placed some reliance on the decline in the terms of trade under Labor. I ask him: Is it not a fact that the Government has chosen a high interest rate policy rather than reducing government expenditure and taking a stronger line on wages in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its accord with the trade union movement and that that is the reason which underlies the high interest rates which are putting such pressure on Australian home buyers and home owners?

—There are a number of factors in that part of the question. Senator Chaney referred to the Government's having opted for a high interest rate policy instead of cutting government expenditure. I do not have the precise figures in front of me now, but government expenditure has been reduced substantially throughout the life of this Government.
—Ha, ha!

—As a percentage of gross domestic product. Insofar as the wages policy is concerned, we have had a very stable one throughout the period of government. That is of considerable concern, particularly to lower income groups in this community. Secondly, I would make the point that a number of other factors have contributed to benefits for less well-off sections of the community which have had some offsetting effect. It is not true to say that the Government has chosen an interest rates policy to the exclusion of doing anything on the fiscal front or on the wages policy front. Both of those things have been done, and they are equally contributing to the problem of trying to adjust the declining terms of trade in the Australian domestic economy to a situation where the effects of that terms of trade decline are borne equally by the community.

—I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the outrageous action of the Tasmanian Liberal Government and so-called Independent legislative councillors in refusing to fill the Senate casual vacancy with Labor's properly chosen nominee in accordance with the letter and spirit of the Australian Constitution. Is it constitutionally possible for Tasmania to continue without its correct representation in this chamber beyond the short period envisaged in the Constitution? Can the Commonwealth take any action, legal or otherwise, to ensure that Tasmania and the Australian Labor Party are not disadvantaged by Mr Gray's unprincipled behaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, as the Attorney-General has pointed out in recent days, the Constitution, as amended in 1977, is not expressly written in such a way as to compel any parliament to choose the endorsed nominee of a particular party as the successor to a departed senator in the case of the casual vacancy. Whether there is some implied obligation to do that, which would give rise at least to some declaratory judgment, is, of course, a complex matter for legal argument if and when this matter should ever come to court. Issues of justiciability, issues of standing and issues of the proper interpretation of the relevant provisions of the Constitution are involved. I do not think it is appropriate for me to speculate here, even if it were within Standing Orders, on what the outcome of any such legal action might be.

ANSWER.PARA: What is clear is that the Constitution ensures that a government and parliament, behaving in the way that the Gray Government and the Tasmanian Parliament are now doing, cannot impose a choice upon a political party against that party's will because in the Constitution it is quite clear that under those circumstances there is a right to expel someone so nominated who is not the officially endorsed candidate and, as such, that person cannot take his seat and the situation reverts to square one. Under those circumstances we have all the makings, however, of a deadlock, and that is what will prevail in the absence of legal challenge and in the absence of a change of heart in Tasmania at the moment.

What is perhaps clearest of all in this, however, is that the situation we have at the moment is one that should never have arisen. Not only is the underlying intention of the constitutional amendment perfectly clear, as it was passed in 1977 and given the circumstances in which it was passed, but on some 13 occasions since then casual vacancies have occurred and there has never been any question but that the officially endorsed nominee of the party in question would take the seat. There have also been numerous occasions within those 13 when a particular government has chosen without any demur at all the nominee of a party in opposition. I refer in particular to the Victorian Liberals accepting Senator Neal; the Dunstan Labor Government in South Australia appointing Senator Haines; the Wran Labor Government appointing Senator Puplick; the Victorian Cain Labor Government appointing Senator Alston; and that same Labor Government appointing Senator Powell. There may well be others that could be added to that list. So the convention is established beyond possible dispute, and that convention was acknowledged in this chamber in the resolution that was passed some weeks ago making absolutely clear our commitment across party lines to the convention that a nominee of the party should be so appointed.

There is no doubt but that that position is one that is shared across party lines. Senator Chaney came somewhat belatedly to his acknowledgment of it, but did so; Mr Howard was quite firm and express in his support for this convention and its application to Tasmania right from the outset--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody takes any notice of him.

—Not that anyone appears to have taken any notice of him, as Senator Walsh has said. Even Mr Sinclair has come into the act, describing in the last day or so the act of the Tasmanian Premier and Government as one of stupidity. I believe the situation is one that is more appropriately resolved-at least in the first instance, not least because of the time that would be involved in any full scale legal challenge-in the political arena. One hopes, and we certainly hope, that this is an occasion-a rare occasion-on which Mr Howard will prove to be able to exercise his authority in such a way that those members of his Party in other parts of this country actually take some notice of him.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Gray obviously is not prepared to do so at the moment, but it is an occasion for the exercise of authority if Mr Howard is to have any claim to credibility as a leader of any stature whatsoever in this country. It is also an occasion when the Premier of Tasmania should start to exercise some long overdue common sense and some long overdue and perhaps impossible to attain sense of constitutional decency. The situation that has arisen is manifestly intolerable; it cannot be allowed to continue, and I hope that this Senate tomorrow, when Senator Tate's motion comes on, will express a view unanimously as to the outrageousness of the situation that now exists in Tasmania.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MILITARY LINKS BETWEEN AUSTRALIA AND VANUATU

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government of Vanuatu given any reasons for its reported intention to cut military links with Australia? Does the Government believe that there is any justification for this action, given that it appears to be based on legitimate expressions of concern by Australia about the increased involvement of the Libyan Government in that country? Will the small number of military personnel involved be withdrawn, and will Australia proceed with its plans to present Vanuatu with a patrol boat next month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, of course, aware of reports based on a conversation at the end of last week by a senior Vanuatu official with a senior Australian official about possible changes by Vanuatu to its policy of defence co-operation with Australia. We are still uncertain about the precise extent, the implications and the timing of this proposed policy change, but we do have particular concerns about its possible implications for Royal Australian Navy visits and Royal Australian Air Force landings in Vanuatu, which are, of course, aimed at not only reinforcing bilateral ties but also enhancing regional security and stability. We are aiming to clarify the proposed change with the Vanuatu Government and, as has been mentioned a couple of times, a senior official from the Department of Foreign Affairs will be visiting South Pacific countries, including Vanuatu, for discussions this week, and we certainly hope those discussions will help to remove any possible misunderstandings.

ANSWER.PARA: In that respect I think it is very important to draw attention to a radio interview that was given earlier today by Father Lini, welcoming the forthcoming visit of the Australian Foreign Affairs official, a Deputy Secretary of that Department, Mr Sadleir. Father Lini, in that interview, also described the relationship with Australia as a mature one. We certainly share that assessment and look forward to an early return to the close, co-operative and very constructive relationship which we have traditionally enjoyed with Vanuatu.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen an article in today's Canberra Times which reports that the Confederation of Australian Industry is calling for a $1,000 tertiary education administration charge for students? Will the Government follow the course of action suggested by the Confederation of Australian Industry? Will the Minister give the reasons for the Government's accepting or rejecting that course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice that the Confederation of Australian Industry thought it would be a good thing to cut education funding and to impose a $1,000 administration charge. The Government will not be accepting the recommendation of the CAI in that respect. It is somewhat disappointing, when industry leaders are constantly coming to the Government asking for improvements in the education system, for a higher level of education for all young Australians-not just for a percentage who may go on to universities-and for a higher level of research, particularly industry oriented research, that they should at the same time choose to nominate education as a suitable area for massive cuts or, as in this case, for fairly massive increases in the cost of higher education for the individual.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly not the case that all business leaders do that. I had occasion to say in the Senate recently that I welcomed the education policy put out by the Business Council of Australia which, although it has from time to time called for education cuts, I think has lately taken a more constructive and more realistic approach to the question of education funding. It is simply not the case that education could be dramatically slashed on the one hand, or priced well beyond the affordable limits of most families on the other, without industry as well as individuals being the losers. I hope that the Confederation of Australian Industry will become a more active partner in the industry-education links which the Government has set up very successfully, and come to a more realistic understanding that, if they are to have improved skills in the work force, an improved level of managerial talent, improved entrepreneurship, better research and better opportunities for development arising out of research, Budget slashing is no way to achieve that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the Minister recall receiving a copy of an open letter to the Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand arguing in favour of seeking a ruling from the International Court of Justice concerning the legality or otherwise of nuclear weaponry? Does the Minister agree that the opinions of the eminent jurists contained in this document put a forceful case in favour of the Australian Government's supporting this step? As the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister have also been in possession of this document for some weeks now, is the Minister in a position to indicate whether the Government intends to respond positively to this initiative? If it is not yet ready to respond, when will it be ready to do so?

—I presume the honourable senator asked me that question in my capacity as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs or as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, rather than as the Minister for Resources and Energy, but never mind.
—Pick a portfolio, Senator. It does not matter. Just answer the question.

—I do recall getting the letter in question, just as I hope Senator Haines will recall my sending a very charming acknowledgment of it on 8 April, which was only four weeks ago. The situation is that the issues involved in getting the ICJ to make the kind of declaratory judgment involved are very complex and weighty. Whether it is practical, practicable or effective to pursue the issue through the ICJ, given the essential stumbling block-which has been, hitherto, the attitudes of the super-powers themselves-is certainly an open question. We welcome constructive efforts at this time to contribute to the debate and to think of new ways in which it can be advanced. Certainly, we will leave no stone unturned in the future, as we have in the past, in the pursuit of our disarmament objectives. All I can say is that the letter is receiving active consideration, I think within the Department of Foreign Affairs. I will be happy to let Senator Haines and the rest of the Senate know as soon as we have reached some considered conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Resources and Energy agree with the final statement of a background paper presented by the Department of Trade to a Caucus committee, namely, that a national coal marketing authority would inhibit structural changes within the industry, thus militating against the continuation of an efficient and internationally competitive industry and that, in the long term, such an authority must be expected to lead to diminishing international market shares? Will the Minister assure the Senate that his Government will not follow the recommendations of the Caucus coal committee to Cabinet reported in the Australian Financial Review on 22 April to appease the coal mining unions by establishing such an authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be premature to anticipate what the final report of the Caucus committee would be, which is not, to my knowledge, yet complete. It would be equally premature to indicate a reaction of the Government to that. What I can say is what I have said on numerous occasions to both industry and coal trade union gatherings and meetings, and that is that I do not believe-I do not think the Government believes-that the concept of a national coal marketing authority is one that is sustainable. A combination of constitutional problems are associated with the inability of the Commonwealth to legislate for such an authority in the absence of State co-operation which, one assumes, would not be forthcoming from the honourable senator's State.

ANSWER.PARA: There are practical problems, given that the commodity is not a single one but involves 40 or 50 different grades of coal, or more than that depending on how one chooses to describe the various combinations of characteristics, and is sold to some 40 or 50 different countries. It is not a commodity that is, in essence, a single commodity such as wheat which lends itself to compulsory acquisition marketing-type arrangements. There are all sorts of other difficulties internationally associated with an attempt by the Government to do all the marketing of this commodity.

A number of other points could be made, but I think it is premature, as I have said, to put any final or conclusive statement on the record at this stage. However, that is not to say that there might not be a case to be made for bringing together, under the head of a single banner, a number of the different functions that are presently performed by the Commonwealth in various departments and various statutory authorities that bear upon the coal industry. That is a live issue as far as the Government is concerned. But, I repeat, it is not one on which we have any concluded view.

The whole position of the Government on export controls so far as the coal industry is concerned has been spelt out in recent times. The realities of the international market-place are such at the moment that it is not susceptible to detailed regulation of the kind that might be regarded by some people as theoretically ideal. The reality is that it is a very fluid and very open trading environment. The crucial thing, as with all consideration of regulatory activity, is that the Government's actions should be directed towards engaging in regulatory activity of any form only when the benefits manifestly outweigh the costs. It is not true of the marketing side of the exercise, but as for other statutory functions and other relevant functions the question is still very much an open one, so far as we are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication `State Estimates of Private New Capital Expenditure: December Quarter 1986 Survey' which was released on Friday, 8 May? Can the Minister elaborate on the information those statistics provide on the State by State pattern of growth in business investment spending during the current financial year? Are the figures for Queensland such that the Commonwealth Government will be seeking to emulate the policies of the Petersen regime for encouraging private enterprise business investment spending?

—I have seen the ABS bulletin. The survey reported in it was carried out in January and February of this year. Data were gathered on how much investment spending private businesses had carried out in the first half of 1986-87 and how much they expected to carry out in the second half of 1986-87-that is, the current half year. Using information from previous surveys on the average extent to which second half year expectations investments were, in fact, realised, the Bureau has produced a table of statistics which is printed at page 1 of the release. It shows on a State by State basis growth in business investment spending from 1985-86 to 1986-87 to be 15 per cent Australia-wide. That is in nominal terms, so in real terms it is something like half of that. On a State by State basis, again in nominal terms, Victoria showed a 25 per cent increase in business capital investment, Western Australia 23 per cent, New South Wales 18 per cent, South Australia 6 per cent, which regrettably is in real terms a small decline, Tasmania 4 per cent, and Queensland 2 per cent. So obviously in the case of Queensland that is a very significant real decline in private capital investment. Queensland is going backwards at a not insubstantial pace. The Petersen regime's policies for encouraging private enterprise business investment consist of three things: A lot of hot air, usually pretty incoherent; special deals for cronies and mates, at least those who are not yet in jail; and hidden taxes and little-publicised regulations on business activity. The Hawke Government will certainly not be following those policies.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR ASIA AND THE PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education able to give any details on the establishment and function of the new Research Institute for Asia and the Pacific? Can the Minister say what States have access to the kinds of services which the Institute is planning to provide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Research Institute for Asia and the Pacific was given some publicity last week. I understand that the Institute was launched yesterday by the Chancellor of the University of Sydney, Sir Hermann Black. Funding and staff for the Institute will be provided by the University of Sydney out of the $146m provided by the Commonwealth in recurrent grants to the university for 1987. The initiative came from the Centre for Asian Studies at the university. The new Institute will provide businesses, governments and academics with a vastly increased range of informational resources than is currently available. It will facilitate the exchange of information and personnel, as well as collaborative research. It will bring together business, government and academic interests in an ongoing program of short courses, public lectures and specialist symposia to facilitate business within the region. It will involve the general public and those with special Asian interests in a program of seminars, talks and lectures. I commend the Centre for Asian Studies and the University of Sydney for this initiative, which will place us in a much better position to meet the challenges and opportunities facing Australia as an integral part of the rapidly developing Asian and Pacific region.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, Senator Elstob asked what access States or State bodies would have to the Institute. I presume that, as is the case with universities generally, the seminars, workshops, symposia and so on that it intends holding will be open to State participation or representatives of State governments as well. I hope that the Institute will facilitate the efforts of South Australia as well as other States of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence noted the reports in today's Press and the reports over the weekend concerning recent initiatives by the West German Government in seeking to clarify and correct a number of apparently false allegations concerning the West German consortium's tender submission to the Government for the contract to construct Australia's six new submarines? —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to recent questions answered by the Minister in relation to the National Farmers Federation Press release headed `Farmers Identify $11 billion Budget Cuts' and to Press reports in last Thursday's Age newspaper reporting accusations by the President of the NFF, Mr Ian McLachlan, that the Government is orchestrating a campaign of misinformation against the National Farmers Federation's policies. Has the Minister received any correspondence from Mr McLachlan taking issue with any aspect of his comments in relation to the NFF's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not received any correspondence from Mr McLachlan, nor do I expect to receive any. The plain fact is that Mr McLachlan is furiously peddling lies and nonsense around the country; therefore, when he has them corrected I do not expect him to indulge in correspondence with the people who have corrected him. Mr McLachlan's reference to misinformation, as reported in the Weekend Australian the weekend before last, is Orwellian-it is straight out of George Orwell-because, as I said before, he has been peddling lies and misinformation around the country for the last few months as, indeed, has the National Farmers Federation in general.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr McLachlan continues to assert, and I notice that the National Party is now echoing him, that if all excise on refined petroleum product were abolished, the consumer price index would fall by nearly 6 per cent. In fact, the CPI would fall directly by a bit over 2 per cent and over a long period of time, probably many years, it might fall by as much as 4 1/2 per cent. The offset to the revenue loss of $5.6 billion proposed by the National Farmers Federation is to end government funding of health services-an almost total withdrawal by the Government from the funding of health services. The effect of that would be to push the CPI up straightaway by 6 per cent. In other words, there would be an immediate addition of 6 per cent to the consumer price index and, according to the National Farmers Federation's line of reasoning, an immediate increase of 6 per cent in nominal interest rates.

I notice that the Liberal Party is starting to echo that line insofar as it is giving any indication at all of the policies it intends to follow. So the net effect of this brilliant NFF strategy would be to add 4 per cent to the consumer price index in the short term and, in the long term, at least 1 1/2 per cent-and possibly a good deal more-if the higher initial CPI got locked into wages. It is typical of the NFF to advocate this sort of policy. Prior to this latest and most brilliant economic strategy the NFF has been among the most vociferous opponents of capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and abolishing the free lunch-measures which have almost no impact on the people the NFF purports to represent, but which would of course have a huge impact on Commonwealth revenue. There would be a loss of around $700m if the fringe benefits tax alone were abolished and another $300m or $400m lost if free lunches were brought back in.

On present indications, as the Treasurer said yesterday, or perhaps it was Saturday, something over $100m would be gained in the first year of the capital gains tax. In that figure, the Treasurer probably was including increased receipts under section 25 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act and under section 26aaa, with those increased receipts being attributable to the introduction of a capital gains tax. Just to polish off the betrayal of the people the NFF purports to represent on tax matters, it is now furiously searching for some excuse to support flat tax at a rate of 25 per cent a la Petersen. The NFF says it is conducting research on the matter. There is no need to conduct research on the matter. All that is needed is a copy of the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation and about five minutes to examine it to realise that the effect of that tax change on the people the National Farmers Federation and McLachlan purport to represent would be that 80 per cent of them would pay more tax than they do now.

—Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate see the article by the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald on 9 May which examined the corporate tax system in Australia and compared it with those in other developed countries? If so, does the Minister accept the conclusions of the article that claims by some business groups about high corporate tax rates in Australia are thoroughly wrong? Is it possible also that some of the taxation levied on the corporate sector in Australia is not ultimately borne by that sector but is shifted to consumers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been the subject of earlier questions in the Senate. I recall that Senator Lewis asked me a question about this and I gave him a written answer. I have seen the article by Ross Gittins, the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald. In fact, it is one of the few sensible and rational articles to address the level of corporate taxation in Australia and our comparative position with other developed countries.
—You agree with it, do you mean?

—Senator Chaney asked by way of interjection whether I agree with it. I would not go that far. However, I would say that I have some sympathy with it because it is a thoughtful piece of work. It is one which has a degree of intellectual rigur about it-something which is not present in the Opposition or in any of its questions. I say that because the article looks at the entire range of corporate tax and taxation concessions and draws the conclusion:

ANSWER.PARA: When you take account of all these factors, Australia's effective level of company tax is quite comparable with those in other OECD countries-which is hardly surprising, when you think about it, since the public sectors they have to finance are roughly the same size as ours, if not bigger.

Unlike these countries, Australia has decided to retain its special taxation concessions for the corporate sector such as the `5/3' accelerated depreciation allowance and the 150 per cent deduction for research and development. Compared with other countries, Australia's tax regime is now highly favourable for investment in industries that are capital intensive and spend large amounts on research and development. The importance of that is to redress some very clear structural imbalances which developed in Australia over the period of the 1970s, particularly in relation to such matters as research and development. Although Australia's company tax rate was increased by 3 per cent to help pay for imputation, which will be introduced from 1 July 1987, the benefits from that, the Government believes, are very considerable. Australia is the first country to offer full imputation, which will relieve the double taxation on dividend income. If I can give some figures, the fact is that the abolition of double taxation of dividends leads to a reduction in the highest level of tax payable by a company from 78 per cent to 49 per cent. This will make Australia more attractive to foreign investors by freeing franked dividends from the 15 per cent dividend withholding tax applying to income repatriated overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not paid by companies. You are misleading the Senate.
—If only the honourable senator could hear himself; he sounds like an oversexed cicada. I cannot answer this question seriously with all that squawking going on.

ANSWER.PARA: Other corporate taxes being abolished are the Division 7 tax on retained earnings and the branch profits tax. The abolition of the Division 7 tax will have particular benefits for small business. The reduction of the company tax to levels of 40 per cent or below would require the introduction of a consumption tax, which would be irresponsible at a time when inflation is a concern to the Government. The Government has indicated its position about that on a number of occasions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY RECRUITMENT IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney-General been drawn to the February 1987 edition of Overseas Trading, a journal now published by the Bell Publishing Group of St George's Terrace, Perth, Western Australia, and particularly page 70 of that journal where an advertisement has been placed seeking recruits for the Central Intelligence Agency? Does Australian law prevent foreign security organisations from advertising for recruits in Australia and actively operating in Australia? If so, what action will the Attorney-General take to stop the CIA recruiting in Australia? If not, will the Government consider amending the law to prevent foreign organisations from actively pursuing their security interests in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisement in question, complete with its tag line that the CIA is an equal opportunity employer. As to the substance of the question, there is no prohibition in Australian law which prevents foreign security organisations from advertising for recruits in Australia. The Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 prohibits the recruiting of mercenaries and recruiting persons to serve with an armed force of a foreign country. No law specifically prevents foreign security organisations from actively operating in Australia. However, any actions undertaken by members of such organisations are subject to ordinary Australian law, including those laws relating, among other things, to the protection of information. Accordingly, the question as to whether the Attorney-General will take any action to stop the CIA thus recruiting does not arise.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final question-will the Government consider amending the law to prevent foreign organisations from actively pursuing their security interests?-the Attorney-General's response is this: Actions contrary to the public interest are prohibited by the general law applying to all persons in Australia. If the activities of foreign security organisations constitute acts of foreign interference, as defined in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act, it is within ASIO's functions to investigate and keep the Government informed.
