To the extent that there is any substantive point of significance that has been raised in the increasingly public debate on this issue, of course, these are matters that will be addressed by the Government in making its decision, and of course they are matters on which I and the Minister himself can properly expect to be questioned after the event.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. How does the Government assess recent reports of a serious escalation of violence in the communal situation in Sri Lanka? What steps has the Government taken to urge upon all parties the need for a peaceful solution to the present conflict?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very deeply disturbed by the recent escalation in communal violence-I might say criminal as well in some instances-in Sri Lanka. The bombing of a bus stop in central Colombo which claimed the lives of over 100 innocent people and critically injured many more is abhorred by all civilised people. Such an act can never be justified by the political end it is calculated to achieve. We are concerned, too, by reports that a large number of civilians have been killed in the Government's offensive against militant strongholds in the Jaffna Peninsula. The Australian Government strongly urges both the Sri Lankan Government and representatives of the Tamil militants to exercise restraint in their approach to resolving the communal situation in order to put an end to the cycle of violence.

ANSWER.PARA: We reiterate our support for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Sri Lanka. Australia firmly supports efforts involving India to renew negotiation between the Sri Lankan Government and Tamil representatives. Discussions between President Jayewardene and Prime Minister Gandhi at Bangalore in November 1986 seem to have generated a package of proposals which could form the basis of serious negotiation. We have made clear to the Sri Lankan Government, at the highest levels and on many occasions, the need to find an early political solution to the communal conflict. We will continue to take every opportunity-bilaterally and in the United Nations-to underline our abhorrence of the use of violence for political ends, and our concern that human rights be respected. I say finally that the Department of Foreign Affairs is closely monitoring the security situation in Colombo and has advised intending travellers to consider deferring travel to Sri Lanka for the time being unless absolutely necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a proposition contained in the volume on spending and taxation reform options for Australia released last week by the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University. In that document it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . in 1984-85 some $6 billion in interest and dividends were declared to the Australian Taxation Officer, far less than estimates by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of interest and dividends received by households of some $14.8 billion. Can the Minister shed any light on the apparent discrepancy implied in the passage between the amount of interest and dividends received by householders-some $14.8 billion-and the amount of interest and dividends declared to the Australian Taxation Office, being $6 billion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little surprised to hear the honourable senator refer to a hoary, old and misleading figure, which is usually trotted out by the Party that believes that fairies inhabit the bottom of the garden. It fails to take into account a number of quite legitimate factors. The figure in the book appears to have been derived by subtracting interest declared to the Commissioner of Taxation from interest payments recorded in the national accounts, with the conclusion that income tax is being evaded on the difference between the two. That simplistic conclusion fails to take account, firstly, of the fact that a great deal of interest is received by tax exempt individuals-that is, by people who do not have a taxable income-and that interest is also received, in large amounts, by tax exempt institutions such as charitable funds. It is also possible, it would seem, that the errors in that book are further compounded by having closed off the measurement of interest declared on tax returns before all the tax returns for the relevant year had been received. ANSWER.PARA: The chapter of the book is, I understand, acknowledged to be the work of three professors of economics-Walsh, Freebairn and Porter. If a third year student were to submit in an examination an answer so lacking in intellectual rigour and knowledge as the conclusions put forward by those three professors in that chapter, that student would be failed-or, if he were not failed, he certainly ought to be failed. If this chapter displays the standard of the teachers of economics in some universities, one must despair about the achievement of their students.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Powell proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to resist the push of the New Right by forcing those Australians who are in greatest need to bear the brunt of its stringent economic measures while allowing the continuing accumulation of wealth by a small number of top income earners.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Senate today this matter of public importance-the failure of the Hawke Government to resist the push of the New Right by forcing those Australians who are in greatest need to bear the brunt of its stringent economic policies while allowing the continuing accumulation of wealth by a small number of top income earners-because the evidence is clear. A new study by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research has estimated a significant overall rise in poverty in Australia between 1981-82 and 1985-86. Using the Henderson poverty line as its base, the Institute found that poverty increased, after taking account of housing costs, from 11.5 to 12.4 per cent of all income units in that period. This means that an extra 100,000 families and single income earners have slipped below the poverty line since 1981-82. More than 650,000 households are now living in poverty, compared with just over 550,000 in 1981-82. The poverty line has crept up on the average worker, jumping 46 per cent, while average weekly full time male earnings have increased by only 37 per cent. Social security benefits increased by between 40 and 46 per cent over the same period. The poverty line itself ranged from a low of $114.80 a week after tax for a single unemployed person to a high of $379 for a couple with five children where the head of the family works. The poverty line, we should remember, marks reasonable costs of living, including housing, gas, electricity and food.

SPEECH.PARA: Hardest hit by the poverty trap in this study were single parent families, but an increasing proportion of families with several children are sliding below the poverty line. We should also remember that the total number of children living in poverty has rocketed to around the 800,000 mark. The big losers over this period were families with four or more dependent children, with the number below the poverty line jumping from 27.1 to 31 per cent after housing costs were taken into consideration. The publication of this report received widespread media coverage, for which I believe the media deserve commendation since it is certainly important that the Australian public be aware of the facts in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: What about at the other end of the scale? We already know that one-tenth of Australians own 60 per cent of the wealth in Australia. The social issues magazine-Australian Society-in its May 1987 edition, revealed new figures which have come from work by John Piggot of the University of Sydney and which will be published in the June 1987 edition of the Economic Record. The figures show that there are now over 30,000 millionaires in Australia. The new study points out that exclusion from earlier studies of fixed assets and inventories of unincorporated businesses, including rural land, has led in the past to an underestimation of the total wealth of Australians.

Piggot's figures show that total wealth is now at close to $1,000 billion, almost 50 per cent higher than in previous estimates. It is most disturbing to note that his figures also show that at June 1985, 13.68 per cent of Australia was overseas owned. Even leaving aside the new figures and using data from Ross Williams of the Australian National University, Phil Raskell presents a clear picture in the Australian Society article of the change in wealth holdings over the past year. In summary, the top one per cent-some 90,000 Australians-have increased their wealth from $1.5m to $1.83m. Recently the Business Review Weekly in its annual wealth report showed that the very rich were doing extremely well and suggested that there are an extra 16 centi-millionaires and 56 people with net estimated wealth of over $50m in Australia. Further analysis by Phil Raskell leads to the conclusion that over the last year the number of millionaires has increased by over 3,000 to 28,000-a figure which would be even higher, almost 32,000, if the new Piggot data were used.

Clearly, there are sharp extremes of rich and poor, as the Australian Society magazine continues to point out, and the gap increases. This must be a matter of great concern. Just this weekend a caution was issued by Bishop Peter Hollingworth of the Brotherhood of St Laurence. The Times on Sunday of 10 May stated:

``There are two million people now living below the poverty line, 850,000 of them children,'' he said. ``It is very dangerous. If the gap continues to widen between the exceptionally rich and the very poor, you create a lot of stresses.

``I am not saying that we're going to have revolution, like in the Philippines, but you will find growing numbers of young people going around slashing, ripping up train seats, a life where it's unsafe to go on public transport. You could describe that as the blind lashing out.''
The Bishop said:
If the Treasury savages welfare in its mini-budget, not only would the Labor Party lose its credibility, but the poor could not take it any more.

I am inclined to ask: What credibility? Clearly from the evidence before us, the Hawke Government's economic policies are hitting hardest at those who are least able to cope. What are these policies and what is the motivation? After the rhetoric of the Fraser years about deregulation it was only when we found ourselves with the Hawke Labor Government and its ultra-conservative Treasurer, Mr Keating, that we actually saw financial deregulation, the delivery of Australia's economy into the hands of the international money profiteers, financiers and major Australian corporate entities.

Now the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, looks almost a benevolent figure before the current crop of New Right advocates from Sir Joh, to John Howard, Andrew Hay, John Elliott, Ian McLachlan, Peter Boyle et al with their strident calls for cuts in the coming mini-Budget of anything from some $4 billion to $11 billion. As it was with those economic policies espoused by the Fraser Government, so it is with what the New Right push advocates today. What it advocates today, the Hawke Government seems to implement tomorrow. I suppose the Opposition conservatives are looking on with some admiration, if not envy, as they rip themselves apart trying to outdo the Hawke conservatives and, of course, they cheerfully vote with them as often as not. In the last Budget session they voted with the Hawke Government in over 40 per cent of divisions.

We remember the Budget session in 1986 in which both the Hawke Government and the Opposition parties combined to impose taxation on juice and milk products-basic necessities of life. They also combined to delay welfare legislation in the form of indexation of payments and the implementation of property traps legislation which was designed to assist those people least able to assist themselves. They introduced legislation to impose fees for tertiary education. They cut various multicultural and foreign aid programs, and on goes the list. It is not surprising, therefore, that in the last two or three weeks in particular but certainly in the whole time since the last Budget session there has been increasing trepidation among people in the community who represent the poor, the weak and the disenfranchised, in particular with the focus on the mini-Budget coming up this Wednesday. Those people, who have been virtually haunting the corridors of this place in recent weeks, and the Australian Democrats recognise the economic problems of this nation, and no one is proposing irresponsible economic measures. We are all calling for the Government to look towards alternative means to raise revenue as opposed to looking merely at spending cuts as a means of achieving some sort of reduction in the deficit.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that honourable senators from both my left and my right do not really want this particular point to be made and therefore have chosen to call out to each other across the chamber. There are numerous voices in the community which support the sorts of calls that the Australian Democrats have been making for the Government to take action on some of the greatest tax rorts which exist in the system, that system which the Government seems determined to support, that system which involves people speculating against out economic position, those people who have been and continue to be in large measure responsible for the enormous overseas indebtedness we have and who continue to profit from that process particularly through the exercise of negative gearing on company takeovers and in particular where the funding for those takeovers comes from international borrowing. The transfer pricing process which is available to the multinational corporations is another area which desperately needs to be looked at and which, along with abolition of this type of negative gearing, could provide the Government with increased revenue and more stability in our international trade situation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great deal of speculation against our currency, which currency has been floated and deregulated by courtesy of the Hawke Labor Government. The Government refuses to act in these matters. It seems quite determined not to displease the international money markets. There is obvious injustice in this when we compare it with the tax paid by people on pensions and benefits, who when they earn just a dollar or two above their allowable $30-this will not go up to $40 until July because of the delay in the poverty traps legislation supported by both the Government and the Opposition in the last Budget session-lose 50c of their pension or benefit and very quickly fall into the tax bracket and have to pay even more. There is also misrepresentation in this whole process of the Government attempting to justify the sort of thrust that it is succumbing to, under pressure from the Right. Representatives of the Combined Pensioners Association and the Australian Pensioners Federation have told me that this is not the case; that they see the injustices and that they want them redressed. We have seen the students putting forward their view on the Government's policy of introducing fees and, of course, the Opposition's policy of introducing full fees for any additional access to further education. The students believe, as do the Australian Democrats, that education is a right and not a privilege. We have seen that the Government--

SPEECH.PARA: The familiar charge that we hear from the Australian Democrats is that this Government has sold out the needy and is pandering to the greedy. On the first charge, over and above the growth in the numbers of people who are entitled to social security payments, we have already directed, through changes in rates and policy changes, more than $1 1/2 billion extra in real terms in closely targeted assistance to social welfare. Would the ratbag Right be demanding that issues be settled in the streets or at public rallies, a la Nuremburg, in the way that it is demanding that issues be settled right now? I am talking about the intellectual non-rigour of the bourgeois Left as against the intellectual non-rigour of the ratbag Right; otherwise they have a great deal in common. Because of policy changes we have directed $1 1/2 billion of closely targeted assistance into the welfare sector. Senator Powell should not forget Medicare, and she should not forget the 770,000 people now holding jobs who did not have jobs when this Government was elected. As present, 770,000 more people have jobs than had jobs when the Howard-induced recession hit its nadir in April 1983. The greatest single cause of poverty in Australia in recent years has been unemployment, and we have made major progress in redressing that problem.

Having looked at the Government's record, I want now to look at the record of the fairies at the bottom of the garden party which is, of course, always on the side of the angels, always calling for justice, income redistribution and so on. But what is the record of the Democrats? They, in collusion with Senator Harradine and the official Opposition, have rejected Government legislation which would have collected more than $600m from tax evaders, from the notorious bottom of the harbour operators. That is what they have actually done while sanctimoniously mouthing their concern for the poor. When it actually came to voting they overturned government legislation that would have required the notorious bottom of the harbour tax evaders to pay another $600m of the tax that they had evaded, stolen from honest taxpayers in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Retrospectively.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are very big on tax reform in the abstract. If they believe that tax is being avoided, or that income is being received on which tax is not being paid, such as in the case of a superannuation fund, they advocate the abolition of the tax exemption of that income. If they stood up and said yes, this was what they advocated, they might get some respect. But what do they do? They parade their ignorance yet again by talking about company tax and alleging that the nation's external debt is a function of borrowing for company takeovers. I have taken Senator Powell through this before but I will take her through it again. I will try to speak slowly and in monosyllables and, although that is not entirely possible, I hope she will actually get to understand it.

One of the nice things about the Democrats is that they are so predictable. When the Whip brought a copy of the letter proposing this matter of public importance to my office this morning, I immediately said: `The Democrats will talk about the alleged evasion of company tax by drawing that ratio of company tax paid as a proportion of company profits and concluding that any figure less than 46 per cent is, ipso facto, proof that taxation is being evaded by companies'.

That fails to take into account two very important facts and a number of less important ones. I will deal with the important two. Firstly, that aggregate figure of company profits entails a lot of double counting; that is, profits transferred to one company from subsidiaries. The same profit possibly is counted many times. The tax, of course, is paid only once. This is known as the section 46 rebate. I suggest that Senator Powell look at it some time.

The Democrats, like bourgeois left populists in general, grab hold of this figure-they do not understand it; they are either not capable of understanding or are too lazy to understand it-and use it as, according to them, definitive proof that company tax is being evaded. Secondly, very generous accelerated depreciation provisions were enacted by this Government in its first year in office. If the Democrats want to criticise that as a policy, they are at liberty to do so. They are not entitled to misrepresent the truth by ignoring the effect that those accelerated depreciation allowances have on company tax liability. The Treasury put out a publication in February 1987. I presume that a copy is available to the Democrats; if not, I am happy to make my copy available. I presume that they are either not smart enough to understand it or too lazy to read it. I want to quote one paragraph from it. On page 15 the document states:
Figure 8 shows no downward trend over the period of analysis in the effective tax rate payable by the corporate sector when measured against National Accounts company income.
The period measured by figure 8 is from 1967-68 to 1985-86. The document goes on:

The average effective tax rate over the last three years of approximately 42 per cent (see Table 4 at Attachment C) is lower than the average of around 45 per cent for the period as a whole. This difference, however, is largely attributable to the peaks in effective tax rates in the early to middle 1970's and the late 1970's and early 1980's, rather than to any downward trend. These peaks are associated with peaks in the rate of inflation, which affects the trading stock valuation adjustment relative to deriving National Accounts company income.

The document is not very big. There are just over 40 pages altogether. I commend the study of it to the Democrats if they have any interest in understanding these taxation and other economic issues, as distinct from having a very keen interest in bourgeois left populist grandstanding and political opportunism.

SPEECH.PARA: The other manifestation of gross ignorance paraded yet again by Senator Powell was the allegation that our foreign indebtedness is caused by foreign borrowings or company takeovers. It might be possible to mount a good case against some of the corporate takeovers and raiding that have been going on and against the fact that more attention is paid to shuffling paper than to producing anything or efficiently managing a business. Some very sound criticism could be made on those grounds. But this is not the cause of our accumulating foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of the cause.

—It could make a very marginal contribution, depending on what the shareholders who were bought out did with the money. The cause of our accumulating foreign debt is the current account deficit-the difference between what we pay for goods and services and what we receive for goods and services; what we receive in interest payments and what we have to pay out in interest payments. This deficit has been running at a high level since 1980-81. It peaked in 1981-82 then fell away quite substantially to about 4 per cent of gross domestic product. It rose to a peak again in 1985-86-almost as high as it was when John Howard was Treasurer-and it has started to fall away again. Because we are running a current account deficit of that size we can either run down our reserves-and they would be exhausted within 12 months-or borrow money overseas. Australia has to persuade people overseas to lend it bridging finance to cover that current account deficit at a rate of interest which will not drive the economy into the ground. That has been a difficult thing to do. This Government has managed to achieve it.

SPEECH.PARA: Enter the bourgeois Left populists and the political opportunists, who solve the problem by reversing cause and effect; by saying that foreign borrowing, which is a response to the problem, is the cause of the problem. That is the shonky economic analysis we get from the fairies at the bottom of the garden party. It is not at all helpful in addressing the nation's real problems that that sort of nonsense should be so frequently and mindlessly repeated. Indeed, that brand of snake oil is as unhelpful as the other brands of snake oil peddled by the Petersen regime and the Liberal Party. These brands of snake oil say that average living standards can be enhanced via tax cuts. That is the National's brand of snake oil, and the Liberal Party's brand is just a milder version of that of the Petersen regime.

Because of the collapse of export prices Australia has two options. It can accumulate debt at a faster rate or average living standards must fall. This Government has been honest with the public about that. In the meantime they are fed rubbish by the Opposition, the Petersen regime and the Democrats with their snake oil device of reversing cause and effect. Foreign borrowings are a function of our current account deficit. They are an inescapable consequence of continuing to run a high current account deficit. The money has to be borrowed by somebody. Even if it was not borrowed in this way before, it is now borrowed by a mixture of governments-particularly the Queensland Government-banks and, in some cases, individuals. The Democrats pretend that if we just stop individuals borrowing for takeovers the problem will disappear. That is nonsense. I hope that they will stop staying this but I do not expect that they will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance gives the Senate an opportunity to examine the policies of the Hawke Labor Government and their effect on Australia and on Australian families. I submit that these policies are quite devastating. Under this regime we have witnessed a government which is the highest taxing and highest spending government in Australia's history. We now find ourselves in a situation where the chickens are coming home to roost and the Government is running into trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look briefly at the history of the Australian Labor Party and how it has deviated from its original principles. The Labor Party was founded on the basis of helping the ordinary working man and to give him an opportunity to improve his standard of living. Unfortunately, these original objectives have now been unceremoniously dumped by the Hawke Labor Government in favour of a pragmatic vote and, I submit, for quite grubby reasons. The irony of the situation is that this Labor Government has presided over a reduction in living standards and labour while paying lip service to the constituency which originally supported it-a constituency which consists of salary and wage earners with mortgages and with children to bring up, educate, feed and provide with medical care and security. I submit that the Government has deserted these very people. At the next election I think the Government will find just what is the popular view of this pragmatism.

Yesterday was Mother's Day, traditionally a day of family reunion, of thinking of mother and the family. What has this Government done for families? In 1986 the Australian Catholic Welfare Commission predicted that by 1988 Australian families as a whole would be $1,156m worse off than they were in 1983 as a direct result of the policies pursued by the Hawke Labor Government. The Commission said that this amount is made up as follows: The non-indexation of the family allowance, at a cost to families of $530m; non-indexation of dependants' rebates, at a cost of $394m; restrictions on eligibility for family allowance, at a cost of $79m; and abolition of concessional expenditure rebate, at a cost off $170m. But even if the second stage of Labor's promised tax cuts is implemented in July 1987, the two-parent single income families with two dependent children on average weekly earnings will still be $15 a week worse off than they were four years ago. That is the status of the ordinary people, the ordinary families.

What has happened in relation to the running of a car, which is considered a basic requirement? Since 1984, a year after the Hawke Government came to office, the price of the family car has increased enormously. For example, the standard Laser-considered a typical working man's car-has risen in price by 53 per cent and a Falcon by 33 per cent. The cost of running a car has increased by $108.29 a week for a Laser and $157.18 a week for a Falcon. The source for these figures is the National Roads and Motorists Association, so they are factual. These are some of the problems.

Let us look at the areas where the burden has fallen. In the 1960s and the 1970s the share of the gross domestic product that went to company profits was between 16 per cent and 17 per cent. During the black years of the Whitlam Government this fell back to about 13 per cent. Under the treasurership of the Hawke-Keating regime, despite the rhetoric about the J-curve and the possible improvement for Australia-`improvement that is just around the corner'-the rate has dropped back to 12 per cent. What does this really mean? It means that the profits after tax which are being retained by business and which can be used for reinvestment purposes to develop new industry and for innovations has fallen back 50 per cent. This has happened under the Hawke Labor Government. I submit that this Government is not even listening to its own advisers. For example, the Economic Planning Advisory Council has warned that Government reliance on high interest rates to restrict domestic demand is dangerous for the growth of a national economy.

What has happened in the interest rate area? Prime interest rates were about 13.5 per cent at the time of the 1983 election. Today they are at least 17 per cent or higher. Bankruptcies are at record levels. In the first nine months of this year they were up 40 per cent. Since the Hawke-Keating duo took over the running-or the ruining-of this country we have noticed in the retail sector of the motor vehicle industry that, for example, 5,500 jobs have been lost, and there is an indication of a further 10 per cent rise in unemployment in this industry in the current year. As a result of the fringe benefits tax, 81 per cent of firms will be forced to retrench staff. From 1 July company tax will rise from 46 to 49 per cent-one of the highest levels in the western world. What does this mean? Because taxes add to the cost of running a business, this means less retained earnings, less money spent on research and development and less employment. Therefore, the Government's policies in this area are not conducive to extra employment and raising the standard of living.

If the companies are taxed out of existence, or are forced to retrench staff, who suddenly find themselves out of a job and in a position where they are least able to protect themselves? In fact, manufacturing employment fell by 17,000 from February 1986 to February this year. The Confederation of Australian Industry said in late 1985:
It should not be forgotten that unemployment still remains some 200,000 above the level at which it was when the 1982 downturn commenced.

That is a sad reflection indeed. Thus, this continued bleating by the Government that the state of the economy is all due to the policies of the previous Government can be clearly seen to have absolutely no basis in fact whatsoever.

That fact is that under the Fraser Government the average unemployment rate from 1976 to 1982 was 5.8 per cent. Since March 1983, when the present Government was elected, the average has fluctuated at around 9 per cent. In addition, the average duration of people receiving the unemployment benefits has risen from 36 weeks to 64 weeks and the number of people who have been unemployed for more than one year has risen by 53 per cent-more than half. I believe that these figures speak for themselves. Again, the policies of the Hawke Labor Government have failed and are placing even greater burdens on the average income earner in this country. Conversely, I think this Labor Government has permitted the unscrupulous and dishonest to make obscenely high profits on the share markets through a spate of takeovers and through certain unprincipled operators selling to uniformed people, many of whom do not have a great familiarity with share markets. In fact, there is evidence that a lot of money has been lost by these sorts of people as a result of the selling of worthless foreign shares. While many unprincipled operators have taken the opportunities afforded as a result of deregulation and internationalism the Australian Labor Party has been quite slow to recognise the dangers inherent in these sorts of changes. It has been slow to act. I submit that the Government has done little, if anything, to contain the monopolies which are forcing out competition with a ruthlessness seldom seen in Australian corporate history.

What has this Australian Labor Party done to put more teeth and power into section 46 of the Trade Practices Act? Very little indeed. This provision, which deals with the misuse of market power, needs urgent attention. I believe that the Government is unconcerned about the effect that this share raiding is having on unemployment, the closure of firms and the placing of people on the scrap-heap. As a result, I believe that the Government stands condemned.

On the other side, what do we find in a comparison of wealth and income? We find that one-tenth of Australians now own 60 per cent of the wealth of this country. At the same time two million people remain below the poverty line. These two million people, I submit, have very bleak prospects for advancement under this Government. The tax laws have the effect of encouraging takeovers, where all too frequently the rich make paper profits and the poor, the worker is confined to the scrap-heap, to unemployment.

So the Government, instead, punishes those who have the least political clout-the pensioners of this country. In November last year the Government deferred the promised pension increase, and this was at a quite considerable cost to the pensioners of Australia. Again this year we find another deferment-from May to 25 June-a sad reflection on the priorities of this Government towards the pensioners of Australia, pensioners who have already given their share to the tax coffers and to the growth and development of Australia through a lifetime of service and work. They deserve some respect in their retirement. This Government has forgotten about the pensioners; it has forgotten about all those people who are least able to help themselves. Unfortunately, this Government is not very interested in helping those who can least help themselves. What is the situation in the health care area? The same people are being forced to bear the brunt of the Government's policies in this area. People who are wishing to undertake elective surgery now often have up to a two-year wait. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there are three separate parts to this matter of public importance brought forward by the Australian Democrats today: Firstly, that the Hawke Government has succumbed to the arguments of the New Right; secondly, that those in greatest need are the natural victims of the New Right; and thirdly, that the accumulation of wealth by certain citizens is bad for all citizens. This `New Right' term has been promoted frequently in the Press lately. It is almost tiresome the number of times that the New Right has been mentioned over the last few months, and I thought it might be appropriate to attempt to define, if it is possible, what the New Right happens to be.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the New Right identifies a set of ideas rather than interests, and this can be shown to be true by the number of governments of widely differing viewpoints that have adopted some or many ideas of the New Right. This is one reason why I believe a better name would be the `New Enlightenment'. The Chinese Communist Government, for example, has adopted many of the New Right's ideas; the Russians are trying to adapt their ideas to the economy of the Soviet Union without suffering the terrifying freeing up of the society as a natural reaction to freeing up the economy. Many of the East European countries have demonstrated that economic success comes not from central planning but from decentralising decision-making, reducing regulations and introducing the profit motive.

The New Zealand Labour Government and the Australian Labor Government have adopted some of the ideas of the New Enlightenment, or the New Right, if one likes to call it that, but have not had the courage to stop wasting billions of dollars of precious public funds. Throughout the world there has been a pronounced swing towards market economies rather than the excessive central planning of Marxian economics and the demand management philosophy of Keynesian economics. These changes in the policies of a wide variety of governments are due to the widespread recognition that increases in government spending designed to boost demand have not operated to increase output and reduce unemployment to specifiable goals. The changes are not due to any pressure from the New Right, but simply represent the adoption of some of its ideas.

I would argue that the New Right is not a political movement underpinned by a set of shared theoretical claims, but an intellectual movement independent of political allegiance. As Dr Chandran Kukathas, a young Australian academic at the Australian National University who wrote an interesting book about this matter recently, has argued, the New Right lacks a natural political constituency and, although the philosophy of the New Right is at odds with that of the Left-which in this Parliament means the darker shades of red in the Australian Labor Party and the tomato red of the Australian Democrats-the philosophy of the New Right is no less in conflict with that of the old Right. The New Right's attitude to the state differs from the attitudes of both the Left and the old Right insofar as its primary concern is the scope of state power, whether that power be exercised through the law or the democratic process.

The New Right argues that the power of the modern state has exceeded its proper bounds. The New Right shares with the conservatives a hostility to the idea of wealth redistribution according to principles of social justice. It also shares with libertarians a suspicion of the state reinforcing particular moral values and a wariness of any moves by the state to strengthen its own authority. Even among those people who can properly be termed as members of the New Right, there are various schools, differing in the degree to which they would limit the role of Government. Thus Ayn Rand and Mr Nozick reject all state activities other than those essential for the defence of society against internal and external aggressors. Hayek and Friedman, of course, argue for a reduction of state regulation of business and labour and of state provision of welfare services.

One study claimed that the cost of government regulation of Australian business was between $40 billion and $80 billion a year. This estimate seems to give a fair bit of room for error. Nonetheless, it demonstrates the order of cost involved in overregulation. This, of course, is what has been recognised by the Liberal Party of Australia. Mr Howard has indicated that the cost of government regulation must be dealt with, and policies have been formulated in order to address that horrendous cost to business when the Liberal Party takes over the Treasury bench after the next election. Senator Watson pointed out earlier in the debate the escalation in the costs of motor cars-the running costs as well as the initial capital cost of a vehicle. Housing costs have gone berserk under the present Government, undermining families. All of these things have been due to the poor economic management of the Hawke Government. The state of affairs in housing today is that repayments cost the average family over 25 per cent of its income.

The New Right holds a favourable view of capitalism, but that support does not extend beyond the defence of the market free of state intervention. The second major claim held by the New Right is that central organisation is not an essential prerequisite of order; or, to put the reverse of that idea, the absence of governmental control and regulation does not mean chaos. The New Right's third claim, and the most important, is that the condition of freedom must exist in which individuals are free to produce and market their wares. Such a system enables individuals to discover values which no one may have realised existed before.

New Right economists have been exceedingly successful in demonstrating that attempts to secure social improvements through the ordering mechanisms of the state invariably prove to be not merely futile but counter-productive. The harm is created not by human planning but by the superseding of countless individual plans by a single enforced plan drawn up by agents who do not have, and cannot possibly acquire, the knowledge necessary for such a task. It may come as a surprise to certain members of the Democrats that they do not have the knowledge to arrange the lives of other Australians.

In this International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, it is worthy of note that in 1906, in the wake of the earthquake that destroyed half of the housing in San Francisco, rendering about one quarter of a million people homeless, in the absence of rent control, replacement housing was completed at an incredible rate. In fact, in the first re-issue of the San Francisco Chronicle, there was no mention of a housing shortage and the paper advertised 65 dwellings for rent. In 1906 there were three houses for sale for every 10 listed for rent. In 1946, simply due to rent control or government interference, there were 730 houses for sale for every 10 listed for rent. That is a remarkable record. Due to the interference of the state in rents and lease conditions, the picture was distorted altogether. I think the same distortion exists in Australia today with respect to the ratios of houses for sale and for rent. I imagine that it would be very similar.

The Government has taken certain actions that have met with the approval of the majority of the nation, in particular, the deregulation of the financial system in accordance with the recommendations of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. However, the Government could not escape certain political interest groups associated with its left wing. As a result, billions of dollars have been wasted with no long term benefits being accrued to the economy of the nation or the efficacy of structurally unemployed. There are, of course, political interests associated with the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party, and every government has these interests to satisfy. The New Right would argue that the less government interferes with the market the more likely it is that a larger part of the population will benefit, and that, as the economy expands, so wealth will be created and more and more people will be educated and able to obtain employment and hold down their jobs.

Mr Howard has promised that when the Liberal Party gains power at the next election, his government will diminish government interference in the market-place. He has also committed a Howard government to deregulation and the removal of constraints. The Liberal Party is also committed to the removal or lessening of the maze of legislation, tax concessions, subsidies, statutory authorities, boards, regulations, professional practices, official and semi-official monopolies, tariff protection import quotas, regulated prices and wages and arbitrary bureaucratic decision making which has built up significantly since the War and particularly under this Government. Because the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has to placate the left wing of his Party and its supporters, he has seen fit to tie the New Right to the Liberal Party. I have tried to demonstrate that that is a lot of nonsense. The New Right is not affiliated or tied to any particular party. One or two people who speak up in the name of the New Right may be members of the Liberal Party, but the New Right is certainly not any part of our Party in a corporate sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your Federal Treasurer?

—Our Federal Treasurer is not, to my knowledge, a member of the New Right. I believe Andrew Hay is, and he has not been particularly helpful in recent times. That is one thing that annoys me. We hear people outside of Parliament telling us to release our taxation policy. One simply does not do that until the election date is known. We will not tell the Government the policies that we have developed because, inevitably, the Government would be attracted to them and would adopt many of them. So we would be very foolish to allow the Australian Labor Party into the secrets of--
—It has adopted just about every other major policy.

—Exactly; they are following the monetarist policy that they seemed to deplore when we were in government. Nevertheless, that is the way it goes. For people like Mr Hay and John Elliott to make those suggestions is, I think, unhelpful to us and I believe in due time they will recognise that the policies we have developed will satisfy the demands of the people of Australia. I am sure many of these ideas of the New Right will be adopted to varying degrees by the main political parties when they are better known. In the meantime, the Prime Minister has attempted to smear those who, working in an apolitical manner, have devised these ideas.

SPEECH.PARA: The media have done their best to malign these apolitical people-and I say that genuinely because I believe most of the spokesmen are apolitical; they are mainly academic people-because the media refuse to do the research required to understand these new or perhaps reborn ideas. It is fair to say that, if the Prime Minister had adopted a number of other ideas of the New Right, Australia would certainly not be groaning under its adverse international trade imbalance and its mounting national debt.

There are a number of problems in this nation, not the least of which is structural unemployment, but the Commonwealth employment program and other artificial job creation programs have done nothing to solve the problem. It is merely an example of putting off the inevitable day when long term solutions to this and other problems must be found. Last year, I think, expenditure on the CEP was something of the order of $1.4 billion, but not very many permanent jobs have been created as a result of that particular program.

There are a number of other matters that must be addressed. Certainly the policies of the Liberal Party are designed to come to grips with the very serious problems of unemployment, getting the economy back on track and increasing our export income. That is what the Liberal Party undertakes to do after the next election.

They are, without a doubt, the big spenders. We thought that we had seen the last of the big spenders when we got rid of Gough Whitlam-but we have not. Let the people understand that the total gross external debt in the last financial year that we were in government was $25 billion. At the end of last year our gross external debt was $101 billion. SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we have this wonderful Treasurer, the best Treasurer in the whole wide world! We all remember him. He lost us our AAA credit rating, which means that we now have to pay a higher rate of interest than we were paying under that rating. Putting private hospitals into three classes-

If that is not the grossest attack on the family, I do not know what is. It is absolutely ludicrous. This Government is certainly not moving more to the right. This is good old lefty stuff. Let the 14- and 15-year-old girls say to their parents: `I'm going out to live with Joe Blow'. If their mothers say `You cannot do that, dear; what would you live on?', they can very rightly say: `This Government will pay a de facto spouse the married rate of pension'. What a situation this Government has created!

SPEECH.PARA: What does this Federal Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit say about the way in which the Government is handling the economy? It says that Australia has not achieved growth for three main reasons: Firstly, national savings have been low due largely to taxation regimes discouraging savings. The Government's own review has said that it is taxing people too much and that they now cannot put their money into the bank for savings. Secondly, there is excessive intervention by the Government through economic and social regulations and, thirdly, the wage determination and other labour market processes are inflexible. So the Government's own review unit is very critical of the Government and says that it is going the wrong way about doing things. What has the Opposition been telling the Government for years, ever since it has been in office? We have been saying that if this Government does not lower inflation, if it does not lower interest rates and if it does not encourage the worker to produce higher quality articles in greater numbers by giving incentives and enabling him to retain more of his wage packet, the standard of living of all Australians will continue to deteriorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Powell for the Senate's consideration is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to resist the push of the New Right by forcing those Australians who are in greatest need to bear the brunt of its stringent economic measures while allowing the continuing accumulation of wealth by a small number of top income earners.

This Government was re-elected on a wave of optimism. It believed that the business climate in Australia was improving. Effectively, the Hawke Government was elected on the strength of its promises of cutting taxes and interest rates, together with lower unemployment, higher pensions and an end to poverty traps. It was expected that improved economic conditions would be maintained, that investment in industry would continue to improve and that Australia would see a return to the good times that existed in the 1960s. However, this has not happened.

The cause for this optimism was a marked improvement in Australia's balance of trade due mainly to high export prices for wool, wheat and other grains and a record harvest which followed many years of disastrous drought. As a spin-off of the improved trade figures, business investment also showed a marked improvement and the economic advantages flowed to the rest of the economy. Once again, Australia was riding high on the sheep's back. Once again, Australia was rich on a good harvest. Once again, Australian governments failed to perceive, and to deal with, the underlying problems of Australian industry. No firm plans for development were put into place. No attempt was made to budget according to a development plan. Instead, the Government pursued a policy of non-intervention in business, in finance and in the activities of the country.

Earlier today the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) described the Australian Democrats as the fairies at the bottom of the garden party. I believe that a good description of the Australian Labor Party under the Hawke Government, or hoax Labor Government, would be the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow party. We all know what happens at the end of the rainbow, and this is what the Government is trying to put up for us. No matter how hard this Government tries to please the gnomes of Zurich, the foreign speculators and the big businessmen of the United States of America, the pot of gold recedes, and will continue to recede, into the future as this Government squeezes ordinary Australians and tries to get the last drop of blood out of them, especially the poor, by its high taxation measures which are backing up its corporate welfare policies.

When the Government had the chance to jump on the windfall returns of a good season for primary industry it did nothing but promise and hope. When it had a chance to build on a lower Australian dollar it did nothing to plan ahead; it did nothing but promise and hope. Laissez-faire government, or, in other words, deregulation and non-interference with free market forces, has had its inevitable consequences on the economy as the smaller and more vulnerable ingredients in that economy-small businesses-have actually succumbed to the trade fluctuations to which Australia is being subjected.

World grain prices have slumped with the outbreak of protectionist trade wars, and Australia is reaping once again the penalty of dependence on primary industry alone for its export income. The inevitable flow-on to the rest of the economy is having its effect and the Government is now selling out Australia's future chances of recovery for the sake of kowtowing to those who will finance it at the next election and to those in the New Right who believe that we need a return to the dark ages of serfdom, cheap labour and control by big business in order to keep the wealthy operating in the state to which they have become accustomed.

In an attempt to maintain an apparent buoyancy in the economy and to keep money flowing into Australia the Government has adopted a high interest rates policy. As a result, the Australian dollar has gone up in value, and our exports are once again uncompetitive on world markets. This problem has yet to surface, since deliveries are still being made under contracts entered into when the value of the Australian dollar was low. High interest rates attract foreign investment into Australia and disguise temporarily, for foreign banks and other currency investors, the real difficulties which are facing our economy. These difficulties are due to very large inflows of capital for useless purposes-not to support a new wave of industry or a revitalisation of the Australian economy, but to overheat the stock market and to provide more money for the speculators in that market, which is supported by the taxpayer. This support by the taxpayer comes in the form of negative gearing arrangements which are available to the large companies, but access to the same negative gearing arrangements has been ripped from ordinary Australians saving for their retirement by owning a flat. High interest rates have diverted savings away from productive investments into speculation on financial and property deals and into short term, high interest loans.

This Government is killing the goose that laid the golden egg at the last election. It is killing the farmers by this overload in interest rates and government charges; it is killing the ordinary small businessman; and it will leave us totally at the mercy of the large industrial organisations. We must not forget that small business and the public sector are the major employers in Australia. Big business is employing fewer and fewer people. Small business is unable to take up the slack and, were it not for the Public Service increase, particularly in welfare areas, unemployment would be much higher. Indeed, it is a sad reflection on the Government that unemployment is the major growth industry in Australia.

Less than 5 per cent of foreign money ends up in any form of productive investment. Most of it is being brought in on a speculative basis and is used to buy up the farm on the cheap. This Government has encouraged the sell-off of Australian resources. It has pulled the teeth of the Foreign Investment Review Board and relaxed nearly all the constraints on foreign takeovers of Australian resources, land, industry and development. Likewise, it has shut up the independent voices close to government, such as the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations. Like the ugly stepmother, this Government cannot face its reflection in the mirror. It will not let the people it has appointed to advise it tell it where it is going wrong. It is deregulating wildly, simply to help its big friends in the media and elsewhere. The Government is proposing to hand over all media activities to a few people who, of course, will support this Labor Government later on in the election!

The people of Australia have to know that the Government is not doing anything to stop the power of these media barons and of multinational financiers and corporations. The Government is attacking the ordinary individual, as Senator Jones has said, through the Australia Card by constraining them and cutting out their methods of gaining income. But it is doing nothing about the large tax rorts in the system-transfer pricing, the flight of earnings to tax havens overseas and the huge takeover surge taking place in Australia all at the taxpayers' expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a parochial issue, is it?

—It is very parochial, but it is something which as an engineer I have taken a great deal of interest in. The Bowen Bridge was named thus by the then Prime Minister on 10 October 1980. The bridge was built using a very interesting technique-the balance cantilever technique. The pieces of the bridge were made upstream, floated down and lifted into place to construct what all Tasmanians who have seen it would say is an excellent construction which has a very pleasing appearance. It was built to replace the bridge damaged when a ship ran into it, something which was foreshadowed when discussions took place in the Parliament of Tasmania before the bridge was built across the Derwent River. It could very well happen again. Because this could happen again, from a mechanical point of view it is now much safer to go back and forth from the eastern and western shores of Hobart. In passing I would like to say how annoyed I get with delays in going over the other bridge, the main bridge, in Hobart. Traffic is held up for an inordinate length of time whenever a ship of certain size passes underneath it. Such delays are much too long and should be looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: This joint committee report on construction shows that the government of the day recognised just how important it was for Hobart to have a second bridge. In November 1975 the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments established a joint committee. Eventually, the results of the investigation and a design were presented to the Prime Minister and Premier in January 1979. It was estimated then that the cost would be some $32m. The total cost, which included the removal of the old rattling bailey bridge, eventually came to some $51 1/2m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took them a year to build that temporary one.

—It did, but not a lot of people had really thought that the first Derwent bridge, the Tasman Bridge, would be knocked down. The bridge that has been built-as a spare, if you like-is an excellent project. I would like to commend all those people who helped design it and work on it, many of whom I claim as my friends. I am very pleased to be able to speak about them today in the Senate. I point out that there are other bridges in the Hobart area that should be replaced. I am reliably informed that the one near Bridgewater on the highway between Hobart and Launceston would not take a substantial knock from a smaller ship or tug.
—And the barges.

—I do not think that barges are going through as often now because products from the newsprint mill at Boyer are being transported by road. But it is not a very strong bridge and at some stage it will have to be replaced. The Commonwealth and the State should be looking at this at this time. I am not saying that the Bridgewater bridge is not safe but it could easily be knocked out of operation. The other bridge that is still safe but will soon need attention is a causeway bridge down near Sorell. Recently, a speed limit has been placed on the bridge to stop any damage progressing to a dangerous state. Sooner or later both the State and the Commonwealth will have to look at both these bridges because projects such as the construction of bridges are usually beyond the means of just one government to finance.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

I wish to refer to one matter which arises from this report of the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission, about which I have spoken previously in the Senate. The report quite carefully goes through the activities of the Commission in 1985-86 and deals with its financial statements. The Commission functions well and serves the community well. The further guidelines, when referring to the future, say that owing to financial constraints it will be necessary for considerable care to be exercised by the Chief Executive Officer and the legal aid committees to ensure that such funds as are available for legal assistance are spread as widely over as many cases and to as many applicants as possible.

The matter that I wish to refer to, and as I have said I have done so previously, relates to Allen Douglas Thompson's appeal to the High Court of Australia based on the question of whether two of the murders that he committed and for which he was convicted took place in the Australian Capital Territory or New South Wales. As I said previously, it is a very interesting legal argument but it seems to me quite inappropriate that this action should be paid for by legal aid. The fact is that Thompson was in goal, having been convicted of six murders. There was no question of this case determining whether he would remain in custody or be set free. I agree that if the actual liberty of a person is at stake, perhaps that is a different matter. But in a technical argument of this kind which has no bearing on whether he would stay in goal or be set free, it seems to me that we have to look closely at restricting grants of legal aid to be quite certain that the Commission's aims as set out in this report-to see that assistance is spread as widely as possible over as many cases and to as many applicants as possible-are followed. I urge the Commission to take a stricter view of this sort of application.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

This paper basically is an addendum to a report issued earlier-the thirty-fourth annual report, 1985-86, of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The addendum concerns expenses and salaries and the general monetary situation. One of the things that the addendum covers in terms of salaries, and it thus refers back to the original report, is the safety aspects of visits by nuclear powered warships. I quote from page 65 of the report:

The Regulatory Bureau discharged for the Commission its role as technical adviser to the Department of Defence on the safety implications of visits by nuclear-powered warships to Australian ports, specifically in connection with berth assessment, co-ordinated routine radiation monitoring during visits and port contingency-planning against accidents.

The advice given to the Department of Defence was wrong because it failed dismally to give any credence to the possibility of accidents involving nuclear weapons. It is probably true that there is little danger from a nuclear weapon actually exploding on a warship in port, but there is a distinct possibility that a nuclear weapon could be involved in a fire-thus it does not explode but it can release radioactivity.

A Professor Jackson Davis from the University of California at Santa Cruz recently visited Australia, testified before a committee and gave a general statement to the Press. He pointed out that the incineration of a single nuclear warhead would release radiation which could cause 11,000 cancer deaths in Sydney and the clean-up cost, if it could be done, would be $150 billion. It is so costly because one would almost have to level the city of Sydney block by block, ship the blocks to outback New South Wales or some other place and then build a new Sydney. This is why the cost would be so expensive. This is the belief of not only Professor Jackson Davis but also of the Government Accounting Office in the United States of America which has included similar data in a report. This information was not put forward by the Atomic Energy Commission at all in its advice to the Department of Defence. The Atomic Energy Commission also underrated the risk and the consequences of nuclear reactor accidents. We know from Chernobyl, from Three Mile Island and from Windscale that accidents can occur in nuclear reactors. The Commission assumes that any accident could be contained and that it would be a fairly easy matter to tow a ship out to sea. It maintains that, if one can tow a ship out to sea in 24 hours, everything will be fine. The Commission assumes an evacuation zone of only 600 metres. It also assumes that potassium iodate tablets would negate the effects of radiation exposure. All these assumptions are wrong.

Current United States assessment of risks and consequences is that ports must plan for uncontained reactor meltdown. In other words, meltdown will not be contained in a ship but will spill over into the harbour itself. Of course, if this happens and one tows the ship out to sea, one must also evacuate the entire city because towing is totally inadequate. Unfortunately the Atomic Energy Commission is still protecting atomic energy in all its forms. In so doing it must become an apologist for nuclear weapons and for meltdown accidents in nuclear warships. The Commission is doing Australia a great disservice by not recognising the risks involved in visits to Australia by nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships. In forthcoming reports I hope that we will see the Commission take a realistic view of the dangers in visits by nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships and advise that such visits to Australia are no longer permitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the motion and respond to a couple of things that were said by Senator Sanders. One of the problems with Chernobyl was the fact that there was no containment on the nuclear reactor.
—It would have blown off the containment dome as well.
—That is not necessarily a fact. If Senator Sanders does some reading on these things, he will learn that the reactor is designed to keep inside any material that could be released.
—There is less impact from inside.
—That is not so. I am not going to enter into an argument.
—Order! Senator Sanders has already spoken in this debate. He should allow Senator Townley to proceed without interruption.

—They are designed to contain any element that might be otherwise released into the atmosphere. This design-and I believe that there are about 15 in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-has no containment. Graphite is used and this is what caused the main problem at Chernobyl: The graphite, to which of course is flammable, caught on fire and the attempts to put it out produced more steam and other products that caused a tremendous amount of trouble. That would not have been the case if proper containment had been designed.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that I do not believe that the Atomic Energy Commission-or the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, which is its new name-is an apologist for atomic weapons. It is just not current to say that someone who believes in nuclear power is an apologist for nuclear weapons. I for one believe that the main problem faced by this world is acid rain, which is caused by the release of sulphur and nitrogen oxides into the air from the burning of fossil fuels such as oil and coal.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the greenhouse effect.

—That is another effect of the burning of these fuels. As I said in this place the other day, acid rain-the combination of nitrates and sulphurous oxides with water from the atmosphere which falls as rain-is very acidic and is causing untold damage to lakes, trees, buildings and structures, particularly in the northern hemisphere. That does not mean that we in the southern hemisphere can sit back and not worry about it because eventually it will intermix and the problem will come down here. If the ozone layer happens to be reduced because of chemical reactions in the atmosphere, the ultraviolet radiation and other radiation will cause numerous cancers-many more, I believe, than would be the case from the accidential release of atomic particles as happened at Chernobyl.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not for one moment believe in nuclear weapons. Those of us who have thought about this realise the damage that they could cause, even if they were on a ship or in an aircraft which sustained damage. But a balance can be found. I repeat: I believe that the main thing we must do is produce a safe and effective nuclear-power plant that can be gradually perfected so that it is not a danger. This will help us to eliminate the burning of fossil fuels which is causing so much trouble in the northern hemisphere and which will eventually cause trouble in this country as well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984 provides grants to the States and the Northern Territory for financial assistance to universities, colleges of advanced education, institutes of tertiary education and for technical and further education for the 1985-87 triennium.

The purpose of this Bill is to adjust and supplement these grants for cost increases in accordance with the Government's agreed procedures. The supplementation takes account of the recent national wage decision for all but the university academics who are currently seeking an amendment to their award with the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Provision to cover changes resulting from this will be included in the next round of legislation. The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $78.281m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The primary purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (School Assistance) Act 1984 to supplement grants to government and non-government schools in the States and Northern Territory, in line with the Government's policy of providing retrospective cost supplementation for the Commonwealth's programs for schools.

This Bill also reflects the Government's decision to streamline the distribution of capital grants for non-government schools from 1988 through allocation as a block grant for distribution by approved block grant authorities. It is expected that in most States, Catholic schools will form one block authority and most other non-government schools a second authority. Non-government schools not electing to join an authority will still be able to apply directly to the Commonwealth for capital grants.
This Bill also implements the Government's decision that full fee paying private overseas secondary students will not be eligible for general recurrent grants.
The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $18m in 1987 and $9m in 1988.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Act 1983 to supplement for cost increases the grants available to government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects and programs under the participation and equity program in 1987. The Bill provides new schedules for 1987 showing the allocation of funds to the States, and Northern Territory and the education sectors.

The cost supplementation proposed is in accord with the Government's undertaking to provide retrospective cost supplementation for this program. The adjustments are consistent with those being made to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bills which are also before the Senate today.
The financial impact of this Bill will be to provide an additional $1.097m in 1987. Total provision for the participation and equity program is $45,819,000 in 1987.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

WOOL MARKETING BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce legislation to replace the Wool Industry Act 1972. The Bill will govern the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation and the wool auction system. It introduces a number of changes consistent with the Government's policy statement `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities'. The Bill also introduces additional administrative arrangements including measures for quality assurance of the Australian wool clip.

Associated with the Bill are five wool tax amendment Bills 1987 which I will address separately.
