It is intended that they provide the framework for the marketing of Australian wool over the next decade.

I believe that it is most appropriate that the Wool Marketing Bill be introduced to this House at a time when the Australian wool industry has re-emerged as Australia's leading rural export industry and in a year when wool exports are likely to contribute almost $4 billion to our balance of payments.

The present legislation for the wool industry, the Wool Industry Act 1972, commenced on 1 January 1973 in starkly different circumstances to those currently enjoyed by the industry. In the early 1970s the industry was on its knees. It was through bold leadership of the wool industry at that time by such men as Bill Vines, Bill Gun and others, including David Asimus, the present Chairman of the Corporation, and the initiative of Ken Wriedt that the reserve price scheme was established, the decline in the wool industry arrested and the basis for a sound reconstruction laid.

The recovery of the industry since that time can in no small way be attributed to the arrangements set in place in the Wool Industry Act. The Australian Wool Corporation has operated effectively in its support of the market through the reserve price scheme and wool growers have strengthened the position of wool in the world textile market by their continued investment in wool promotion and research and development.

Notwithstanding the present buoyancy in the wool market, the industry faces enormous challenges in the future. We should not let our record wool exports hide from us the fact that wool is a special fibre occupying a small and declining share of total textile consumption. It presently accounts for only around 5 per cent of overall world textile use against a 47 per cent share for cotton and 48 per cent for synthetics. Furthermore, in those areas where wool is relatively strong, its share is declining. Wool had 33 per cent of the menswear market in 1970, it has about 18 per cent today. Similarly its share of womenswear has fallen from 27 per cent to 14 per cent and knitwear from 40 per cent to 27 per cent.

These markets are extremely volatile and subject to the vagaries of shifts in world fashion and alternate expenditure choices available to consumers. We must remain vigilant to the need to maintain high levels of investment in wool marketing, promotion and research and development, so that wool continues to be profitably sold overseas.

On the supply side, honourable senators are aware of the present disruption in world agricultural markets and the potential for a continued shift in resources away from other farm enterprises, in particular cropping, to wool. Sheep numbers have grown rapidly from 133 million in 1983 to an estimated current flock of 160 million. A continuation of this rate of growth poses a longer term challenge for the wool industry and must be monitored. We must have flexible marketing arrangements in place to meet any crisis in the supply of wool arising from an expansion in sheep numbers.

In addition to demand and supply considerations, the wool industry must also remain aware of the future options which may emerge in the whole chain of events from the production to consumption of wool. At the moment the Australian industry can stand proud. It clearly surpasses all other wool producing nations not only in the quality of wool it produces but the way that it is harvested, handled, sold, stored and distributed. It has an outstanding record of innovation. However the industry cannot rest on its laurels. We compete not only against other wool producers, but against other fibres and other options for the consumer to spend his or her dollar. The industry must therefore remain cognizant of the need to continually innovate, adapt and modify, to ensure that wool is moved from the sheep to the consumer in the way that presents the best product to the consumer in the most cost effective way.

This means that the wool industry must think creatively in working out better ways of doing things and how new technologies can be embraced in the industry. In many cases this will involve an extension and improvement in present techniques. For example it is likely the industry will continue with manual shearing for many years. But I believe there is considerable scope for researching the ergonomic basis of shearing and to research shed management to improve the process to the benefit of both wool growers and shearing teams.

But in addition to incremental changes of this kind, I am sure there is still scope to make dramatic changes in the wool logistics system through a re-examination of the location of present facilities and the way wool is stored, handled and sold.

In this respect I anticipate that the industry will make significant breakthroughs in the coming years in computerisation of the selling system linked with sale by description. I also believe there is potential for significant gains in the on-shore transportation of wool.

Further to the above, the Government is of the view that there is considerable scope for further processing of wool in Australia. Vision will need to be applied in working out how this can best be done and in marshalling the necessary investment funds. Nevertheless the potential benefits for the community and the industry in employment, infrastructure development and in ensuring long term contracts for sale of Australian wool are significant. The Government will continue to examine these opportunities, in particular, as part of the textile initiatives being introduced by my colleague Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

This brief outline of pressures on the industry and possibilities open to it, illustrates the extent of change the industry inevitably faces. Continued success in the industry, like any other business operation, will require that change process to be properly understood and effectively managed.

It is timely therefore that the process commenced in the late 1960s and early 1970s be extended to cover modern demands and to position the industry to prepare for the circumstances it will encounter in the 1990s and into the next century. It is for this purpose that the Minister has developed new arrangements in consultation with the wool industry. The result of this process is the Bill I now propose to this House.

The Bill focuses on four principal objectives. First, the Bill seeks to place the Australian Wool Corporation on a sound commercial footing so that it is equipped to respond now and into the future to the pressures of the market place. Second, the Bill is designed to introduce appropriate arrangements to ensure the Corporation is fully accountable to industry and Government without disturbing its commercial performance. Third, the Bill introduces new arrangements for the quality assurance of Australian wool. Finally, the Bill has the objective of providing modern businesslike legislation for the industry which will guide the industry towards the next century.
I would now like to comment in more detail on the Bill in relation to these objectives.

This Government has distinguished itself in comparison to the previous coalition governments in that it has introduced significant market deregulation and opened the way for better commercial operation by Australian enterprises. It has abandoned conservative rhetoric and given the market the chance to work. The initiative of this Government is particularly evident in the approach it has taken to the changed administration of its Government statutory business enterprises and to the reform of its statutory marketing authorities.

The Australian Wool Corporation has been successful in its commercial operation. But the Corporation like other statutory marketing authorities has been constrained by the need to comply with numerous Government controls which have presented difficulties for it in its market operations.

The Government has already, in its general reforms of statutory marketing authorities, made a number of changes to the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation. These are outlined in the Government's policy statement `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Marketing Authorities' released as a White Paper on 29 January 1986. Many of the reforms outlined in that document have been discussed in this House in respect to the meat, wheat, dairy and wine and brandy statutory marketing arrangements. I do not propose to discuss these reforms in detail except where the wool statutory arrangements are significantly different and where this Bill removes further controls on the Corporation to place it, where possible, on an equivalent footing to commercial business corporations.
It is essential if the Corporation is to operate on an effective commercial basis, that its Board comprise the best available talent. To this end I introduce a number of changes.

The Minister will continue to select and appoint the chairperson of the Corporation as well as the Government director. However in keeping with best commercial practice I believe it is appropriate that there be flexibility to make sure that the person appointed to chair the Corporation is the best available and that that appointment is made on the most appropriate basis for the Corporation at that time. The Bill will therefore provide for the chairperson to be appointed on a part time or full time basis. Where a full time chairperson is appointed that person will be the Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation. Where however the chairperson is appointed on a part time basis, a Managing Director will be appointed by the Board as an additional director of the Corporation and that person will be the Chief Executive Officer.
Honourable senators will agree that it is imperative that the Corporation be headed by the best available person and the increased flexibility provided by the Bill will enable this to be the case.

The wool industry has been fortunate to have David Asimus as its Chairman for the past eight years. David has been an outstanding Chairman and has piloted the Corporation to its present successful position. David has publicly announced his intention to retire as Chairman of the Corporation when his current term expires at the end of June 1988. He will be sorely missed and he will be a most difficult person to replace. The new arrangements in the Bill will give the Minister more options to work with in trying to fill the gap David will leave. I hope however that we can do more than this.

The Minister has said that he will ask David to stay on to serve the industry in some capacity, if it is at all possible for him to do so. There are numerous positions a person of his talent could ably fill. One which occurs to me is Chairman of the International Wool Secretariat. In the past the Australian Wool Corporation and International Wool Secretariat Chairman roles have been filled by two people, although in recent practice the full time Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation has also been the Chairman of the International Wool Secretariat. The new arrangements could open up the option for David to continue as Chairman of the International Wool Secretariat.

In respect of other appointments to the Australian Wool Corporation the Bill provides for nine other Directors, in the case of a part time chairperson with a full time Managing Director, and eight other directors in the case of a full time chairperson. At present there is a Chairman, Government member and eight other members, four grower members appointed on the nomination of the Wool Council of Australia and four special qualifications members selected and appointed by the Minister. The Australian Wool Corporation has been served well by its members and these have been of the highest calibre. Nevertheless I do not believe that this procedure will always result in the best available persons being appointed.

The Bill proposes a selection arrangement for the purpose of seeking out the best persons for appointment as directors of the Australian Wool Corporation. The procedure to be used has been worked out with the Wool Council of Australia and is unique to this Bill. The arrangement acknowledges that the Wool Council of Australia, as the body representing the growers who contribute to Australian Wool Corporation funds, should be represented on the Committee tasked with selecting the best persons for appointment to the Corporation.

When a vacancy on the Australian Wool Corporation occurs the Wool Council of Australia will nominate between three and six persons to represent them on the Selection Committee. Those persons will join the presiding member of the Committee who will be a statutory officeholder appointed by the Minister for a term not exceeding three years.

The Wool Industry Selection Committee so comprised will select grower and other special expertise persons for nomination as the eight selected directors to the Australian Wool Corporation according to selection criteria specified in the Bill. In undertaking its task the Selection Committee may employ staff and engage the services of a personnel search consultant. The Committee will be required to advertise for nominations in a newspaper circulated throughout Australia and the presiding member will be required to consult with the chairperson of the Australian Wool Corporation on the skills and qualities that should be reflected in the membership of the Corporation.

Members of parliament, members of the Wool Council of Australia and members of the Selection Committee established to select persons for nomination to a particular vacancy will not be eligible for nomination to the Corporation. When the Selection Committee has completed its task it will be abolished by the presiding member. When another vacancy arises the presiding member will write to the Wool Council of Australia so advising them and requesting nominations of persons to represent them on the Selection Committee he will then establish to select persons against that vacancy or vacancies.

The Wool Industry Selection Committee will therefore be an `ad hoc' committee established for the purpose of nominating persons to a position or group of positions and will dissolve once appointments are made. The one permanent appointment and obviously the pivotal position will be that of presiding member.

It has always been the Minister's intention that a leading business figure would be appointed as Presiding Member to provide guidance to selection committee members on the requirements of a balanced corporate Board and on selection techniques. I have pleasure in announcing that Sir Roderick Carnegie has agreed to serve as Presiding Member for an initial three-year period. As members of this House will be aware, Sir Roderick is an outstanding Australian. He will serve the wool industry with great distinction.
In the interim all current members of the Board of the Corporation will continue in office as directors under the new arrangements until their terms expire.

Members will be aware of the sophistication of modern financial markets and of the complexities involved in present day financial management. Any corporation which is not structured so that it can control its cash flows, place its money and borrow at the best rates and adapt to changing circumstances, is vulnerable. In this context it is worth noting the financial demands on the Australian Wool Corporation. It presently has in excess of $1 billion to the credit of the market support fund, sells wool internationally in various currencies and could in the event of a severe downturn in the market be required to spend heavily in purchasing wool to support the market. The Australian Wool Corporation can on a financial transaction basis be equated with larger Australian private corporations.

It is not appropriate in this regard for the Australian Wool Corporation to be hampered in its ability to operate commercially. It cannot be expected to frequently seek ministerial or government approvals for corporate financial decisions. It is also fundamentally wrong for major decisions on the finances and market operations of the Australian Wool Corporation, such as decisions on the minimum reserve price, to be taken in a political environment. If the Australian Wool Corporation is to act as an autonomous commercial body it must have its financial arrangements established, as far as possible on a commercial basis like any other business organisation. The Bill introduces a number of changes to ensure this. It also establishes a proper relationship on financial matters between the Australian Wool Corporation, the Government and the Wool Council of Australia.

At present the Minister for Primary Industry determines the market indicator floor price each year for the Reserve Price Scheme. This is inconsistent with the Government's objectives of maximum commercial flexibility and autonomy. Accordingly, the Bill provides for the Corporation, as the commercial operator, to set and announce the minimum market indicator reserve price and the reserve prices for the various wool types, after agreement with the Wool Council on the minimum market indicator price. This arrangement recognises not only the commercial role of the Australian Wool Corporation but also the role of the Wool Council of Australia in representing the wool growers who provide the funds through a tax paid on the shorn value of wool sold. If the Corporation and the Council are unable to agree the Minister will determine and announce the minimum reserve price for that year.

The Corporation will be required to furnish information relative to the setting of the minimum market indicator reserve price and the proposed levels for minimum reserve prices in the annual operational plan for the Minister's agreement. Moreover, the Minister will continue to require the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to advise him on the factors underlying the supply and demand for wool and the appropriate floor price level and to publish this information to provide another viewpoint to assist the Wool Council in the consultation process.

Recently the need has been demonstrated for more flexibility in the rate and apportionment of wool tax. In particular the present experience of a healthy market support fund has been accompanied by a shortfall in funds for promotion arising from the depreciation of the Australian dollar. As a move in this direction the Bill provides for the Wool Council, after consultation with the Corporation, to decide how their wool tax should be allocated each year. Minimum allocations of 2.5 per cent to market support, 2.5 per cent to promotion and general purposes of the Corporation and 0.25 per cent to wool research and development have been specified. In other words 5.25 per cent of the wool tax on the shorn value of wool will be committed each year leaving the Wool Council free to allocate the remainder of the tax among these areas of activity.

The Minister will shortly be introducing complementary legislation to increase the ceiling rate of wool tax from 8 per cent of the shorn value of wool to 10 per cent. This will give greater flexibility to the Corporation to respond to pressures on the reserve price scheme and promotion funding needs. I should hastily add that the increase in the ceiling rate does not mean that the operational rate will automatically change from the current 8 per cent. Any request from the Wool Council for an increase in the present ceiling rate will be studied very carefully by the Treasurer and the Minister before making a decision. The reponsibility for determining refunds will rest with the Wool Council.

Current arrangements, whereby the Corporation can borrow up to $200m without ministerial approval, and at least a further $200m with approvals are inflexible and inconsistent with statutory marketing authority reform policy. In the event of a sudden and significant downturn in the market necessitating heavy buying by the Corporation, it is vital that the Corporation be able to fund purchases and maintain market confidence in the floor price through immediate access to substantial funds available under previously arranged lines of credit. This Bill provides for the Australian Wool Corporation to borrow, without ministerial approval, up to 50 per cent of its net assets valued at the end of the previous financial year. Borrowings beyond 50 per cent of Corporation net assets at the end of the preceding financial year will continue to require ministerial approval.

In effect this means that the greater the net value of assets the higher the permissible level of borrowings with approval. To place this approach in perspective, it would have implied borrowings of about $500m if applied in 1986-87. This arrangement allows the corporation to borrow to the extent of a 50 per cent debt to equity ratio which is a conservative level when compared with leverage levels of modern business enterprises particularly in the light of the Corporation's conservative valuation of some of its assets. The Australian Wool Corporation has an outstanding record of financial stewardship to support this arrangement and will have a high calibre expertise based Board to oversight its implementation.

The Bill also provides for the Corporation, after consultation with the Wool Council, to appoint a commercial auditor should it so wish. If it does seek to use a commercial auditor, the Minister for Primary Industry will be responsible for the appointment of the auditor subject to the Auditor-General's agreement that the auditor is suitable and to the agreement of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Accounts. I believe this provision is an important step in increasing the commercialisation of the Australian Wool Corporation.

Under the existing legislation the precise ownership of some wool stores which were vested in a predecessor of the Corporation in 1953 has been uncertain, particularly in view of the defence provision dating back to World War II which allows the wool stores to be reacquired in the event of threat of war. This Bill removes the defence provision which has been rendered obsolete and clarifies the ownership issue by fully vesting all wool stores in the Corporation.

Simultaneously the Bill upgrades the status and visibility of the wool stores operation by establishing a separate wool stores board of management as a sub-committee of the Corporation to administer the stores to the benefit of wool growers. The wool stores board of management will be required to prepare corporate and annual operation plans and an audited annual report, with full visibility of financial accounts, to the corporation for inclusion in the latter's annual report.

The wool stores managed by the Corporation are an important aspect of the wool marketing and logistics system in Australia and it is of paramount importance that they be established on an appropriate management basis. In addition the stores are a significant asset of Australian wool growers. They should be managed so as to ensure the best commercial returns to wool growers and growers should be appraised of the location and other relevant information on the stores and on the results of their management. Provisions in the Bill will achieve these goals.
The third objective I stated for this Bill was that of ensuring accountability by the Corporation in a way which does not disturb the Corporation's commercial performance.

Under the arrangements proposed in the Bill there will be a significant devolution of responsibility to the Corporation to allow greater operational flexibility by freeing it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for approval of each major activity. This re-direction is essential to the proper commercial functioning of the Corporation. Whilst they give additional freedom to the Corporation over commercial matters, these changes can in no way be taken as reducing the level of its accountability by the Australian Wool Corporation to government and wool growers. The changes I have mentioned are accompanied by provisions to ensure proper accountability. These provisions are interlocked in the Bill so that the Corporation will be required to operate on a corporate strategic basis both in its management and in its dual accountability to Government and industry.

The Bill, as discussed previously, clearly defines the role of the Australian Wool Corporation and ensures that it has the wherewithal, including the necessary skills at board level, to perform its role in a commercial manner. In this respect the selection committee comprised essentially of Wool Council of Australia nominees will have an important accountability role. The Minister will select and appoint the chairperson of the Corporation and that person will be his principal point of contact with the Corporation. He will relate with the chairperson throughout the year and in particular he will request that he or she report to him on any substantial policy matters, pertinent to the corporation's relationship to Government policy, following each board meeting.

The Minister will also select and appoint the Government director who will be a special expertise appointee knowledgable in matters of Government policy and public administration. The Government director will not however have a reporting relationship to the Minister on Corporation business which is any different to that of any of the other directors. In this respect the Minister will expect that person, like any other director, to perform a two hatted role in respect of the separation between the corporate role as a director of the Corporation and any other role normally filled.

In keeping with modern corporate practice, the Corporation will be required to prepare each year, after consultation with the Wool Council of Australia, a corporate plan for the ensuing five-year period and an operational plan for the next financial year and submit these for the Minister's agreement at least one month before the commencement of the period. These plans will address the strategies the Corporation intends to follow and the Corporation will be required to state its strategies in respect of wool stores, research and development and its equal employment opportunity program. The Wool Research and Development Council will also prepare a five-year research and development plan for presentation to the Corporation for later submission for the Minister's agreement.

The Corporation will also be required to present an annual report for the latest financial year to Parliament and to the Wool Council of Australia within a specified time frame. This report is to include full particulars of the Corporation's activities with full visibility of the financial accounts pertaining to each activity. In particular the report will contain an assessment of the Corporation's performance during the financial year against the corporate goals agreed with the Minister for that year. The Chairman of the Corporation will be required to personally present the report to the first meeting of the Wool Council after it is tabled in Parliament and to be available to answer any questions arising from the report.

Apart from the accountability procedures mentioned above, there is also a provision for the Minister to give directions to the Corporation in exceptional circumstances. I do not envisage the use of such a power with any frequency. It is in the nature of a reserve provision and there are strong caveats against its capricious use including the requirement that any directions issued to the Corporation be in writing, gazetted and tabled in Parliament.

The corporate strategic arrangements I have outlined here both provide the Australian Wool Corporation with a modern management system for its operations and an effective strategic basis for its meeting its accountability obligations.

In respect of the wool quality assurance objectives of the Government it is important to recognise the value of wool to Australian agricultural producers and the wider community. Wool is our number one rural export and Australia is the dominant world supplier of apparel wool. We must do everything possible to preserve that market dominance of Australian wool and its competitive position relative to other fibres. This includes taking whatever measures are necessary to safeguard the integrity of Australian wool.

The wool industry has, essentially through self-regulatory approaches, sought to institute sound quality controls in the selling system and has participated on Corporation advisory committees in the establishment of wool selling regulations and clip preparation standards. The Australian Wool Corporation also operates a voluntary scheme for registration of wool classers.

Notwithstanding these measures there are reports from overseas mills of wool being delivered which is not to standard, contains contamination or in some other way does not conform to desirable levels of quality. When one examines present procedures and the prospect for unscrupulous operation, the need for change is real. This will become an increasingly important issue as wool is sold by description with further introduction of automated processes in modern textile mills. There is also a growing community concern about the quality of commodities generally and with the pesticide issue.
I believe that more has to be done to build industry co-operation and the Bill introduces a number of new quality assurance provisions with the Corporation playing a pivotal role.

The Bill provides for compulsory registration of wool classers classing wool to be sold at auction, prohibition of sale at auction unless classed by a registered wool classer and deregistration of wool classers for up to two weeks where such classers have been found to consistently flout industry agreed standards for presentation of wool for auction. The scheme, to be administered by the Corporation in consultation with appropriate industry advisory committees, will cover owner classers, professional classers and classing houses. Although aimed at auctions for practical administration reasons it is expected that the benefits will flow over to wool sold outside auction.

It is expected that deregistration action would be an infrequently used deterrent but would have a significant impact on the industry. Any deregistration action would be subject to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Minister will request the Corporation to form a committee comprising all relevant industry organisations, including the Woolclassers Association, to develop this scheme.

Pesticide residues in wool and wool by-products such as lanolin also pose a threat to our exports. Pesticides such as dieldrin are illegal under State legislation for use on livestock but at present there are no adequate control mechanisms to ensure that sheep are not improperly treated. Pesticide residues can only be detected through chemical analysis and this Bill enables the Corporation to acquire samples from wool testing houses, to ascertain the ownership of wool found to have excessive levels of pesticide residue. The Corporation will then be able to provide a warning to the grower and if necessary to inform the relevant state authorities for action under State legislation.

Reserve powers are also provided in the Bill to allow the withdrawal from auction of any wool which the Corporation advised where appropriate by its industry advisory committees, considers does not meet industry standards of preparation. This also includes action to stop the use of second hand wool packs. These reserve powers will require the offending bales and documentation to be noted accordingly, with such notation to be withdrawn once the wool has been re-prepared in accordance with acceptable standards. The intention is only to invoke such powers if industry agreement and action on a self regulatory approach is not forthcoming.

A further matter which affects wool quality is shearing. The Minister is concerned at industry reports that the present high level of wool production will lead to shortages in the availability of quality shearers with adverse effects on the industry. The Minister has specified a function in the Bill for the Australian Wool Corporation to encourage and facilitate the training of shearers with a view to ensuring the availability of shearers for the industry and a standard of shearing suited to its needs.
The Minister has also asked his Department to investigate what more can be done by the Commonwealth Government in this respect and will introduce further policy changes if necessary.

I make the comment, in regard to the quality assurance provisions of the Bill, that these issues have been around the industry for many years. Recently a report was released by an industry committee set up to prepare a code of practice for preparation of Australian wool clips. Apart from that report the questions of poor clip preparation and contamination, classer registration, use of secondhand packs and pesticide residues are all issues, Mr President, which everyone has been aware of and nobody has acted on. This Government is not prepared to shirk the issue. The risks from exposure under present legislation are too high and this Government has acted decisively to introduce real change.
The final objective I mentioned for this Bill is that of providing a modern, businesslike legislation to govern the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation and the auction system.

We have through the Bill sought to establish a new modern commercial approach to the administration of wool marketing in this country. If we are to be successful in this endeavour, the new arrangements must provide a sound good management practice and be expressed in such a way that its provisions are clearly communicated to and understood by participants in the wool marketing system.

This Bill is expressed, as far as possible, in what is commonly called plain English terms. Much of the detail of the Wool Industry Act has been removed and the Bill is organised on the basis of a clear logical structure. There is a clear specification in the Bill of the objects and functions of the Corporation. The Bill comprises nine integral parts, including a new part introduced to cover the finance of the Corporation. Each part is self contained with a statement of the object, functions and powers of the Australian Wool Corporation in respect of that part.

I have outlined as far as possible the most significant reforms to the administration arrangements for the wool industry since 1972. I have considered a number of changes in detail and have alluded to the Government's reforms for statutory marketing authorities which include adoption of equal employment opportunity procedures and the power to establish subsidiaries, subject to Ministerial approval.

Because the reforms are so extensive it has been considered logical, as proposed, to repeal the existing Wool Industry Act 1972 as frequently amended and replace it with the Wool Marketing Bill, a title more representative of the content and orientation of the legislation. Many sections of the Wool Industry Act have been retained, notably the 1986 amendments to wool research and development. The old section relating to refunds from the Market Support Fund was essentially a set of administrative procedures and guidelines and these have been removed to be redrafted as regulations to be made under the proposed legislation.
I am confident that the new Wool Marketing Bill will enable the wool industry to better respond to future marketing challenges.

The proposed reforms are not expected to impose any additional costs on the Commonwealth. Indeed it is expected that there will be indirect savings, albeit modest, in administration through devolution of responsibility to the Corporation.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
WOOL TAX (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool Tax Act (No. 1) 1964. At present the Act provides for the imposition of a tax on the sale value of shorn wool sold by a wool broker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Advisory Council (Amendment) Ordinance 1987, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 2 of 1987 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

The Advisory Council (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 proposes to do two things. Firstly, it removes a requirement that seven people be needed to form a quorum at meetings of any advisory council that a government may set up in the Australian Capital Territory in the future. Of course, such an advisory council is no substitute for effective self-government, which is what the Australian Democrats would like to see for the Australian Capital Territory. Such effective self-government must have proper financial guarantees available in the legislation and an electoral system which would not provide 60 per cent of the seats on 40 per cent of the votes and must provide real control over the day to day matters, including land planning and administration of the Territory, by a body which has been properly and reasonably elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

The second arm of the Ordinance which I am seeking to disallow today has the following objectionable aim: To allow the Minister, at his discretion, to determine the number of people on such an advisory council. I quote from the explanatory statements on this Ordinance:
The Advisory Council (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 amends the principal Ordinance to provide that the number of members comprising the Council will be at the Minister's discretion.

I would like the Senate to realise that `at the Minister's discretion' means totally open slather. The Senate has, at this stage, knocked out the quite outlandish sums of $9,701 in fees and $1,000 in allowances that the Remuneration Tribunal put forward in response to the submission of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) for this advisory council.

However, it is still possible for a future government to aim at a similar waste of money, and perhaps even a greater one. Under those circumstances we would need to be constantly vigilant because we could end up with a Minister deciding that he wanted to appoint 30, 40 or any number of people to such an advisory council, if this type of arrangement were available. Indeed, the Government might want sinecures for people to assist in a campaign leading up to a general election. It might want to pay off old debts and give people safe positions on a body. This is an open cheque if we do not reject this Ordinance.

It is quite important that we should be making certain that future governments cannot just take up the idea of the advisory council. The current Minister has said that he will not go ahead with it, so it really does not make any sense that we should be debating this now. I offered, if the Government were willing to support me, to make this a formal motion; but the Government said that it would vote against this disallowance motion. That seems very fishy to me. The Government said that it was not going ahead with the advisory council; why then is it so keen on making this change which gives the Minister open slather? I remind the Senate that the Government has failed to make available time for debate of any of the Bills for self-government which are now on the Senate Notice Paper. We have not been given a chance to debate them. If we had been, they would have been passed with amendments and we would now have properly elected self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. I point out that it is distinctly in the Government's court that we do not have proper and effective self-government in the Australian Capital Territory.

The second point that I want to make is that already a large number of committees advise the Minister directly. Such committees as the Taxi Fares Advisory Committee, the Community Services Council and the Housing Liaison Advisory Committee advise the Minister, and others are set up from time to time. A small advisory committee might have been acceptable, provided that we did not pay for it. Had the Government made clear that what it wanted to do was to have no more than 13 people on any advisory committee, we would not have objected to this-if it was to be a smaller number. However, that is not what the Ordinance says. The Ordinance removes the words `12 other councillors' in section 6 (1) (b) of the Advisory Council Ordinance 1986 and it leaves the way open for 20, 30 or 100 appointees if that is what the Government wants.

The current shambles over the appointment of the successor to Senator Grimes, I believe, shows that it is very important to get wording right. The alteration to the Constitution in 1977 had a variety of known defects and others have emerged since.

We have had quite a few difficulties, even with the very first appointments under that new system, and we will have quite a few more. The Senate is able to say to the Minister and the Department of Territories: `If you really do mean no more than 12 advisory councillors plus a president, then we should say it explicitly'. That is what our job is. We should not just leave it in a vacuum and let some sort of general understanding prevail. History has shown that governments do not operate that way. The situation in Tasmania with the replacement of Senator Grimes shows that if there is a hole in the wording it will be used. It would be totally remiss of this Senate as a House of review to allow an open-ended proposition of this type to go through and on the books, even if this Government does not intend to use it. If this Government does not intend to use it the Government should be voting against it and not cluttering the books, cluttering the legislative system, with utterly useless pieces of legislation. I believe we are here to keep Ministers and administrators on the straight and narrow. We were elected as Australian Democrats on some type of theme to `keep the bastards honest'. That is exactly what we are doing. It may be in something very small; in this case there is something fishy about this Ordinance. Why is the Government insisting on wanting to have a vote at this stage on an issue which it is telling us is dead? We need answers to those types of questions, and we must also have the courage to stand up and say to the Government: `Come clean on this. If you really do mean not to have an advisory council, why are you forcing us into this situation?'.

I would just like to complete my short presentation on this matter by pointing out that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has a role to play in investigating the problems that exist in the Australian Capital Territory. The people of the Australian Capital Territory are not being given proper rights of representation by this Government, and that is a real problem that we are facing. This particular Advisory Council (Amendment) Ordinance is just a part of the artificial construction which this Government is putting up as an excuse for self-government, as a replacement for self-government, and I believe that is just not good enough and we should throw it out holus-bolus.

DEBATE.TITLE: JURISDICTION OF COURTS (CROSS-VESTING) BILL 1987JURISDICTION OF COURTS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill implement major proposals by the Government to rationalise the judicial system in Australia, and that question is of the utmost importance, and these Bills have very great significance because of that importance. The Opposition has favoured the cross-vesting proposal, and we will support that Bill, although we will be proposing a number of amendments to it. However, we believe the other Bill, the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, is not only contrary to the notion of cross-vesting of jurisdiction, but also goes a step backwards from the present situation, and we will oppose that Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject that these Bills deal with, as I have said, relates to the whole of the judicial system of Australia, and therefore the legislation is of historic significance. Because Australia is a federation and because the Constitution creates a Federal judicial power, we have within our Constitution the inevitable situation of there being Federal jurisdiction as well as State jurisdiction. That was the choice of the founders of the Constitution. They in that regard, as in many others, were influenced by the Constitution of the United States of America. Anyone familiar with the United States Constitution and the way it works in the judicial area is well aware of this great significance of the Federal jurisdiction and State jurisdiction, of Federal courts and State courts, and of the misuse which can be made of those two streams, because in the United States of America the concept has been taken to excess, and virtually never the twain shall meet. Indeed, I suppose television watchers these days without any legal training would have heard the expressions `That is in the Federal jurisdiction' or `That is in the State jurisdiction' and so on.

The Australian Constitution did not go as far as that, and indeed left it open for the Federal Parliament, although it has the power to set up its own judicial system, to invest the State courts with Federal jurisdiction. By and large, until the last decade or so, that has been the choice followed by governments and parliaments in Australia. So the real problems of having conflicting jurisdictions between the Federal and State systems was avoided in Australia until comparatively recent times. I might add, of course, that there is another major difference between the United States system and our own system under our Constitution. That is the establishment of the High Court of Australia as the final court of appeal, not only, of course, in constitutional matters but also in matters from all courts in Australia, whether they are State courts or Federal courts, exercising State or Federal jurisdiction. It was a piece of great enlightenment on the part of the founders of the Australian Constitution that they saw the force and certainly the desirability of having a hierarchical judicial system with one final court of appeal. Of course, in those days there was the Privy Council as well, but I do not need to go into that. But certainly the fact that they established the High Court as the final court of appeal from both the Federal and State judicial systems is of tremendous importance and value. It now gives us the opportunity of doing something effective about the conflicts which have arisen in recent years.

The possibility of such conflicts has always been inherent in the system. Their dangers were perceived very well by Australia's greatest lawyer, Sir Owen Dixon. In fact, he detected and warned about them as long ago as the 1920s when he gave evidence before a royal commission on the Constitution. He strongly advocated then, 60 years ago, that we do something about the matter before we got into the American mess. He suggested that there ought simply to be a unified court system in Australia which was neither Federal nor State. But, of course, the proposal that he advanced would have required a constitutional amendment, and no government or parliament in Australia has thought that to be a very satisfactory way of proceeding.

I would like to refer to some remarks made by Sir Owen Dixon when he was sworn in as Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. My colleague the shadow Attorney-General quoted these remarks in another place and I think they should be put into the record of the Senate as well. Sir Owen said:

. . . I think it has become apparent to a larger number of people, and to all the judges of the Commonwealth, that the judicial system of the Commonwealth is an integral whole and that the High Court stands merely as the final appellate tribunal in Australia in that coherent and established system which is recognised as a unit in judicial administration . . . In saying that this represents simply the appellate tribunal and the tribunal for Federal questions in the judicial system of the Commonwealth, I do not overlook the distinction which we unfortunately maintain between State and Federal jurisdiction. This is an eighteenth century conception which we derived from the United States of America in the faithful copy which was made of their judicial institutions. It is to be hoped that at some future time it will be recognised that under the English system of law, the British system of law which we inherited, the whole body of law is antecedent to the work of any Legislation and that the courts as a whole must interpret and apply the whole of law, so that there should be one judicial system in Australia which is neither State nor Commonwealth but a system of Australian courts administering the total body of the law.

As I said, those remarks were made by Sir Owen, when he was sworn in as Chief Justice of the High Court in, I think 1952. He was repeating then what he had already said 20-odd years before. Indeed, he maintained that view throughout the rest of his legal career. I think it is a view which is subscribed to by most Australian lawyers, but, as I said, unfortunately it is one which requires a constitutional amendment to give effect to it. Although the odd few problems probably arose from time to time prior to the 1970s, I would imagine that it was then that problems began to arise more regularly, particularly after the establishment of the Federal Court in Australia in 1977. However, there had been a Federal Court prior to that, known as the Industrial Court, and no doubt there were some areas of conflict then.

The other major initiative of the Federal Parliament in the 1970s was the establishment of the Family Court of Australia. So about this time there were very great advances by the Commonwealth in establishing and expanding the Federal judicial system. At more or less the same time there was also a very considerable increase in legislative activity by the Parliament. New areas of legal rights and obligations were created, particularly in the trade practices area. In many other areas Federal powers were exercised for the first time, creating further potential for conflicts of jurisdiction.

Looking back, I regret that the matter was not really more fully thought out and that these problems were not grappled with at an earlier stage. But, certainly by the time I became Attorney-General towards the end 1977, a lot of concerns were arising. I can remember suggesting at the Constitutional Convention in Perth in 1978 that we should look, through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, not at the ideal propounded by Sir Owen Dixon but at some ways of co-ordinating the State and Federal courts and the jurisdictions conferred on them respectively by this Parliament in order to minimise as far as we could the potential for conflict so that litigants would not be shunted around from one court to another wasting money and time and generally finding the legal system utterly infuriating. I might say that fortunately it is not an area of the law which most legal practitioners find of any interest, because the legal arguments involved really are quite arid and useless and I think most lawyers-even though some of them may make a little money out of them-do not find them agreeable or satisfying.

So the search has continued since then. One of the ways that were favoured at one point was the investing of State and Federal courts with concurrent jurisdiction under Federal laws. There were thought to be difficulties about State parliaments investing Federal courts with jurisdiction-I suppose there still are difficulties-but legal advice now seems to indicate that that is possible, and that has been a major advance towards the legislation that we now have before us.

Shortly after the present Government came to power, at a legal convention in Adelaide some more adventurous proposals were advanced whereby, instead of simply conferring concurrent jurisdiction on State or Federal courts we made a move to a bolder plan along the lines envisaged, I guess, by Sir Owen Dixon which might be achieved without the need for constitutional amendment. A committee of that Constitutional Convention was set up. It was chaired by Mr Storey, a former Victorian Attorney-General for some years; and Senator Gareth Evans and I were members of that committee, together with a number of other State politicians most of whom had had experience in this area and who had in some cases also been State Attorneys-General.

That committee consulted widely with judges, with State Governments and with the profession, and it recommended to the Constitutional Convention held in Brisbane in August 1985 two proposals. One was the cross-vesting of jurisdiction at trial level between the Federal Court of Australia and the State Supreme Courts and between the Family Court of Australia and the State Supreme Courts, such cross-vesting of jurisdiction to be effected by the conferring of original Federal jurisdiction on State Supreme Courts and the conferring of original State jurisdiction on the Federal Court and the Family Court; and secondly it recommended the setting up of an Australian court of appeal below the High Court of Australia to hear appeals in civil matters from the decisions of the State Supreme Courts, the Federal Court and the Family Court. That committee was well aware of the objections widely held to the idea of establishing an Australian court of appeal, so it did not link the two proposals together. It left it to the Convention to decide either to accept both proposals or simply the proposal for cross-vesting. In the event, the Convention decided that the only proposal that would be widely accepted was the proposal for cross-vesting of jurisdiction, and the committee detailed the way it would work.

The Convention did not adopt the proposal for an Australian court of appeal below the High Court. I think that was an unfortunate decision. It was unfortunate that, for the better development of the Australian legal system, agreement could not be reached on the establishment of an intermediate Federal court of appeal below the High Court. Schemes were proposed whereby State judges would participate fully in that court. When I say a Federal court, it would be Federal only in the sense that it would necessarily be established by Federal legislation, but certainly every opportunity should, in my view, have been taken to proceed with that proposal because it would have been better, instead of having a whole appellate system within the Federal Court and another in the State court, with the High Court ultimately at the pinnacle of the system, to pool the resources of the State and Federal systems into one appellate court standing between those judges exercising the original jurisdiction and the High Court. But that opportunity was not taken. I hope the proposal will not be abandoned or forgotten by government and parliaments. I hope some day the wisdom of the proposal will be better considered without the degree of prejudice that unfortunately seemed to be attached to it.

Mr Storey presented that proposal. On behalf of the Government, the present Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, said that the Commonwealth Government was pleased to go along with those proposals that found favour with the Convention. In his speech at Brisbane he said:

As far as cross-vesting is concerned, the Commonwealth has made it clear that, provided the States are prepared to amend their legislation similarly, the Commonwealth will amend the Federal Court of Australia Act in order to prevent actions being brought before the Federal Court which ought more properly to be brought in State courts.

I am aware also that there are problems in what is called the trade practices jurisdiction, but I am advised that a legislative solution can be found to accommodate the particular problems that have arisen in that area.

That was a promising situation because we had wide agreement at the Convention and the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth was saying that he would proceed to implement the proposals. He certainly proceeded in that direction and, at the end of last year, the Bills now before us were introduced into the House of Representatives. Given the slowness with which things move in the legal area in Australia, it was not a bad performance to have it in the House within 12 months.

Unfortunately, the proposals fell very far short indeed of the concept and the detailed provisions of the recommendations of the committee of the Constitutional Convention to which I have referred. To quite a large extent, the legislation still falls short of those recommendations and, as I said, the recommendations themselves also fall short of the ideal that could have been achieved had there been bolder and more forward thinking. The real failing of the legislation is that it preserves the concept of exclusive jurisdiction in some areas for the Federal Court, which is quite contrary to the proposal for cross-vesting. It also goes a step further and removes from the State courts their exclusive and original jurisdiction in tax matters and at the time the Attorney-General introduced the legislation, also in intellectual and industrial property matters. Since then the Government has amended the legislation to bring the intellectual and industrial property jurisdiction into the cross-vesting system, and that is a considerable advance about which I am pleased. However, the Government has not seen fit to bring the tax jurisdiction into the scheme, as envisaged by the cross-vesting Bill. Indeed, it has gone one step further and removed from the State courts their jurisdiction to hear taxation matters and has given exclusive authority in taxation matters to the Federal Court.

That is the reason why the Opposition proposes to vote against the second Bill. Hopefully, the Government may think again and come up with a full cross-vesting scheme in relation to tax matters. We can achieve that in all other areas where exclusive jurisdiction is retained for the Federal Court. We can achieve that under the Trade Practices Act and other Acts by a simple amendment to the cross-vesting Bill, but it is not so simple to do that in respect of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.

The Government's argument for retaining exclusivity of jurisdiction in certain areas is hard to follow, particularly in the light of its support for the concept of cross-vesting which the Attorney-General gave at the convention in Brisbane. This scheme was supported by the chief justices of the States at the time. I have checked again and have found that they are still of the same view-that is, that it is desirable to have a full cross-vesting system. The Attorney seems to suggest that one reason why State chief justices would be happy to get rid of the tax jurisdiction was the great volume of tax cases that had suddenly flooded the State systems. However, from my discussions I believe that their real concern was that they were being asked to cope with all of the cases that are in the system without being able to rearrange their judges and their systems to cope on a permanent basis. That was pretty unreasonable.

Amendments to the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill 1987 provide for a complete or holus-bolus transfer of all existing tax cases to the Federal Court of Australia, as well as future cases that can only be exclusively commenced there. Compared with State supreme court judges, judges of the Federal Court do not have superior wisdom in tax matters. Obviously, there are horses for courses, so to speak. A number of judges in the State courts may not have had much experience of tax matters. Many judges do not have much experience of criminal matters before they become supreme court judges. Yet a lot of the work of supreme courts is in the criminal jurisdiction. Certainly there are some very fine judges in the Federal Court who do tax work and work in other specialised areas. But there is absolutely no reason why State judges who can handle a lot of other complicated legal matters should not be quite capable of handling these areas which are, according to this legislation, still kept exclusively within the Federal Court. I believe that the Government's proposals are a step backwards from the advances that were made after great effort at the Brisbane convention in 1985. As I have said, I would have hoped that the Brisbane convention might have gone further towards creating a unified court system in Australia. At least that objective should be achieved by this legislation and this Parliament at this time. It is disappointing to see the Government's proposals are a step backwards rather than a step forward from Brisbane where there was wide agreement.

For those reasons the Opposition supports this legislation in principle but it is disappointed with the restrictions that it contains on the cross-vesting principle. We believe there is no rational argument in support of that. We hope that if our amendments succeed, the Government will be induced to adopt a full cross-vesting system. But even if it does not happen, I must record the Opposition's support for the advances in that direction that are made in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the intro- duction of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill 1987 which should go some way towards freeing the Australian court system from jurisdictional disputes. The proposals should eliminate at least some of the problems which have arisen in the past involving the choice of the correct jurisdiction in which civil actions might be brought, particularly in relation to commerce and family law matters. Senator Durack referred to the Brisbane convention. Of course, there were some extensive discussions in the family law area at the Adelaide and Brisbane conventions. Up to now, choosing the wrong court has been very expensive to litigants both in terms of time and money. Despite that support, the Australian Democrats have some concerns about each of the Bills. I will look at these concerns in some detail at the Committee stage when we are discussing the clauses and the Opposition amendments which have been circulated in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, this scheme was arrived at after quite lengthy and detailed consultations between the Commonwealth, the States, the Northern Territory and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The rationale for the scheme, as finally devised, is sensible-that is, that the jurisdiction should be shared between the courts in our Federal system. The proposal involves the transfer of jurisdiction between Federal and State systems, between State and State and between Territory and Territory. Problems which have arisen in the past should be greatly simplified by the passage of this legislation and matching legislation in all States and Territories of the Commonwealth.

As Senator Durack pointed out, some matters will remain within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia. We will obviously deal with this issue in greater detail at the Committee stage. This proposal means that litigants will not be able to go forum shopping. By and large, the scheme will mean that justice will be administered, hopefully more quickly and efficiently, and some of the futile arguments about the particular jurisdiction in which a case should be heard will be avoided.

The legislation provides for the existence of specialist jurisdictions and the Opposition, through its amendments, will oppose this measure. The types of arguments outlined by Senator Durack certainly have merit. Indeed, there has been a great deal of argument leading up to this legislation. Honourable senators who have been involved have been inundated with representations and material.

In looking at the operation of the legislation overall, the Australian Democrats have decided that a case can be made out for the matters of particular significance to the Commonwealth which are to be treated in these Bills as special Federal matters. Before speaking further on that matter, let me say that while it is a great pity that the courts of this country have never been fully integrated, that is a fact of life which we cannot ignore. In terms of our attitude to the Bills, we are concerned to see that the best is made of this fact.

The relatively narrow range of matters defined as special Federal matters in the Bill are presently within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Court. The special role and expertise of that court is recognised in relation to matters that arise particularly under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act; under section 39b of the Judiciary Act under which writs or injunctions are sought against certain Commonwealth officers; under Part IV of the Trade Practices Act, except sections 45d and e which, obviously, will be debated in this chamber at some later stage; under section 32 of the National Crime Authority Act; and other matters as defined in clause 3 of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.

The body of expertise built up by courts with specialist jurisdictions means that these courts will be able to deal with cases within that jurisdiction more efficiently, more quickly and, hopefully, more cheaply than courts that do not have that expertise. As I have said, that argument will be dealt with at greater length when we debate clauses of the cross-vesting Bill. Before moving on to comment on the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, I want to raise some concerns that have been drawn to the attention of the Australian Democrats by the Law Reform Commission of Victoria.
