TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was making some comments on the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill 1987. I was about to draw the attention of the Senate to some concerns that have been raised by the Law Reform Commission of Victoria. Essentially, these concern the cross-vesting Bill, in particular clause 11 (1) (c) and clause 11 (1) (b). I raise these concerns in the hope that the Minister in summing up the second reading debate might be able to address those problems raised by the Law Reform Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern with clause 11 (1) (c) seems to be aimed at any possible difficulties that might arise, particularly under sections 79 and 80 of the Judiciary Act in cases where transfer is possible, and where different States have different statutes of limitations. It is not possible to say what the Government has considered or not considered in the run-up to this legislation. It may very well have looked at these particular problems. If so, I would be quite interested to hear any comments from the Minister. The Law Reform Commission has drawn attention, for example, to the vast and unstructured discretion granted by clause 11 (1) (c) to apply any rule of evidence or procedure anywhere in Australia. This could very well cause problems, possibly in terms of the way it might be done. Hopefully, we might be looking at the absolute minimum of expense in protracted litigation, which is after all the intent of the Bill. When one looks at the experience with respect to statutes of limitations under sections 79 and 80 of the Judiciary Act one is rather pessimistic that this might be the case. The concern with clause 11 (1) (b), however, is more substantial. The Law Reform Commission has raised this problem:

Its effect is that if the subject matter of the action arises under the written law of another State or Territory, the court must apply the written and the unwritten substantive law of the other State or Territory. The real source of the difficulty is that this clause requires the application of a choice of law rule which is different from that which would have been applied in a non cross-vested action. This may give rise to a different result entirely at the discretion of the plaintiff, because it is the plaintiff who chooses whether to commence in a court with ordinary jurisdiction over the matter or in a court whose jurisdiction is only a cross-vested one.

I will certainly be interested in the Minister's comments on that. I might need to return to that matter at the Committee stage. I would like now to turn to the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. In passing I note the regret of the Australian Democrats that there is not full integration. The Senate, of course, has already been appraised of some of the concerns, for example, of the Law Council of Australia, and I wish only to raise these arguments briefly. The Law Council of Australia has been quite active in making submissions on this matter. It is important to point out that the Council's most recent submission, that of 11 May, says basically that the legislation is commendable. That is the attitude that the Australian Democrats have taken; hence we will be supporting the legislation.

However, the Law Council goes on to raise essentially two other items. One is the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Court in tax appeals. The other concerns clause 7 (5) of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill. It maintains that it should be opposed on the grounds that it will have an adverse effect on the status of the Supreme Court. These items were raised previously in the debate by Senator Durack.

While in our deliberations we have taken full account of the concerns raised by the Law Council about these two Bills, particularly its weighty submission of a couple of weeks ago, we believe that it is far better to proceed with the Bills as they currently stand-at least we are moving somewhere. While obviously there will be hiccups along the way and while we may wish we had more, we are getting part of the way down the track. When one considers the rather tortuous history of this affair, one is rather loth to give up the chance of some movement in the hope of getting everything one was looking for. It is on that basis that we intend to support the legislation before us in its entirety, in the hope that further down the track future governments, whether of the persuasion of this Government or of the Opposition-I was heartened by Senator Durack's full support in this matter-will, in fact, take the steps necessary to enable this legislation to operate fully. Having sat through so many of these debates in the Constitutional Convention, I do not believe it is proper at this stage to tamper with something which actually has been agreed on widely across Australia by so many jurisdictions, although it might not be the optimum level that everybody might want or require.

I hope that the Minister will be able to refer to the points that have been raised by the Law Reform Commission of Victoria and the Law Council of Australia. I would also be interested in the Minister's comments on points which were raised by Senator Durack about the possible increased work load being transferred to the Federal Court by virtue of this legislation. Undoubtedly, the Government has taken this into consideration.

I would be interested in the Minister's response as to how the Federal Court will handle what could be a vastly increased work load, considering the work load carried by the Federal courts and the difficulty they currently have in completing their task in the timeframe that I think most people would think is reasonable. This is not a problem solely to do with the Federal courts, although this legislation is likely to compound Federal Court problems; it is also to do with State jurisdictions. One is reminded of the enormous problems encountered, for example, by the courts in New South Wales in dealing with matters in a time frame that seems to be reasonable. When one looks at a possible hearing of a case two or three years hence, one feels that justice could seem to be done in many of those cases in such a time frame. There is a fundamental principle of the ability to be able to get into the court as rapidly as is possible. But with all the good will in the world and with the case loads which are currently being experienced by so many judges, it is fairly obvious that that is not possible. Most governments are finding it very difficult to increase this capacity by increasing the number of judges and all the ancillary services which are necessary to allow those judges to meet. I think this will be an emerging problem in the more litigious society that Australia seems to be moving towards. But in this legislation I am interested particularly in the Federal Court of Australia and its work load.

Let me conclude by reiterating that the Democrats welcome these two pieces of legislation. I do not think the Government believes that they are perfect. The Australian Democrats certainly do not believe that they are perfect, but we believe that they go a considerable way towards obviating many of the jurisdictional problems that have arisen in the past in this country. Hopefully, they will set the pattern for further reform in this area in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) is eager to get to his feet to deal with the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill 1987 with his usual style, aplomb and gusto, so I will not speak for long. I wish simply to say a couple of things about this legislation before Senator Tate gets to his feet and outdoes any brilliance that I might show. I think these Bills are a great reform. Speakers have conceded that they are a reform but I do not think they have given them the praise that should be given them. These Bills are radical in the sense that they make available to litigants a much more sensible system than has hitherto been available to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who have already spoken in the debate have mentioned the effects on the status of courts and the niceties that must be preserved by members of the legal profession. This legislation has turned itself not so much to that question but to the question of what litigants are entitled to have when they go before the courts of this country-and it is becoming more and more a matter of this country rather than a matter of separate States. With the increase of trade across the borders, with the increase in our means of transport, with planes getting faster and faster and with telexes being replaced by facsimile machines and so on, business, social intercourse and relations generally between people are conducted not so much on a State basis but very much on an Australia-wide basis. It is appropriate in those circumstances that all the courts in the land, whether they be set up by a Federal system or a State system, be available to all litigants.

I notice that Dr Gavan Griffiths, QC, the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, is sitting behind me in the chamber. I understand that he has had much to do with the initiatives that have been taken in this legislation and I think he, together with those who have fallen behind him, deserve congratulations for bringing this legislation before the Parliament. Not only has he received the praise-perhaps muted-of all parties in this Parliament but also he has obtained consent and agreement and an enthusiastic response from all the States to making courts available to litigants no matter in which State they are situated. I think that is a great reform. Indeed, as we look through the history of law we note the introduction of merchant law, which has become part of our legal system and which everybody now presumes has always been there. It makes the law much more sensible than it would otherwise have been. I do not think it would be too much to say that this legislation fits in with that grand tradition.

Some points have been raised and some adverse opinions have been given about this legislation. Senator Macklin mentioned the Law Reform Commission of Victoria. As I understand it, if he has the same letter as I have, it is not so much the Law Reform Commission of Victoria but David Kelly, the chairperson of a committee, who has properly raised matters which he has discussed with Matthew Goode of the Adelaide Law School.

It seems that there may be some misconception of what this legislation is all about. Perhaps I ought to explain it to those people who might be listening. This legislation sets out to exchange Commonwealth and State jurisdictions so that Commonwealth courts will now be able to exercise State jurisdictions, except in certain matters. Not only will State courts be able to exercise Federal jurisdiction but also each State court will be able to exercise the jurisdiction of other States. This means that a litigant can go into any State court and that the judge who is seeing to the matter can listen to the propositions that are put before him by the litigant and then make a decision. If the judge thinks that it is appropriate for a litigant to go elsewhere and for a matter to be heard in some other State or in a Federal court, subject to some qualifications the judge can send the matter there. In those circumstances it seems that David Kelly and Mr Goode have perhaps not properly appreciated that that service to the litigant will make things much easier, more understandable and more appropriate than was previously the case.

Honourable senators have also raised the question of the plaintiff choosing the forum. I would have thought that the whole legal system was based on the plaintiff choosing where he or she goes. Whether a matter goes to a county court, a supreme court or wherever, the plaintiff always initiates the litigation. If the plaintiff wants to initiate the litigation not only in a particular court within a State but also in some other court or in a Federal court, how unusual is that? As was the case before this legislation was introduced, if a court thinks that a matter is not properly raised in that court, the plaintiff can be sent off somewhere else. It seems to me that honourable senators are clutching at straws when they raise this question of the plaintiff being able, solely as a result of this legislation, to choose the jurisdiction. It seems to me to be a misunderstanding of the situation that has existed until now.

The question of tax appeals has been raised. It has been said that the supreme courts ought to have a right to hear tax cases, as if that were the be all and the end all of litigation-that somehow the standing of supreme courts would be lowered simply because they did not hear tax cases. The situation at present is that people can take their tax appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or to a supreme court, but in either case the appeals ends up in the Federal Court of Australia for hearing. As has been said, instead of going the dog-leg way from the Supreme Court to the Federal Court, why should litigants not go through the State system to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and then on to the Federal Court, which is a much more direct approach?

The question of the status of the supreme courts has been raised. The reality is that the supreme courts of the States will not have any of their existing jurisdictions changed much at all. In each State the Supreme Court will be the highest court. There is no attempt in this legislation to lessen the dignity of the supreme courts in any way. If anything, it gives them a greater status because they will be able to exercise not only their own jurisdiction but also the jurisdiction of the courts of every other State. They will also be able to exercise the jurisdiction of the Federal Court, except in certain matters. One of those matters relates to sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, about which we might hear some more in this place. I think that is appropriate enough. I cannot resist going on to the topic of sections 45d and 45e at this stage, as they are matters which are presently placed in a commercial setting by the Trade Practices Act. In my view, when they are used in the industrial relations field they should be properly placed in that field. Perhaps I have deviated a little from the proper path.

The Law Reform Commission of Victoria, of which Senator Macklin spoke, certainly does not express the view of the Attorney-General of that State. Mr Kennan, perhaps one of the great Attorneys-General in the history of this country, is very much behind the system set up in this legislation. Perhaps I could quote from a letter from Mr Teague, a former President of the Law Institute of Victoria. This letter was written in April. Mr Teague has been twice President of the Institute. He is an outstanding solicitor. I emphasise that it is very rare for people to be twice elected as President of that society. Senator Tate will be interested in what Mr Teague said:
I write on behalf of the Institute to express the support of the Institute-
that famous Law Institute of Victoria, on which the patina of glory glows-
. . . for the scheme of legislation contained in the above Bill to which you spoke in the House of Representatives on 22 October 1986.

He was writing to the Attorney-General. Perhaps the only thing that he could have added to that would be `about which you spoke so well'. Senator Tate is about to speak in the same sort of mode. Mr Teague continued:

The Institute has been a supporter of the principle of granting to the States the jurisdiction to hear Federal matters particularly when the monetary value of those matters does not justify the cost of proceedings within the Federal Courts.
Perhaps I could skip a bit. He raised the matter of clause 5 (8), which I think Senator Macklin criticised. Mr Teague continued:

Clause 5 (8) of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross Vesting) Bill provides for a temporary entitlement of a Barrister and Solicitor to practise in the jurisdiction of another State if an action in which he is involved is transferred and the amendments proposed to be moved by the Government shall have the effect of avoiding problems in the case of a series of actions.

He means that if somebody briefs a barrister and instructs a solicitor in South Australia and the case has to be removed to some other State, such as New South Wales, that person will be able to take with him the solicitor he has instructed and the barrister he has briefed so that the people representing him, seized of the matter right from the start, can follow it through. As things now stand, if a person starts a matter in South Australia and then has to take it to New South Wales, he has to brief a barrister who is admitted in New South Wales. The whole thing is very clumsy. Indeed, Mr Teague puts the following logical idea:

In the Institute's view there is no sound reason why a national scheme of complementary legislation ought not provide at this point for a Barrister and Solicitor of one Court to be automatically admitted to practise as a Barrister and Solicitor of any other Court in another State or Territory or in the Federal sphere.

I hope it is not suggested that a barrister or solicitor found competent in one State should not be allowed to practise in another. There is only one State which would take that view, and that is Queensland. I hope that there is no resistance to this Bill from the Law Council of Australia on that basis. Some suggestions have been made that the matter ought to be held up but that is certainly not the sort of basis on which to hold up a Bill that enables people to litigate and gives them the access to the courts of this land to which they should be entitled.

Senator Macklin talked about delays in the law-and this legislation certainly will help resolve that problem-as if they were something new. Charles Dickens talked about delays in the law in Bleak House. Since then there have been a series of law reforms, such as the Judiciary Act and others, which have tended to speed up matters. Here is the next reform in that grand tradition. But Senator Macklin says: `No, this will delay the law'. That is absolutely wrong. What has happened to some extent is that Senator Macklin has been affected-and properly so because he is a man of great compassion-by the various letters that have been sent to him which have raised problems about this great Bill and which have erected windmills in his mind at which he tilts. I assure him that this legislation is another step in the long line of reform so that no matter what State or court one stands outside one can go in and get some sort of relief. Until now people have stood outside courts saying: `Should I go in there?'; `Is this the place to litigate?'; `Is this the court I should go to to get access to my child?'; and `Is this the court I should go to to get a property settlement?'. If a person enters the trap and it is the wrong court he is milked for costs and is sent out again. This way the person can go into a court with assurance that he can litigate properly. It is very imaginative and great legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the result of the Government, though.

—We on this side of the House are the sort of people who do not look at matters in those terms. We do not care whether the legislation comes from this Government. We say that this is very effective legislation which has been introduced into this chamber and which has been accepted on the other side, although perhaps a little grudgingly. The Australian Democrats also accept it, but a little less grudgingly. We on this side accept it with full heart and without any grudge at all. Given that scenario we simply say that that is our position. If the legislation is not due to us, at least we are the ones who have embraced it with such enthusiasm-the enthusiasm that it deserves.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate not only the Federal Government but the various State governments right around Australia which have come together to bring this idea to fruition. I again congratulate the Solicitor-General who, as I say, has worked tirelessly together with other legal bodies. We have legislation that will go well. Before I conclude I should say two other things. First, there is a three-year sunset clause so if this legislation does go wrong-which is very much against my expectations-at the end of the three years something can be done about it. Secondly, there is a committee of chief justices and chief judges to monitor the operation and balance the various interests around the courts and between the States and the Federal body. So this legislation hopefully will be passed tonight. It will make litigation a happier-if we can call any litigation happy-more pleasant, faster and less stressful venture into the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be very mundane compared with those of my colleague Senator Cooney, who preceded me. The Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill are very important pieces of legislation. I thank the honourable senators who contributed to the second reading debate. One need think of only a few instances for it readily to come to mind why such legislation is required. When the property market on the Gold Coast collapsed a few years ago, people tried to avoid their contracts for the purchase of home units and so on. The vendors went to the Supreme Court of Queensland to get specific performance of the contracts whereas the purchasers went into the Federal jurisdiction, trying to avoid the contract and claiming misrepresentations under the Trade Practices Act. That sort of conflict between the jurisdiction in which the purchasers and vendors tried to assert their rights in relation to the contracts is just one example that comes to mind quite readily.

SPEECH.PARA: The other case which caused greater anguish and was a cause, I think, of much of the political momentum initially for this project occurred within families where on the dissolution of a marriage the Family Court of Australia could deal with the children of the marriage but not with ex-nuptial children. In that situation there was more trauma and anguish for the households which already have enough problems without having to go to different jurisdictions to try to resolve the matter. So with those two very homey instances, I simply illustrate the fact that this legislation is so complex that at times it sounds as though it is concerned with only asserting the jurisdiction of courts. Because we are subjected to so much lobbying by groups of legal luminaries, it may sound as though it is a fairly esoteric matter. It is not. It is a matter with very practical consequences for us as we, as Australians, try to assert our rights and conduct ourselves in accordance with legal principles, wherever we may happen to be, by geographic happenstance.

This package of legislation, as has been commented on by other speakers, comes into this chamber after a very long history. It may be that perhaps Senator Durack more than most, but certainly Senator Macklin who was on the Constitutional Convention sub-committee which dealt with these matters, will be more aware than I as to the complexities of the negotiations that occurred between politicians in that instance trying to find a way through the complexities brought about by the fact that in our creation as a nation we were dependent on that initial framework of separate colonies which spread throughout this continent. As politicians we try to come to grips with that. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General-known as SCAGS-tried to refine the proposals that came partly from consideration by the Constitutional Convention sub-committee, and the result is what I believe to be a balanced and workable-if not perfect-scheme. I think it is important to note that on 5 March 1987 in Adelaide members of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General reaffirmed their full support for the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they passed any legislation yet?

—Perhaps they are dependent on seeing whether some of the forces of reaction that occasionally stalk the corridors of this place stymie our efforts here in this chamber. I am sure that the State and Northern Territory Attorneys-General, having given their imprimatur to this package of legislation, will come up with the complementary legislation and arrangements that are required. Therefore, this legislation is not something which the present Federal Government necessarily claims as its own. Nevertheless, it does take responsibility and some pride in the fact that at last there has been brought into this Parliament legislation which helps to deal with a problem which all have recognised particularly and acutely over the past few years.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to one or two matters which may come up again during the Committee stage. The tax jurisdiction has been particularly placed in the Federal jurisdiction and there has been some complaint that this has stripped the State supreme courts of some element of their work. I think it is important to recall that taxation board of review functions have been transferred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from which an appeal lies on a question of law to the Federal Court. As a result, the right of appeal from the Commissioner of Taxation to a supreme court is now something of an anomaly when we look at it in that context and in the context that the full Federal Court has exercised appellate functions for appeals from decisions of supreme courts since 1977. It must be recalled also that State full courts have no jurisdiction in taxation appeals, nor do State courts now hear appeals from boards of review. So in some of these matters it is quite clear that the movement to an exclusive Federal jurisdiction in relation to tax matters makes a lot of sense. I could give more instances of why that should be so.

Senator Macklin I think, and perhaps Senator Durack, also raised the question of the anticipated work load that would be placed on the Federal Court and whether it would be able to deal with the backlog of tax cases any more quickly than perhaps would the supreme court system. We believe, and I am advised, that the Federal Court's capacity to deal with lists more quickly than some supreme courts has been publicly recognised. We believe that the Commonwealth can respond to any work load in the Federal Court fairly readily. But I think it has to be noted that the backlog transferred to the Federal Court jurisdiction by the transitional provisions of tax matters comes about really as the result of a request. The Commonwealth was asked to transfer the backlog because of the concern in some States as to the very large number of taxation cases pending before State courts, and there was a recognition of the strain placed on those courts as a result. Once again SCAGS at its meeting fully agreed to this transfer.

It may be also not well known to Senator Macklin as a matter of fact that, for example, the Victorian Supreme Court has not held a taxation callover since September 1986. So no new cases are being set for hearing in that jurisdiction. In New South Wales, with one exception, no new matters have been given hearing dates since 1 January 1987. So the State supreme courts themselves are not trying to deal with new cases and I think that they will be very pleased to see the transfer that I speak about. I think Senator Cooney dealt very adequately with the problems raised with clause 11 by Messrs Kelly and Goode in their submission. I do not know whether Senator Macklin requires me to reiterate those points.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—The honourable senator says no. Therefore, with that matter put to one side, I again thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this debate and seek the support of the chamber for the second reading.
—I believe it would suit the Senate if we dealt with the two Bills separately. I put the question: That the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in the second reading debate, the Opposition proposes to move a number of amendments to this Bill in order to put into place a true cross-vesting regime. In an ideal world the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill 1987 should have been presented together because there are restrictions on cross-vesting in each of them. The House of Representatives dealt with them in a more logical order by having this Bill dealt with before the other one. For some reason which is unknown to me but which may be explicable they are being dealt with in this order here. As I foreshadowed, the Opposition wishes to move some amendments to this Bill to give effect to that full cross-vesting regime. I do not need to go over that ground again. The five amendments which the Opposition will move all deal with that matter. I seek leave to move them together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 2 and 3, subclause 3 (1), definition of ``special federal matter'', leave out the definition.
Pages 7 to 9, clause 6 leave out the clause.
Pages 9 and 10, clause 7, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``7. An appeal from a decision of a court shall only be instituted and heard in accordance with the appeal provisions which normally apply to that court.''.
Page 11, paragraph 10 (c), lines 15 and 16, leave out the paragraph.
Page 14, Schedule, leave out the Schedule.

The Opposition opposed the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill because it was designed solely to preserve exclusivity of jurisdiction in the Federal Court of Australia although, as I said, it had some other minor features in it which transferred jurisdiction to a State court. The overwhelming reason for it was to transfer exclusive jurisdiction to the Federal Court from the State courts. This is the Bill which gives effect to the principle of cross-vesting. We support that main purpose of the Bill. However, it qualifies that principle in quite a substantial way by introducing the concept of special Federal matters. They are set out in the interpretation. They preserve as the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Court matters arising under Part IV of the Trade Practices Act, the part of the Act which deals with the classic restrictive trade practices. That has traditionally been dealt with in the Federal Court. From our point of view there seems no sound reason why judges dealing with commercial matters in State Supreme Courts would not be perfectly capable of handling these matters. The judges who would be dealing with those matters in the State Supreme Courts would almost certainly, as counsel, have had great experience under the jurisdiction of the Trade Practices Act. It is quite arrogant of the Federal Government and this Parliament to assume that only Federal Court judges would have the capacity to handle these matters. It is totally arrogant, totally unnecessary and totally wrong. So it goes on.

I have already dealt with the reasons why the Opposition opposes the view that the Federal Court judges should have a monopoly over tax matters. Exactly the same argument applies. We have dealt with that, and I do not want to go over it again. Suffice it to say that this Bill, in the clauses that we are seeking to change, qualifies the very sound principle of cross-vesting of jurisdiction, which is the purpose of this package of legislation, in quite a considerable way and to some extent certainly destroys its basic purpose. So the amendments we are proposing to this Bill are designed to remove those qualifications. There are some other matters I want to raise that are not the subject of amendment, and they can be dealt with separately. These amendments simply give expression to the views of the Opposition which I have already dealt with at length in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the matters raised by Senator Durack, although the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill goes a long way towards cross-vesting, it does leave some matters exclusively within the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia. That is understandable, because the matters that are contained within that jurisdiction are matters which, as I have said and as Senator Durack acknowledged, already fall within that exclusive jurisdiction because they have a very clear relationship to that jurisdiction, and it is thought sensible to maintain that expertise which has been built up in relation to matters involving the review of decisions or the hearing of appeals from decisions of Commonwealth officials or restrictive trade practices matters which are obviously of particular concern to the Commonwealth officials or restrictive trade practices matters which are obviously of particular concern to the Commonwealth. It is thought important that the acknowledged expertise be maintained by dealing with these matters by the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I think it is probably too late in the day to try to unscramble this in a way that is satisfactory to the Opposition, nor do we intend to try to do so. The fact is that this has been the subject of prolonged negotiation and has been agreed to by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and affirmed again on 5 March in Adelaide. It required some delicate negotiations, and of course there are jealousies and misgivings, no doubt some protection of turf, and the erection of barriers both within the Federal Court and on the part of some of the Supreme Court judges who naturally would like to so some of this work. But a compromise-a balance-has been reached which is acceptable to the Attorneys-General from right around Australia, and this Bill tries to incorporate that final agreement.

The proof of the pudding which I think Senator Durack was looking for in a question to me a little earlier was extent to which those State Attorneys-General were prepared themselves to come up with legislation which would be complementary to this project that we are engaged in this evening. I am informed that Victoria has already passed legislation which will be its complementary statutory framework for this cross-vesting of jurisdiction, and that in New South Wales the legislation is in the House of Assembly, so already there is movement is those State jurisdictions, which indicates that we can fairly safely assume that, should the Senate be so minded and this legislation is passed and receives the assent of the Governor-General shortly, all those jurisdictions that are interested in this matter will have passed legislation which will make it as workable as we could hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin raised a question in the second reading debate, but I did not hear the conclusion of his speech, and I am not aware whether it was answered. I also have received a letter from Mr Kelly, the Chairman of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria, about clause 11 (1) (b) of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Bill, which is a more detailed version of the clause that was contained in the Bill that was introduced in the House of Representatives in the first place. It deals with how one chooses laws to be applied in a situation where a cross-vesting occurs-in other words, where a matter is transferred from, say, a State court to a Federal court or vice versa, or between State courts for that matter. The original version of it seemed to be a simple and practicable way of dealing with it, but it seems to be the case that the Commonwealth draftsmen think of more subtle or more complicated ways of doing things, and the present version raises a rather odd concept, as I understand it, of the difference between written and unwritten substantive law. Certainly Senator Macklin drew the Government's attention to this matter but I do not think we have received any answer to it. The memo sent to me by Mr Kelly of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria states:

SPEECH.PARA: The real trouble maker is Clause 11 (1) (b). Its effect is that, if the subject matter of the action arises under the written law of another State or Territory, the court must apply the written and the unwritten substantive law of the other State or Territory.
That is even though the action arises under the written law. It is a very odd sort of provision. The letter continues:

The real source of the difficulty is that this clause requires the application of a choice of law rule which is different from that which would have been applied in a non cross-vested action. It is a highly technical subject. It was not in the original Bill; it has been introduced now into this legislation. Mr Kelly seems to raise a matter of some obvious concern, and I should like to know what the Government's explanation is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say firstly that I did reply to Senator Macklin, but it was by way of asking whether he was satisfied with the response which Senator--
—You dealt with another subject altogether.

—No, I asked him whether he was satisfied with the response on clause 11 which Senator Cooney had put forward, and he indicated that he was. However, I am quite willing to repeat the advice I have in relation to the matters raised by Messrs Kelly and Goode, because they need to be set at rest. Generally speaking, the objections are thought to be misconceived in these ways: First, it is thought that Kelly and Goode do not seem to have understood completely that the courts of a State or Territory will have cross-vested jurisdiction from every other State and Territory. Accordingly, in their example one-and they were kind enough to particularise and try to make concrete their particular concerns-for instance, the South Australian Supreme Court would have both its ordinary jurisdiction, in which case the action based on the Victorian Act would fail, and cross-vested Victorian jurisdiction, in which the plaintiff would succeed, as would happen also in the Federal Court of Australia. SPEECH.PARA: As far as example three is concerned-and I think this is the one Senator Durack was concentrating on-although the example itself seems correct, it does not seem to involve any undesirable results as asserted in the comments in the memorandum.
