SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Health Bill and the National Health Amendment Bill reflect the sort of chaos that the Government has now imposed, through its policies, on the health area. The first Bill seeks to establish the Australian Institute of Health as a statutory body. This is a totally unnecessary proposal and the Opposition sees no merit in creating such a body. The reality is that there is no need for yet another statutory body to be created by this Government in addition to the great mound of statutory bodies which exist, frankly, to harass the Australian public. It is intriguing that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in the House of Representatives on 19 March, in dealing with the Australian Institute of Health Bill and responding to our objections, said that a whole range of reports over the last decade recommended an independent body to carry out the collection of the data required by this Institute.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the Institute would include collection, analysis and dissemination of health related information and statistics and the conduct and promotion of research into health services. The Institute would consist of 13 members including the Chairman, the Director, the Australian Statistician and the Secretary of the Department or their nominees. The Government claims that there will be no financial impact on either government expenditure or private industry. The Institute, in fact, is not a new body as it already exists in one form or another within the Department of Health. Our view, of course, is that it should be made to work within the Department rather than the people of Australia being burdened with another body with no foreseeable or evident benefit. There is a need for better performance in the area of health statistics, and I think we all agree about that. In comparison with other countries our health survey performance ranks just about in the middle of the range, but we rank second last in gathering usable statistics and last in gathering information about our hospitals. The Australian Institute of Health was established to provide a central health data service. It has not performed and it should be made to perform.

What is intriguing about the Minister's second reading comments in the other place was that he claimed that a report by Professor Kerr White made it quite explicit that the statistical collection should be done by a statutory authority. He attacked the concept that a statutory authority was not necessary. I have to concede that, on the point of statistical analysis, the Minister is quite right. The statistical analysis is appalling, as is evident from his own statements and from those of such senators as Senator Crowley in this place last week and Senator Coates, who misused and misquoted statistics and misled this Senate in a totally disgraceful way, simply because there is not a body which has been effectively preparing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I object to the honourable senator's suggestion that I have misled the Senate. I would like him to withdraw that remark.
—Senator Crowley, if after Senator Baume's speech you claim to have been misrepresented you can then put your point of view.

—As I was saying, the Senate has been misled by statistics which have been misused, simply because there is no appropriate or effective statistical service provided on health, which leaves the Government the opportunity to seek deliberately to mislead the Parliament and the people on the reality, for example, of the increased utilisation per person of medical services as a direct result of bulk billing and Medicare. I quote from the Minister's statement of 13 April. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has loosely based this claim-
that is, that bulk billing has led to increased utilisation-
on the false assertion that Medicare, and in particular bulk billing, has resulted in an increase in the average number of services received by the enrolled population.
He went on:
In fact in the 1983 calendar year-
that is, the last full year of the fifth Fraser scheme-
the enrolled population-
I emphasise the word `enrolled'-
received an average of 7.70 medical services.
He said further:
In the last calendar year-1986-they received 7.68 services.

I draw the Senate's attention to the word `enrolled', because that is where the mischievous misleading takes place. In reality, of course, out of the total population in 1983 the services used were about 6.25 and they have increased to 7.70. It would be unreasonable to compare those two figures because in fact 1.8 million people were excluded in 1983. But, for the benefit of Senator Crowley, not all of that 1.8 million were in fact excluded because they were large users. On the contrary, they had excluded themselves because many of them were fit and did not want to take insurance for the very reason that taking insurance was actuarially a bad proposition for them because they did not want to have to subsidise through the funds the health users who would have a much higher rate of utilisation of health services. Those younger healthier people would then have been subsidising other users. They preferred to take the tax benefit as a result of paying their medical fees. The point emerges here quite clearly: It is totally phoney for the Government or any Government senator to pretend that utilisation has not increased when in fact in every instance one can see that it has. In the Budget of 1986-87, for example, and in every Budget in every year since the Government came to office it has admitted that utilisation has increased. If utilisation has increased every year, how is it possible that Senator Crowley can pretend that her figures, which show that utilisation has fallen over three years, have any credibility? It is absolute bunkum. It is simply self-evidently false. Senator Crowley, by that inane grin on her face, is recognising that she cannot possibly defend this proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point or order. I call for the withdrawal of the remark `inane grin'. A person may have a grin on one's face, but to call it inane is, I think, just going over the edge and becoming offensive.

—I happily withdraw the word `inane' and replace it with `embarrassed'. Let us look at the facts for 1986-87. The Budget said in the second dot point that the reason for the increase on the 1985-86 expenditure was the expected growth of 7 per cent in one year in the utilisation of services. In the special appropriations for the Department of Health, one sees that further utilisation rises by quite an amount. For increased utilisation, population and free drift-a mixture of things-there is $208m extra. So increased utilisation in the latest year is clearly a significant factor.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the previous year? We hear this bunkum about the utilisation having fallen since Medicare and bulk billing came in. In the 1985-86 Budget, one sees exactly the same thing-increased utilisation. In the special appropriations I notice changes to population utilisation. If they had applied for the full year 1984-85, something like $4.2m would have been involved, and on page 118 of the Budget itself we have expected growth in the utilisation of services in 1985-86 of $121m.

Here we have in every year growth of utilisation, yet the Government still claims by the phoney use of phoney figures that utilisation has in fact fallen. How can it have fallen when every year it is demonstrated by the official Budget statistics to have increased? This underlines the real reason why we must have better health statistics-so that the Government will stop trying to fool the people of Australia. I certainly favour the creation of such a body. The question is whether it should be another statutory body, and of course there is no justification for that at all.

The Minister quite misleadingly suggests that the great body of opinion is that it should be so. He says, for example, that a study of health in Australia undertaken by Professor Kerr White made it quite explicit that the statistical collection should be undertaken by a statutory authority. I have had a look at that report, which says that the recommendations of the Australian Institute of Health:

. . . should be strengthened by giving it a more clearly defined role as the substantial policy analysis and `intelligence' group working directly for the Minister and Secretary and reporting to the latter or the Deputy Secretary. It should have a Director and staff of perhaps 6 to 8 professionals with appropriate support personnel. The Minister and the Secretary, together with the Director, should set the AIH's agenda.

No suggestion is made there of a statutory body. The Minister then says that a National Centre for Health Statistics together with a National Advisory Committee on Health and Vital Statistics should be established by legislation. `By legislation' is the only straw at which the Minister is clutching to justify the suggestion that this should be a statutory body. There is no evidence within the report to justify or support that proposition or to assert that this should be anything more than a committee.

Let us look at all the other reports that have recommended such a body. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts said that there was a lack of adequate objective advice on economic aspects of the health industry. At paragraph 9.28 it reported:

The Director-General of Health stated that there was no specific division or unit within the Department of Health which has provided specialised economic advice . . . the Department of Health should be serviced by a specialised group of economists and other relevant disciplines, advising on economic matters associated with the health industry.
Nothing there says that it should be a statutory body. The Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, in its report of December 1980, recommended:
A Bureau of Health Economics as proposed by the Commonwealth Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1979 be established.

There is nothing there about a statutory body. In 1979 the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare recommended that the Commonwealth Government direct the Australian Bureau of Statistics to raise to an appropriate level the proportion of its budget spent specifically on health and welfare statistics. That in fact leads us in the right direction. Why have we not simply got a situation where the Commonwealth Statistician is used as effectively as he can and should be used for this purpose? We have no explanation whatsoever from the Government as to why the Australian Bureau of Statistics is not an appropriate body to collect this information. The Minister says that it is important that this collection be carried out, and I quote him:

We have endeavoured to carry out the task of a national collection of health data in this country through the Department of Health . . . it is not possible to do this through that method . . . First of all, we are very dependent on State governments for the basic health statistics because they are the deliverers of health services. They have made it perfectly clear that unless we have a body divorced from the Commonwealth Department of Health-separate, independent and not under that Commonwealth department-we will not gain State confidence to provide statistics.

What is wrong with the Australian Bureau of Statistics? It is created for that purpose. It is nonsense to say that the only way to solve the problem is to go down the track that the Government has followed of creating yet another statutory body. The Minister was frank enough to admit that there have often been adverse relations between the Commonwealth Department of Health and the State departments. He said:
States are willing under the . . . arrangements that we have reached with them, to pass that information on through a separate statutory authority.

He makes no comment on whether the Australian Bureau of Statistics should be that statutory authority. The Minister goes on in a quite insulting way about the Australian Bureau of Statistics, by inference, because he says:
. . . we need top class people with top class research backgrounds. In other words, they apparently are not available elsewhere.
He continues:
It is much more difficult to attract them into a health department, into a sort of basic Public Service operation, than it will be into an independent statutory authority.

Is he saying that the Australian Bureau of Statistics people are not good enough? There is no discussion here of what is clearly the relevant issue when we are discussing whether it is important to create a separate statutory body. There is no discussion whatsoever by this arrogant Government and this arrogant Minister of the reality of the recommendation made and advice given by other bodies over the years that this function could and should be carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Perhaps the Minister in this place will be kind enough to respond in a way that the Minister in the other place found beyond him.

I now come to the second part of this package, the National Health Amendment Bill. This involves, I suppose, to use the word in its real sense, a scandalous situation in which the Auditor-General has demonstrated that the Department and the Minister have broken the law. The purpose of the amendment is to correct retrospectively that law breaking. The Opposition will of necessity support the Bill, but we point out that it is simply another fix that ignores the basic problems. The Bill attempts to patch up the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by changing the law so that chemists will be able to be paid without the Government continuing to break the law. The Auditor-General in his report in March on audits to 31 December 1986, said that staff resources at Pharmpay processing centres had been insufficient to process all prescriptions lodged by pharmacists. In March 1985 the Department of Health sought comments on a proposal from the Department of Finance that the processing of the backlog of prescriptions on hand should be overcome by making advance payments prior to the verification of the entitlement to those payments. The report states:

Finance raised no in principle objection and noted that such payment should be subject to Ministerial determination . . . It suggested, however, that Attorney-General's Department advice be sought on the drafting of the proposal to be put to pharmacists. In the event, the Department of Health did not seek such advice.

Why did not the Department of Health or the Minister find out whether what he was going to do was illegal? We do not know; we have not been told why that matter was not pursued. What we do know is that the advance payments commenced in May 1985. By November 1986, advance payments for a total of 67.4 million prescriptions had been made to pharmacists but I emphasise that the unprocessed backlog of prescriptions peaked at 61.3 million during that month. That is the mess that this Government, this Department and this Minister got this scheme into. What is the excuse, the justification? It was primarily because of repetition strain injury to keyboard operators. That is how the Department got 61.3 million prescriptions behind by November 1986, and that is after illegally paying 67.4 million prescriptions in advance. The Auditor-General's report continues:

During discussions with the Department over settling the backlog of pharmaceutical claims, Audit suggested that legal advice be obtained of ways of ensuring the validity of the proposed basis of settlement. The resultant legal advice-
that is, at the end of 1986-

from the Attorney-General's Department stated that the advance payments were not authorised by the National Health Act. In particular . . . the Act does not authorise the making of payments; it only allows the Minister to determine conditions subject to which payments otherwise authorised by the Act can be made. The Department has advised that, on receipt of the legal advice, advance payments were suspended immediately, and action has been taken to seek amendment of the National Health Act.

That is why this legislation is now before us. The Department and the Government were acting illegally largely because the Department did not get the advice of the Attorney-General's Department at the time the Department of Finance suggested that it should. On 13 February 1987 the Minister wrote to pharmacists offering to settle claims which had been paid in advance but which had not been fully processed. The offer provided for a pharmacist to receive an adjustment to bring claims previously paid in advance to a level calculated by a consultant as being due. In addition, a once only payment of 10c per prescription item would be made to compensate for any inaccuracies in the initial payment. It is estimated that adjustment payments will be approximately $7m and the once only payment will be about $6m.

The Auditor-General commented that the effect of the legal advice that the payments were not authorised by the National Health Act is that all of the PBS advance payments had been made without appropriation in contravention of section 83 of the Constitution which states:
No money shall be drawn from the Treasury of the Commonwealth except under appropriation made by law.

Audit sought information from the Department to quantify the total amount paid without appropriation. In response, the Department advised that it did not have the statistics currently available on the amount of advance payments made. However, it estimated that at November 1986 the amount unadjusted by subsequent reprocessing was of the order of $300m illegally paid.

Clearly, we have what could at best be described as a curious situation which, naturally, needs serious attention. I would suggest that it is part of a whole pattern of disaster within the health policies of this Government. We have this sort of backlog and illegal behaviour allegedly because of a lack of personnel but basically because of the impact of RSI. Yet in May 1986 nearly 700 staff comprised the body which administers the Pharmpay system-organisation which is costing the taxpayers of Australia in excess of $18m a year to mess up the system. As I have said, it has been a total disaster, an absolute disgrace which we now have to have to pass this legislation to fix up.

Clause 3 of the Bill redefines the table of benefits so that when samples are taken from a patient during a stay in hospital, pathology tests performed after the patient is discharged can be considered as an inpatient professional service for the purpose of private hospital insurance benefits. Such tests will be covered by the limited gap insurance arrangements applicable to such charges raised through a hospital stay and, of course, the Opposition supports that change. However, we want to know why the Government has not taken this opportunity to address the problem it has created with all medical services by its aggressive bulk billing

As we know from the genuine statistics which involve annual increases in the utilisation of medical services since Medicare was introduced, there is certainly a problem. It is intriguing that this Government puts out statements about utilisation having fallen and calls on various reports and so on as evidence. But when one looks into the reports, one finds that this is simply not so. Let me quote two studies which reveal increased utilisation under Medicare. A Macquarie University study, which is often quoted as being in support of bulk billing, in fact admits that there is `increased use of services per patient induced by bulk billing'. That Macquarie University report points out, however, that because bulk billing is at a lower unit price than non-bulk billing, the total cost to the society, to the nation as a whole, is not adversely affected by this increased use of services per patient. The reality is that the burden is transferred on to the taxpayer. The clear consequence of that Macquarie report is that the taxpayer is picking up a bigger bill because of bulk billing.

The annual report of the Health Insurance Commission quite clearly demonstrates some more statistics which I hope Senator Crowley will look at with perhaps greater impartiality, energy and enthusiasm in her search for the truth than she did when she took the Minister's figures as gospel. The Health Insurance Commission statistics show that medical practitioners who bulk billed between 95 and 99 per cent of their services last year had an average number of services of 7,428 compared with only 4,698 services on average for those practitioners who bulk billed between only one per cent and 25 per cent of their services. That is not conclusive but it is very persuasive when one looks at the enormous difference between the rates of utilisation from those doctors who almost entirely bulk bill and those who bulk bill only a little.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of those are specialists who take longer in their consultations. That is the problem.

—Many reasons may well be involved. As I have said, those figures are not conclusive but if one goes up the spectrum-the group aged between 25 and 50 years and the group aged between 50 and 75 years-one sees that the utilisation clearly increases.

SPEECH.PARA: The second and main issue addressed by the Bill is the revision of certain administrative procedures of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I addressed parts of this issue before. This scheme was changed last year and under the new safety net program the chronically ill, whose financial burden without the pharmaceutical benefits scheme would be a hardship, are now protected by a maximum contribution for their first 25 prescriptions, after which a supply of all drugs on the PBS will be free of charge. The Opposition supported the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme last year as the changes were in line with Opposition policy. We promised that we would carefully monitor the implementation of these changes. Regrettably, as I indicated, the introduction of the scheme has been yet another disaster. Patients and pharmacists were given little or no notice of the changes made to the PBS and the Government was forced, at great expense, to airfreight the relevant documentation to pharmacists even though it took months to organise the scheme. It is yet another example of gross administrative incompetence by this Government. The current Pharmpay scheme fails every test of efficiency and cost effectiveness that one could think of. Pharmacists are currently buried in paper work to meet the demands of a bureaucratic payment scheme. The promised improvements in the speed and accuracy of payments made to pharmacists have not been forthcoming. Pharmacists are still being paid in guesstimates and averages of previous months billing. These two Bills clearly reflect the sort of administrative incompetence and ministerial inability to cope with the disasters being brought about in the health system in Australia by this Government's fixed and philosophic problems in health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Institute of Health Bill 1987 and the National Health Amendment Bill 1987. Principally, I wish to direct my remarks to the Institute of Health Bill. In doing so I wish to outline what the legislation aims to do and to refute some of the scurrilous claims made by the new shadow Minister for Health, Senator Michael Baume, who does not mind--
—What is scurrilous about the truth?

—Since the honourable senator asks, amongst other scurrilous things are his tactics of smearing people such as me and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). Let us talk about the facts, let us talk about the numbers, but if the honourable senator wants to drag name calling into this place he stands judged by his own smear remarks. This Bill establishes the Australian Institute of Health. It will, in essence, collect and provide assistance in the production of health related statistics, it will conduct and promote research into the health of the people of Australia, and it will undertake studies into the provision and effectiveness of health services and health technology.

SPEECH.PARA: In establishing this statutory authority, the legislation not only aims to make sure that there is actual and perceived independence of the collection of health statistics-that is an absolutely vital part of this legislation, and it also goes to one of the reasons why this legislation is establishing the Institute of Health as a statutory authority-but also establishes the long term viability of the authority. I will come back to that in a moment when I will tell the Senate what Mr Porter plans to do with this legislation should he ever get to be the Minister for Health.

The next point that will be insisted on and established through this legislation is the co-operation of States on data provision. Senator Michael Baume seems to be unclear about why we should have a statutory authority and why it is necessary to go down this road. One of the principal reasons is the importance of clear co-operation of the States, and to this point that co-operation has been, to say the least, troublesome. It is certainly clear that we do not have sufficient statistics to make any of the estimates that we need to make in this area. That certainly is the case. It is confirmed by all sorts of reports and by the Opposition itself. The co-operation of the States is critical to the successful outcome of health statistics being collected around this country. The Bill also provides legislative guarantees to the States of confidentiality of the information they provide. It will ensure the support of professional bodies and it will also enable the drawing in of researchers from outside of the Australian Public Service-a very important point that a statutory authority allows much more readily than an Institute within the Department of Health. The legislation also clearly defines the roles and structure of the Institute.

The Opposition made some extraordinary claims. One of the points raised by Senator Michael Baume was: `Why can't we use the Australian Bureau of Statistics?' He seemed to suggest that the Minister had never dealt with this or that there was no evidence of it. In establishing this legislation, the Government has insisted on good collaboration with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and that body will be represented in the Institute, so that optimal arrangement between the two statistical gathering bodies will continue. I draw two things to the attention of Senator Michael Baume, if he is not too busy talking to listen. I ask him to turn to page 62 of volume 1 of `Looking Forward to Better Health', a Better Health Commission report. The Senate will remember that this report was tabled in 1986. Under the heading `Why are our health statistics so poor?' there is an accounting of the fact that we have huge gaps in health statistics and health statistical organisational structures around this country, and that in 1976, presumably under the Opposition which was then in government, the National Committee for Health and Vital Statistics was established to co-ordinate State collections and to identify priorities. It had little success in this area. The paragraph goes on to point out:
In addition, within ABS there has been a lack of enthusiasm about health statistics and, indeed, an apparent lack of understanding of their social purpose and importance.

That is a comment in the Better Health Commission report on one of the insufficiencies of the collection of health statistics under the arrangements up until then. I also draw to the attention of Senator Michael Baume a document put out by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission titled `Occupational Injury and Disease Statistics: Proposals for a Minimum Data Set'. The honourable senator might argue that occupational health and safety does not come directly under the Australian Institute of Health, but the relevant points and comments are very much the same as those made in the Better Health Commission report and in other reports mentioned by Senator Michael Baume or other Opposition people in the House of Representatives. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission report comments:

The extent to which State and Territory compensation authorities have adopted the ABS standard varies, and at the present time it is not possible to produce a nationally comparable set of compensation-based statistics.

I go to another comment in the same document which says that these statistics between States are not comprehensive in coverage, that they lack reliability and consistency between States, that these deficiencies are due to a number of reasons, and that the ABS to this point is insufficient to collect that data. If Senator Michael Baume were listening he would realise that that would at least refute those points that he raised in some strange way to suggest that the establishment of something that might do the job thoroughly and competently is not to be encouraged. The main objection from the Opposition, of course, is that it is a statutory authority. It claims that we want to have better statistics but it seems to be griping about the way in which the Government is proposing to do it.

The next important point in looking at this legislation was to anticipate what the Opposition would say against it. As in the debate we had the other day, the Opposition's objections to this legislation are, again, boringly predictable. It referred to bulk billing statistics. Senator Michael Baume had no difficulty in smearing my name across this chamber. By way of refutation, I refer him to the claims by the Minister. If he wishes to call him a liar that is his business, but I think it is a disgraceful thing to do so. I also object strenuously to being so called myself.

If, as the Opposition claims, we have insufficient statistics, how can it suggest that anything that is said on either side can be believed or refuted. The Opposition seems to suggest that anything we say is a lie, based on insufficient statistics, and anything it says is the truth, based on the same insufficient statistics. One wonders what source it has to feel as though it is right. I do not quite understand the logic of it saying `We need better statistics' and `We've got the answer'. That is a very simple and basic contradiction in terms, but apparently it is beyond the Opposition to deal with it.

I turn now to the bulk billing figures and the peculiar and clever little tricks that Senator Michael Baume was playing. If we compare the actual yearly statistics it can be seen that in 1983, the last full calendar year of the final Fraser Government health scheme, each Australian used an average of 7.7 medical services. In the 1986 calendar year the average was 7.68-in effect, an identical utilisation rate. Senator Baume claimed that figures proving increased costs suggest that there has been an increased usage. A couple of things ought to be borne in mind. Firstly, Senator Tate interjected to point out that the costs provided an insufficient analysis because one would then have to work out the cost of an individual item or service and some of the treatments under Medicare were much more expensive than others. A reliance on cost figures is fraught with difficulties. It is unreliable and insufficient. Secondly, the increase in services has occurred for a number of reasons. Let me read the following:

The growth in use of and spending on medical services has been rising throughout the last decade with or without Medicare and bulk billing. Between mid-1975 and mid-1983 pathology use increased by 105 per cent, radiology by 55 per cent, with an overall increase in medical services of 20 per cent. With Medicare there has been a slight increase in the use of services. However, this is expected as Medicare is intended to remove financial barriers which have prevented people in the past using those services.

The two million Australians who were disadvantaged under Fraser health schemes and could not afford to go to the doctor were able to do so in Medicare. Many of those who previously had waited until they could see their way to being able to afford going to a doctor went to their doctors once Medicare was introduced by the Labor Government. Of course, they would have accounted for some small increase in the number of services being measured. Essentially, let me quote again from the figures mentioned by the Minister for Health. In 1983 each Australian used an average of 7.7 medical services if the full year's statistics are compared with the average of 7.68 in 1986. To all intents and purposes there is no change.

The other important thing is that, when talking about health costs, to selectively pick out statistics, which Senator Baume has done, is again to misrepresent the position. This Government has held the costs of health care to about 7.5 per cent of gross domestic product. Another area that I am surprised Senator Baume did not raise is the great furphy that the Opposition likes to wheel up; that is, the hospital waiting lists. I am not quite sure to what we owe our freedom from that attack tonight. But, in anticipation of Senator Walters speaking this evening, let me refute the wild, ridiculous and again very misleading claims of the Opposition. The Opposition suggests that 100,000 people are on hospital waiting lists around this country. That is an absolutely wicked claim. It is nothing more than a scaremongering tactic. A recent Australian Hospital Association survey concluded that the number of people on waiting lists was well below those quoted by Senator Baume. As for his claim that people on waiting lists are dying, I refer him to a reply on the same subject by former Senator Grimes. He is reported in the Hansard of 16 April 1986 as replying to a question from Senator Peter Baume as follows:

I was disappointed with the last five minutes of Senator Peter Baume's speech, because he said something I have not heard him say before and which I did not expect to hear him say in this place. I can get up and say: `I know two people who died in recent times while waiting for cardiac surgery and waiting for a bed in one of Sydney's leading private hospitals'. Am I entitled to get up and say, therefore, that the private hospital system is crook because that happened to those people, who had conditions from which one may die at any moment? This is absolute nonsense. If I got up and made a statement like that, Senator Peter Baume would laugh at me, but it happens to be true-I do know two people who died while waiting for cardiac surgery, waiting for beds in private hospitals, as people will always wait for beds in public hospitals and private hospitals.
Senator Grimes went on to say:
Senator Peter Baume has done what so many Opposition and conservative politicians do in this place. They come in and say that we have problems in our hospital system . . .

He said that, according to the Opposition, this was all due to Medicare, and to the Labor Government and did not exist before this Government came to power. Senator Grimes described that assertion as `hogwash'. I am happy to put it on the record in my own name that that claim by the Opposition is utter hogwash. The Opposition simply does not understand the issues, although these were spelt out for Senator Michael Baume in that recent debate. At a recent Australian Health Ministers conference, all Health Ministers agreed that the following factors affect waiting times: Nurse shortages resulting in bed closures; the supply of some specialist medical services, such as orthopaedic surgeons; advances in technology allowing a greater variety of procedures, such as coronary bypass surgery, lens implants for eyes, or hip and other joint replacements to be more readily performed; and greater public awareness of new improved technology leading to greater demand. The Health Ministers agreed that it was up to the States and the Territories to develop programs to overcome waiting list problems. But, as I said, at that time the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, agreed to provide support, co-operation and proposals to assist the States in dealing with those difficulties.

I remind Senator Michael Baume that, as he should be aware, 14,000 people had elective surgery in Victorian public hospitals in March 1987, the last month for which statistics are available, and that overall public hospital waiting lists for elective surgery fell by more than 1,000 in that month. If the honourable senator wants to use figures I urge him to approximate facts rather than provide the scurrilous fiction that he has used not just to argue against us-he knows full well that this legislation will go through-but simply to scare people out in the community. I hope that they understand that his scare tactics will do nothing. If the Opposition intends to do away with Medicare and, as stated by Mr Porter in the other place, to do away with the Australian Institute of Health, how could it have any figures from which to draw conclusions? It is quite clear that members of the Opposition do not need figures with which to argue; they just need any faint suggestion that pops into their heads. All they need is a good idea.

In stressing the importance of this legislation I wish to cite another group of figures, which I would not argue were statistics. In 1982, Mr Macphee, a Minister in the previous Government, said that occupational health and safety was a disaster that this country had failed to address and must address. As I remember, according to his figures about 300 Australian workers died per year and the cost was assessed at $4.5 billion. A mere two years later, the figures still suggested that 300 Australians were dying each year from work related injuries or accidents, but the cost had risen to $6.5 billion. We then observed claims of 300 deaths emanating from New South Wales. Victoria had a bid for 300 deaths per year, and we eventually reached a figure of about 800 people dying every year from work related accidents or injuries in this country. In other words, such figures are still grossly unreliable. They point to the absolute importance of statistical collections of health costs and health related matters, such as occupational health and safety statistics, and they also point to the importance of the work this Institute will do in standardising definitions and methodologies, in analysing figures and in standardising the collection of data and what is being counted in any one of those collections.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think the Bureau of Statistics does?

—I have already pointed out-the honourable senator was too busy chatting in the gallery to notice-why the ABS figures are insufficient and why they have not been able to do the job to this point. The remarks made by Opposition senators and by Senator Michael Baume point to the inadequacy of those statistics to this point and why the legislation in this chamber is of such importance.
—They haven't been given the job.

—Does the honourable senator want me to run through the statistics again? Let me refer the honourable senator again to volume 1 of the report of the Better Health Commission. This matter is referred to and spelt out in that report. It actually says that the Australian Bureau of Statistics had a lack of enthusiasm about health statistics and, indeed, an apparent lack of understanding of their social purpose and importance. That was said not by me or the Minister but by the Better Health Commission, which took a lot of time to come up with this comprehensive and thorough report. Indeed, the honourable senator might wish to quote from other parts and chapters of the report. Will the honourable senator be selective about which parts of the report he agrees with? We have already refuted that, but I am happy to do it again for Senator Baume now that he is listening and taking notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the importance of this legislation can be overstressed. The Minister has made quite clear why the Institute needs to be a statutory authority. First, it is to ensure the best co-operation with the States and Territories, which is absolutely critical if the health statistics which we all need, want and hope will become more comprehensive, adequate and reliable than they are currently, are to do so. Understandably, as Senator Baume said, there has been ill-will or suspicion in the past which means that relations among the Commonwealth, States and Territories need to be specially addressed. The Minister has done that in this legislation by establishing the independence of a statutory authority.

The second important point that the legislation to establish the statutory authority provides is contained in the very significant clauses going to the confidentiality of that information, not only for States and Territories or departments but also very much for individuals because some of those statistics are not about costs or numbers of beds, but about the health status of people in this country. Another very important point that I would like to reiterate is that of being able to invite to work in the Institute researchers of world reputation in this critical area-in the methodology of examining statistics and even of looking at what should be measured.

I will move to some areas of great interest to me-other areas of the Better Health Commission report that point to the importance of public promotion of good health, the establishment of preventative focuses in the whole delivery of health services and promotion, and the importance of adequate epidemiological data to discover the health status of Australians and whether any programs put in place to implement the altered health status of the community can be measured. The significance of all that cannot be overemphasised. Just in passing, the Minister points out that there will be no financial impact, no increase in costs, with the establishment of the statutory authority. But I am quite sure that members of the Opposition would presume him to be a liar on that point too. Those opposite are of little minds and one cannot argue with little minds. The importance of the health status--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are so polite.

—I thank Senator Baume for that. I am much more polite than he is. He is a very much meaner person. The things the Government has promoted and intends to promote further under the Better Health Commission-and has already implemented in some areas; for example, its program to try to eradicate measles-are very important. They certainly go to the prospect of changing and improving the health status of Australians. But there is no way that we can rely on a good guess or what seems to be the case. It is absolutely critical, not only in terms of properly accounting for the expenditure of taxpayers' dollars but also in terms of claiming whether the services being put in place are having an effect. For example, if insufficient people are immunised against measles, the prospect of a measles epidemic is always on the cards. Measles is one of those diseases that, while a lot of people think it is just a childhood disease, has a very serious series of consequences in a sufficiently high number of people to more than justify the measles eradication program.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of health statistics that really deserves the Senate's attention is the appalling statistics, to the extent that we have them, on the status of Aboriginal health. It is a great shock to me that to be born Aboriginal means a person is more likely-according to some statistics, three times, and according to others, five times more likely-to die very young than a person born to white parents. That alone is sufficient to justify a complete campaign by the Government. I am entirely in support of the steps being taken by the Department of Health and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to try to address that and all other areas of Aboriginal health. Again, the definition of who is Aboriginal and the importance of being able to measure much more accurately the statistics on our Aboriginal population are absolutely critical. These matters certainly demand the attention of the Senate and this country. They certainly have the attention of the Government but they are one small example of a statistic that I think justifies the Government's very serious intent through this legislation to ensure that our health statistics are the very best possible.

Other changes in the area of public health include improved prospects for training. The establishment of the Master of Public Health, now decentralised and available in a number of States, will contribute to the establishment of better statistical data and analysis and to having more people with those skills, and also to alternative ways of implementing health services to ensure an improvement in the health status of Australians. There are a number of critical areas that one could cite in justification of the importance of having the Institute to collect this information. I turn to page 69 of volume 1 of the Better Health Commission report. I will quote a small item from a whole chapter referring to evaluation and the absolute importance of it, the reason why we have not had sufficient evaluation to this point, the importance of standardisation and so on. This is very well illustrated by the following paragraph, which states:

The evaluation of random breath-testing . . . provides further compelling evidence of the need for an adequate national statistical data base. Australia has no national hospital inpatient statistics collected and the quality and scope of such collections that do exist varies among and within States. The Hunter region is the only New South Wales region with fully enumerated public hospital morbidity data for each year since 1977. Using this information, it has been shown that the introduction of RBT in the Hunter region was associated with a 20 per cent decline in the number of patients admitted to a hospital with traffic accident injuries. This figure is over and above the 3 per cent per annum decline observed during the previous five years.

If anything illustrates the importance of adequate and comprehensive statistics and data collection, that does. If a program, for example the random breath test program, is implemented, it is absolutely critical to find out whether the expenditure of costs and time, particularly by our police forces, is justified. There are many demands on our police forces. Implementing a random breath test program has to be justified in terms of cost savings and the changed health status of the community. That small example from the Hunter region of New South Wales suggests that there was a 20 per cent decline. By any criterion, that is a very good justification for having random breath tests. If we did not have that figure we would be going on only a best guess of the effect of random breath testing.

We must have much more adequate and national statistical collection. The importance of national statistics cannot be overstated. Most of our health services are delivered through the States and Territories but we have a Federal government responsible, in large part, for the expenditure of public dollars to deliver those services through the States. The Government honourably and properly requires adequate and proper collection of data, even if we look only at proper evaluation of the expenditure of those dollars. But the Government is also very concerned with putting in place legislation that will allow comprehensive and proper collection of epidemiological statistics that go not only to the evaluation of dollars but also to the health status of individuals and communities.

I do not understand how the Opposition possibly can object to this legislation. The principal objection of those opposite seems to be that while we need all those things we do not need a statutory authority to get them. Their arguments finished with a lot of evidence that despite the fact that we have insufficient statistics, Medicare is still to blame for everything. I simply point out that out of their own mouths they are hung with such an argument. The Government appreciates the difficulties in gathering and the importance of these statistics. It says that the best way to go is the statutory authority way, principally to deal with the points that I have already enumerated but will state once again. I refer to the absolutely vital regard that must be placed on the co-operation of the States. Clearly, I have spelt that out on a number of occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is possible through the ABS.

—While it may be possible, Senator Baume, that the Australian Bureau of Statistics should do it, to this point it has not. However, it has been charged with doing it for quite some time. I have pointed out that it is not committed to doing it and to this point it has been inadequate in doing it. Further, the ABS will be involved as it will be participating in the Institute of Health. I would have thought that the co-operation and collaboration that is allowed between the Institute of Health and the ABS in the collection of this data is the preferred way to go. I also hope that there will be close co-operation and collaboration between the Australian Institute of Health and the Occupational Health and Safety Institute in collecting that very large body of information about accident and injury in respect of people in the work force in this country. As well as that, it is to be hoped that one day we will see established a proper national births, deaths and marriages register so that a more adequate set of comprehensive data about morbidity and mortality and health statistics in general will be available to the people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I welcome tonight the introduction of the Australian Institute of Health Bill and the National Health Amendment Bill which we are debating cognately. The Democrats intend to support both Bills, but we will be raising a number of concerns about each. We will move an amendment to the Australian Institute of Health Bill which we believe will strengthen the legislation and enhance the operation of the new Institute. First, I will deal with the National Health Amendment Bill which, of course, is concerned with streamlining the operation of the safety net provisions for pharmaceutical benefits which were introduced in last year's Budget with the support of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The safety net scheme is consistent with the ethos of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which was first introduced in 1950 to mitigate the financial hardship associated with necessary drug use. The system which we had until last year buffered all Australian users from what most pharmaceuticals would otherwise have cost us, and particularly protected those of little financial means. With the introduction of the safety net, we saw the recognition of the criterion of chronic illness in an individual or family as a basis for additional subsidisation, and the Australian Democrats very much welcomed this move. The pharmaceutical `safety net' was consistent with our amendment to the original Medicare legislation to place a ceiling on the maximum medical payments which would accrue to any one person in any year. Unfortunately, a number of overly large holes in the net still leave certain Australians with chronic illness out in the cold. I will return to these problems which perpetuate financial hardship for those families with most illness after commenting on the significant provisions before us in this Bill.

Clause 4 extends the operation of the safety net by making two exceptions to the requirement that prescriptions will only count towards eligibility if the maximum quantity is prescribed. This provision was included originally to prevent splitting scripts into smaller prescribed quantities so that a total of 25 scripts could be reached more quickly. The amendments here provide for, first, transitional arrangements should the Minister revise his or her determination of the appropriate maximum quantity and, secondly, an exception in the case of dangerous or addictive drugs. I particularly welcome the amendment made by clause 4 (2) to address the dangers of excessive prescribing, and the Democrats note the major problems facing our country in this area. Claims that the safety net scheme is already running well over budget indicate that Australian families are clocking up 25 scripts more quickly than had been expected and that the rate of prescribing in this country had been underestimated. The number of Australians obtaining free pharmaceuticals through the safety net is just one more indication that we need to look carefully at doctors' prescribing habits and other influences on the level of pharmaceutical use and abuse in this country. It is certainly true, as was recommended in the Industries Assistance Commission report on pharmaceutical products, that we need to see increased information to prescribers, pharmacists and consumers about the costs of pharmaceutical over-use.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) made certain flourishes about `the Government's present drug initiatives' in the context of clause 4 (2). I can only say that, given the history of therapeutic disasters associated with thalidomide, the Dalkon shield, the anti-depressant, merital, the anti-inflammatory, opren-and the list goes on-and examples of incompetent or fraudulent scientific `studies', for example, into the pill, and the recently infamous 33 generics, it is a pity that the review into the evaluation of pharmaceuticals and the revision of therapeutic goods legislation has taken so long. Furthermore, while tobacco and alcohol promotion continue without further restrictions, while the Aboriginal youth of Australia are being destroyed through petrol sniffing and while the social ills of poverty and hopelessness promote substance abuse throughout society, the Government has no cause to be over-confident about its drug policies.

Clauses 5, 6, 7 and 11 of this Bill make changes to administrative arrangements concerning the issue of safety net entitlement cards. The requirement that supporting documentation be retained by the Department of Health rather than individual pharmacists is clearly a welcome reduction of bureaucratic imposition on private businesses. The provision that the fee to be paid to pharmacists, for issuing the card for the Commonwealth, is to be set with the agreement of the Pharmacy Guild is a welcome instance of consultation with industry; and the provision for advance payments to pharmacists in certain circumstances is similarly sensible.

The subject matter of clause 8, and the associated clauses 9 and 10, however cause the Australian Democrats some concern. Clause 8 concerns the `special patient contribution', a charge which was introduced by the Government in 1985 as section 85b of the principal Act. The charge was introduced to deal with situations of failure to reach an agreement between the Government and the manufacturer as to the price to be charged for an item when no other therapeutically equivalent alternative exists. The charge is the difference between the price the Government is prepared to attach to the drug for pharmaceutical benefits listing and the price claimed by the manufacturer. Currently, special patient contributions apply to three products: An anti cancer drug, a fertility drug and to a preparation commonly taken by epileptics known as dilantin. Patients requiring these drugs pay an additional charge over and above the approved Commonwealth dispensed price to which the products are subsidised. In the case of dilantin, the price to patients has increased by 44.7 per cent in two years. The Democrats are concerned because each of these drugs treat chronic illness, and in each case a patient has no substituteable alternative, meaning an additional cost to ill and vulnerable people.

Democrat health policy advocates protection for the chronically ill against the compounded hardship of financial strain which they can experience. However, we recognise that this charge represents the outcome of the judgment and negotiation of the Government with manufacturers which has given Australians pharmaceuticals at prices much lower than most overseas levels. In fact, average drug prices range from 65 per cent to 100 per cent higher in the United States of America than is the case in Australia, from 40 per cent to 80 per cent higher in many Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and 37 per cent higher in New Zealand. So the system has worked to our advantage except in relation to those exceptions. The Democrats are opposed to the concept of a special charge on chronically ill patients, but we recognise the function this serves as a disincentive to indiscriminate price increases by manufacturers. Accordingly, in spite of our reservations, we will support clause 8 of this Bill, but we call on the Government to seek a mechanism which will discourage unilateral price increases without penalising the patients as it does at present-albeit in a relatively small number of instances.

The Democrats are also concerned about what we see as a second major flaw with the safety net. This is its failure to protect those Australians who obtain pharmaceuticals from hospitals in those States which raise a charge for drugs to outpatients. These charges range from nothing in some States to $10 per script, with considerable variation across the States. In South Australia, where a charge of $7.50 per script applies, a State safety net pays for drugs after three scripts of $22.50 per family per month. However, a family with one, let alone more than one, chronically ill member can soon pay $270 a year to a hospital in this way in that State, quite separately from the $250 that it might pay filling scripts in community pharmacies. Patients are easily caught in a limbo between the State and Federal systems and, safety nets notwithstanding, can pay up to $620 a year, or even more if any of their drugs attract a special patient contribution. While we recognise that many Australians are in a better position after the revision of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme last year, the Democrats call upon the Government to correct this anomaly by negotiation and consultation with all State governments to provide better for those patients whose circumstances are jeopardised by a lack of co-ordination between the levels of government.

The other Bill that is before us tonight seeks to establish the Australian Institute of Health as an independent statutory body. The Institute currently exists as part of the Commonwealth Department of Health, with the function of co-ordinating research in public health and health services for Australia, emphasising social medicine, health statistics and health economics. This Bill seeks to make the Institute a separate body and to broaden its functions to facilitate the collection of data and the conduct of research. Australia's poor performance in the collection of health status information is well known and documented. The need to take action on this lack of data and on evaluation of health services and technology has recently been identified in both the Review of Research and Teaching of Public Health in Australia, known as the Kerr White report, and the report of the Better Health Commission, both of which have been alluded to in the debate already.

It is no secret that Australia ranks low internationally in the collection of health data and, according to the World Health Organisation, lowest of 16 developed countries in the collation of hospital statistics. There is bipartisan recognition that a reliable database is an absolute prerequisite for priority setting and resource allocation decisions in health care, yet the Opposition has opposed this Bill here and in the other place where it has argued that an independent statutory authority is not necessary to carry out these functions effectively.

The Democrats have considered this proposition but have not been convinced by the arguments. It seems to us that the short sighted, curative, acute care approach to illness which the Opposition has so often demonstrated has again caused it to put its collective head in the sand. The Institute of Health does not and will not work optimally as it is currently constituted. The truth, of course, is that the sort of information that we need nationally has been least forthcoming from those States where the Federal Opposition parties are in power. We need an Institute that is both really independent and seen to be independent from the Commonwealth Department of Health and from other government agencies, and it is for this reason that the Democrats support this Bill. In addition, we can be confident that the future of the Institute is better secured from a hostile Opposition as a statutory authority than as a departmental division. An independent body, we would hope, will also be more conducive to community input than an established bureaucracy. The capacity of a non-departmental body to attract a range of researchers is also very important. The staffing arrangements of the Institute are intended to be flexible enough to accommodate academic and a range of contract staff. Clause 19 of the Bill deals with this matter, we believe, satisfactorily.

The particular provisions of this Bill that are of interest to the Democrats are clause 5, which sets out its functions, and clause 8, which determines its composition, as these are the factors which we believe will determine its success to a very large extent. We are concerned to ensure that a range of researchers should, within the limits of confidentiality, of course, have access to the health information held by the Institute. The Democrats are concerned that community based researchers, not only those affiliated with formal research bodies, should be in a position to conduct investigations into the variables affecting the health of Australians. It is critical, in my view, that this information gets out of the ivory towers and gives power to those people in the community who are concerned with wellness, not just illness. We have been advised that the word `researchers' in clause 5 (1) (h) would include a very broad range of people and bodies conducting research. I will be seeking an assurance to this effect from the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) as Minister representing the Minister for Health.

In this context we are pleased to note that clause 5 (1) (d) expressly confers on the Institute the function of facilitating research by other groups, which was one of the recommendations of the review of community participation in the Department of Health. Ultimately, of course, the leadership and ethos of the Institute will determine its success, at least as much as legislation can. However, the Democrats believe that another significant step is needed to encourage community responsiveness in the Institute. This is to add the Consumers Health Forum to the Institute's Board. The Democrats will be moving an amendment to this effect. As it is constituted under clause 8 (1), the Institute is made up of academic and bureaucratic appointments. The expertise of those likely to be appointed is not in question at all, but the perspectives that they bring and the interests that they represent are not everything that the Institute needs. The Democrats, along with many others, want to see consumer and community input into this body and its decisions about resource allocation, health service and technology evaluation, and information dissemination.

The Consumers Health Forum was established by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in response to the recommendations of the review of community participation in the Department of Health. Like the Institute, the Forum has very exciting potential, despite being well overdue as a mechanism to redress the imbalance of influence that has existed between providers and administrators of health services and those who receive them. Our amendment seeks to add the Forum to the Institute for the very purpose for which the Forum was set up-that is, to provide community input into health policy decisions. Accordingly, we expect Government support for this amendment. Anything else would be an abandonment of the Minister's stated commitment to community consultation and a betrayal of those who believe the Government to be bona fide about the Health Forum and what it represents.

The other key provisions of this legislation are clauses 29 and 30 concerning the confidentiality of information obtained by the Institute. The Democrats have received a number of submissions about the desirable weighting of these mechanisms for protection, but we accept that in the circumstances the provisions proposed should encapsulate the appropriate balance to ensure that the Institute both obtains and respects the information it will need-the information that Australia needs in order to address the health challenges of the future.

The Australian Democrats welcome the new Institute of Health and recognise its critical role in our response to the World Health Organisation's goals for the year 2000. Until now, in its current form, the Institute has been known only through its annual report. We need an Institute of Health with dynamism. It needs newsletters and seminars, not just reports, as effective channels for communicating about its work. We need an Institute which takes a positive role in educational outreach. Its information must be presented in user friendly forms. It should produce a directory of research, a contact list of staff and a liaison person as a first point of contact, amongst a range of other initiatives, to maximise its accessibility. We can only hope that the job ahead of an organisation which represents such a positive initiative is not compounded by Budget cuts which enshrine the inhumane values of the New Right and disregard the public welfare in favouring greater private and corporate gain. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats will be moving the appropriate amendments and will subsequently be supporting the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating cognately the National Health Amendment Bill 1987, which is to amend the National Health Act 1953, and the Australian Institute of Health Bill 1987. The first Bill is one with which we would have no argument. We agree that it points up the incompetence of the Government that it has got so far behind with its own payments that it now has to pass legislation to pay retrospectively some of the bills that it should have paid, were it competent.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall confine my words to the Australian Institute of Health Bill. The purpose of that Bill is to set up a new statutory authority to be called the Australian Institute of Health. The functions of that Institute are clearly set out at page 2 of the Bill in clause 5:
The functions of the Institute are:

(a) to collect, with the agreement of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and, if necessary, with the Bureau's assistance, health-related information and statistics, whether by itself or in association with other bodies or persons;
(b) to produce health-related information and statistics, whether by itself or in association with other bodies or persons;
(c) to co-ordinate the collection and production of health-related information and statistics by other bodies or persons;
(d) to provide assistance, including financial assistance, for the collection and production of health-related information and statistics by other bodies or persons-
those are the ones that deal with statistics. The Bill goes on and deals with evaluation, but it is not very clear-
(e) to develop methods and undertake studies designed to assess the provision, use, cost and effectiveness of health services and health technologies;
(f) to conduct and promote research into the health of the people of Australia and their health services;

(g) to develop, in consultation with the Australian Bureau of Statistics, specialised statistical standards and classifications relevant to health and health services, and advise the Bureau on the data to be used by it for the purposes of health-related statistics . . .
It goes on to say further:
(j) to publish methodological and substantive reports on work carried out by or in association with the Institute;
(k) to make recommendations to the Minister on the prevention and treatment of diseases . . .
(m) to do anything incidental to any of the foregoing.

So what it is basically saying is that the Government wants to set up this statutory authority to gather data with the agreement and help of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, to develop studies to assess the provision, use and cost effectiveness of health services, and to do some research into the health of the people of Australia and their health services.

There are so many committees of this Parliament that have sat, and indeed I have been a member of two of those that asked for additional data. I have no problem whatsoever in the Government seeking accurate additional data. Indeed, the report of the committee of which I was a member and of which Senator Peter Baume was Chairman submitted a report called `Through a Glass, Darkly'. It was a report solely on evaluation of Australia's health and welfare services.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good report, too.
—It is a very good report. The part I would like to read is headed `The Rationale of the Report'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This report asserts that, in order to achieve an efficient, effective, rational and equitable health and welfare system, it is necessary to conduct ongoing evaluation.

Evaluation need not be confining. There is a wide range of possible evaluation methods and no need for any program to be confined to one prescriptive format. Evaluation reports can make it possible to improve programs and rectify mistakes and, at time, they may indicate a need for program termination.

The benefits derived from evaluation include increased accountability of decision makers, improvement in the decision-making process, more effective use of resources, and enhancement of the capacity of organisations to strengthen their bids for additional resources. The consequences of not evaluating are possible indiscriminate cuts in funds, indiscriminate handing out of funds, continuance of the present ad hoc decision-making process . . .

It is very clear that this Government needs evaluation. It has had so many people telling it that it is not cost effective to have universal bulk billing. Its chief medical adviser, Professor Penington, has told it that indiscriminate bulk billing is not cost effective, and yet it refuses to believe him. He has said that health care costs are out of control. He has told the Government repeatedly. He has told the Government that if it continues automatic universal bulk billing it is headed for disaster, and yet the Government will not heed his words and has decided instead to set up a whole statutory authority to be told exactly what Professor Penington has already told it but it will not take any notice of. Senator Grimes was a member of the Committee which recommended that the Commonwealth Government direct the Australian Bureau of Statistics to raise an appropriate level of its proportion of its budget spent specifically on health and welfare statistics. He did not see the need for a full statutory authority to be set up to do that. Senator Grimes, along with all the rest of us on that committee, said that the Commonwealth should direct the Australian Bureau of Statistics to do it and direct it to set aside a certain proportion of its budget to enable it to do so. But there is no need for a statutory authority to do that. Senator Grimes has now left this place, and Senator Walsh really amazes me. He is the Minister on duty in this chamber at the moment. Why does he allow the Government to spend this sort of money when we are already paying the Australian Bureau of Statistics to do this? All the Government has to do is to instruct the Bureau to do it, instead of setting up a totally new authority. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank Senator Walters for sitting down before time to give me the opportunity of complying with the Standing Orders. Pursuant to Standing Orders I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 2 standing in my name for the next day of sitting for disallowance of the Christmas Island Lands Ordinance 1987. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ordinance reforms land law on Christmas Island. The Committee was concerned about the absence of review of decisions of the Administrator to be exercised under ministerial guidelines. After taking evidence from officials the Committee has agreed that Administrative Appeals Tribunal review is not practicable. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has agreed with the Committee, however, that the guidelines should be subject to tabling and disallowance. The Committee thanks the Minister for his helpful response. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a more detailed statement of the Committee's scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Territory of Christmas Island Lands Ordinance 1987

This Ordinance makes wide ranging provision for control of the Island's leasehold land. The Committee was concerned about the extensive discretionary powers given to the Island Administrator to vary rents and determine leases without there being any independent avenue of review through which to challenge decisions. The Committee asked the Minister to advise it on the possibility of AAT review being provided making use of telephone hearings which could be available with the new satellite technology. The Minister in correspondence and through his officials who gave evidence before the Committee, explained that determination of residential rent levels was closely related to industrial relations negotiations on the Island and independent review in a single case could undermine complex agreements. It was also pointed out that telephone hearings could not always overcome the difficulties which might arise from the cultural and language differences as between the Island and the mainland. Finally, in deciding to withdraw its reservations about the lack of independent review the Committee noted that the Minister would be closely involved in personally deciding appeals against the Administrator's decisions on lease conditions and liabilities. The Committee decided therefore that it was not realistic to pursue the question of AAT review at this time.

The Committee also asked the Minister why Ministerial Guidelines to be followed by the Administrator in exercising his or her powers had not been made subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament as was usually the case with such instruments. It was explained to the Committee that Guidelines could contain instructions regarding the Administrator's preferred position in negotiating business leases, the premature publication of which could be damaging to the Commonwealth's position. Other Guidelines could contain instructions on when to act against defaulting leaseholders and tenants. Once again it was argued that publication of these could enable potential defaulters to take advantage of the Commonwealth.

The Committee considered that since the Guidelines would be the subject of consultations with the Island Assembly and since they would in any event be subject to the Freedom of Information Act, the traditional standard of parliamentary scrutiny should be maintained to prevent the possibility that Guidelines could be unfair or inappropriate. The Committee agreed that given the Minister's reservations, Guidelines containing financial criteria for negotiation of business leases need not be tabled. The Committee counselled that careful drafting of the Guidelines should ensure that they were adequate to protect the interests of both the Islanders and the Commonwealth without the need for resort to counterproductive unwritten ``ghost'' Guidelines.
