QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, on notice, on 22 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Defence's attention been drawn to an article in the National Times of 4-10 July 1986 concerning the role of the North West Cape Communications base.

(2) Can the Minister confirm that the current role of the base has been downgraded by a reduction of the range of its signals to 5000 kilometres and a reduction in the numbers of its VLF frequencies to 2; If so, does this mean that North West Cape is no longer a key communication base for US missile-bearing submarines and consequently, no longer has an important role in deterrence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The two VLF frequencies used by the Naval Communication Station at North West Cape are 15.5 kHz, which has been registered with the International Frequency Registration Board since 3 May 1967, and 22.3 kHz which had been registered since 21 April 1969. Both frequencies are registered with a nominal range of 5000 km. These registrations have been unchanged since 1967 and 1969 respectively.

While a number of other frequencies between 14 and 29 kHz were trialled when the Station was being established, these two are the only frequencies which have been used operationally since the Station became a joint facility in 1974. There has been no reduction in the number of operational frequencies registered for or used by the Station, or in their nominal registered range, since 1974. It should be noted, however, that the Station's VLF signals can be received with varying degrees of reliability at distances well in excess of the nominal registered range of 5000 km.
There has been no change in the role of the Station.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are recent media reports which state that from 1 July 1987, Telecom plan to charge between fifty cents and seventy cents for each call to directory assistance, correct.
(2) How many calls in each State and Territory were made to directory assistance in 1986.
(3) How can the Minister for Communications justify such an excessive charge given the fact that subscribers already pay a sixteen cent call charge fee for the service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom plans to introduce charging for some Directory Assistance calls from July 1988. The charge will apply only when the wanted number is listed in the local area, and not for enquiries concerning new connections, changed numbers or numbers outside the area of the local directory. Calls from public telephones and mobile telephones will also be free, and special arrangements will be made to ensure that handicapped people are not disadvantaged by the charge.
The actual charge to be applied has not yet been finalised, but will be based on the cost of processing those calls which relate to numbers published in the local directory.

(2) New South Wales and Australian Capital Territory, 37.6 million; Western Australia, 14.3 million; Victoria, 32.7 million; South Australia, 12.1 million; Queensland, 24.6 million; Tasmania, 2.7 million.

(3) All calls to Directory Assistance are at present free. The purpose of introducing a charge for calls to Directory Assistance when the required number is already listed in the local telephone directory is to help offset the considerable cost of providing the service (some $57 million in 1985-86) and encourage customers to use the telephone directory. Recent studies have shown that up to two thirds of calls to the 013 service are for numbers which are already published in the local directory. The charge will reduce the level of demand for directory assistance which at present cannot be economically satisfied, therefore enabling Telecom to provide a more efficient service to those people with a genuine need to call the Directory Assistance service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On whose authority were employees of the ACT Fire Brigade permitted to use the department's vehicles to stage the protest outside Parliament House, on 17 March 1987 including the use of sirens which are intended only for emergencies, as part of an attempt to intimidate Members and Senators of the Parliament.
(2) Who paid for the petrol and other costs involved in the protest.

(3) What action does the Minister for Territories intend to take to stop this kind of unauthorised use of emergency vehicles and what action can the Government take and will it take relating to this kind of noise pollution.

(4) Will the Minister now consider providing employment opportunities in the ACT Fire Brigade for the ACT's unemployed who are keen to work dispensing with the services of those Fire Brigade members whose skill at ripping off the compensation scheme and improperly using government equipment exceeds their enthusiasm for attending to their duty, given that the ACT Fire Brigade, in 1986, recorded an incredible workers compensation claim of 60 per cent of total employees even though they were on strike for much of the year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Brigade vehicles were used without appropriate authority.

(2) All costs, except for wages for the on-duty members, will be paid through the Brigade's appropriation. All on-duty members who attended the stop work meeting in front of Parliament House will have 2 hours wage deducted.

(3) and (4) The Fire Commissioner has taken appropriate action and has the full support of the Government. Since the election of the Hawke Government progressive action has been taken to reverse the types of problems which had developed because of the failure of the previous Government to establish the Brigade on a sound basis following its separation from New South Wales in 1978.
